   847	if you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by that
   848	AntichristâI really believe he is AntichristâI will have nothing
   849	more to do with you and you are no longer my friend, no longer my
   850	âfaithful slave,â as you call yourself! But how do you do? I see I
   851	have frightened youâsit down and tell me all the news.â
   852	
   853	It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna PÃ¡vlovna
   854	SchÃ©rer, maid of honor and favorite of the Empress MÃ¡rya FÃ«dorovna.
   855	With these words she greeted Prince VasÃ­li KurÃ¡gin, a man of high
   856	rank and importance, who was the first to arrive at her reception. Anna
   857	PÃ¡vlovna had had a cough for some days. She was, as she said, suffering
   858	from la grippe; grippe being then a new word in St. Petersburg, used
   859	only by the elite.
   860	
   861	All her invitations without exception, written in French, and delivered
   862	by a scarlet-liveried footman that morning, ran as follows:
   863	
   864	âIf you have nothing better to do, Count (or Prince), and if the
   865	prospect of spending an evening with a poor invalid is not too terrible,
   866	I shall be very charmed to see you tonight between 7 and 10âAnnette
   867	SchÃ©rer.â
   868	
   869	âHeavens! what a virulent attack!â replied the prince, not in the
   870	least disconcerted by this reception. He had just entered, wearing an
   871	embroidered court uniform, knee breeches, and shoes, and had stars on
   872	his breast and a serene expression on his flat face. He spoke in that
   873	refined French in which our grandfathers not only spoke but thought, and
   874	with the gentle, patronizing intonation natural to a man of importance
   875	who had grown old in society and at court. He went up to Anna PÃ¡vlovna,
   876	kissed her hand, presenting to her his bald, scented, and shining head,
   877	and complacently seated himself on the sofa.
   878	
   879	âFirst of all, dear friend, tell me how you are. Set your friendâs
   880	mind at rest,â said he without altering his tone, beneath the
   881	politeness and affected sympathy of which indifference and even irony
   882	could be discerned.
   883	
   884	âCan one be well while suffering morally? Can one be calm in times
   885	like these if one has any feeling?â said Anna PÃ¡vlovna. âYou are
   886	staying the whole evening, I hope?â
   887	
   888	âAnd the fete at the English ambassadorâs? Today is Wednesday. I
   889	must put in an appearance there,â said the prince. âMy daughter is
   890	coming for me to take me there.â
   891	
   892	âI thought todayâs fete had been canceled. I confess all these
   893	festivities and fireworks are becoming wearisome.â
   894	
   895	âIf they had known that you wished it, the entertainment would have
   896	been put off,â said the prince, who, like a wound-up clock, by force
   897	of habit said things he did not even wish to be believed.
   898	
   899	âDonât tease! Well, and what has been decided about NovosÃ­ltsevâs
   900	dispatch? You know everything.â
   901	
   902	âWhat can one say about it?â replied the prince in a cold, listless
   903	tone. âWhat has been decided? They have decided that Buonaparte has
   904	burnt his boats, and I believe that we are ready to burn ours.â
   905	
   906	Prince VasÃ­li always spoke languidly, like an actor repeating a stale
   907	part. Anna PÃ¡vlovna SchÃ©rer on the contrary, despite her forty years,
   908	overflowed with animation and impulsiveness. To be an enthusiast had
   909	become her social vocation and, sometimes even when she did not
   910	feel like it, she became enthusiastic in order not to disappoint the
   911	expectations of those who knew her. The subdued smile which, though it
   912	did not suit her faded features, always played round her lips expressed,
   913	as in a spoiled child, a continual consciousness of her charming defect,
   914	which she neither wished, nor could, nor considered it necessary, to
   915	correct.
   916	
   917	In the midst of a conversation on political matters Anna PÃ¡vlovna burst
   918	out:
   919	
   920	âOh, donât speak to me of Austria. Perhaps I donât understand
   921	things, but Austria never has wished, and does not wish, for war. She
   922	is betraying us! Russia alone must save Europe. Our gracious sovereign
   923	recognizes his high vocation and will be true to it. That is the one
   924	thing I have faith in! Our good and wonderful sovereign has to perform
   925	the noblest role on earth, and he is so virtuous and noble that God will
   926	not forsake him. He will fulfill his vocation and crush the hydra of
   927	revolution, which has become more terrible than ever in the person of
   928	this murderer and villain! We alone must avenge the blood of the just
   929	one.... Whom, I ask you, can we rely on?... England with her commercial
   930	spirit will not and cannot understand the Emperor Alexanderâs
   931	loftiness of soul. She has refused to evacuate Malta. She wanted to
   932	find, and still seeks, some secret motive in our actions. What answer
   933	did NovosÃ­ltsev get? None. The English have not understood and cannot
   934	understand the self-abnegation of our Emperor who wants nothing for
   935	himself, but only desires the good of mankind. And what have they
   936	promised? Nothing! And what little they have promised they will not
   937	perform! Prussia has always declared that Buonaparte is invincible, and
   938	that all Europe is powerless before him.... And I donât believe a
   939	word that Hardenburg says, or Haugwitz either. This famous Prussian
   940	neutrality is just a trap. I have faith only in God and the lofty
   941	destiny of our adored monarch. He will save Europe!â
   942	
   943	She suddenly paused, smiling at her own impetuosity.
   944	
   945	âI think,â said the prince with a smile, âthat if you had been
   946	sent instead of our dear Wintzingerode you would have captured the King
   947	of Prussiaâs consent by assault. You are so eloquent. Will you give me
   948	a cup of tea?â
   949	
   950	âIn a moment. Ã propos,â she added, becoming calm again, âI am
   951	expecting two very interesting men tonight, le Vicomte de Mortemart, who
   952	is connected with the Montmorencys through the Rohans, one of the best
   953	French families. He is one of the genuine Ã©migrÃ©s, the good ones. And
   954	also the AbbÃ© Morio. Do you know that profound thinker? He has been
   955	received by the Emperor. Had you heard?â
   956	
   957	âI shall be delighted to meet them,â said the prince. âBut
   958	tell me,â he added with studied carelessness as if it had only just
   959	occurred to him, though the question he was about to ask was the chief
   960	motive of his visit, âis it true that the Dowager Empress wants
   961	Baron Funke to be appointed first secretary at Vienna? The baron by all
   962	accounts is a poor creature.â

  6643	CHAPTER I
  6644	
  6645	In October, 1805, a Russian army was occupying the villages and towns of
  6646	the Archduchy of Austria, and yet other regiments freshly arriving from
  6647	Russia were settling near the fortress of Braunau and burdening the
  6648	inhabitants on whom they were quartered. Braunau was the headquarters of
  6649	the commander in chief, KutÃºzov.
  6650	
  6651	On October 11, 1805, one of the infantry regiments that had just reached
  6652	Braunau had halted half a mile from the town, waiting to be inspected
  6653	by the commander in chief. Despite the un-Russian appearance of the
  6654	locality and surroundingsâfruit gardens, stone fences, tiled roofs,
  6655	and hills in the distanceâand despite the fact that the inhabitants
  6656	(who gazed with curiosity at the soldiers) were not Russians, the
  6657	regiment had just the appearance of any Russian regiment preparing for
  6658	an inspection anywhere in the heart of Russia.
  6659	
  6660	On the evening of the last dayâs march an order had been received that
  6661	the commander in chief would inspect the regiment on the march. Though
  6662	the words of the order were not clear to the regimental commander, and
  6663	the question arose whether the troops were to be in marching order or
  6664	not, it was decided at a consultation between the battalion commanders
  6665	to present the regiment in parade order, on the principle that it is
  6666	always better to âbow too low than not bow low enough.â So the

  8859	CHAPTER IX
  8860	
  8861	Pursued by the French army of a hundred thousand men under the command
  8862	of Bonaparte, encountering a population that was unfriendly to it,
  8863	losing confidence in its allies, suffering from shortness of supplies,
  8864	and compelled to act under conditions of war unlike anything that had
  8865	been foreseen, the Russian army of thirty-five thousand men commanded
  8866	by KutÃºzov was hurriedly retreating along the Danube, stopping where
  8867	overtaken by the enemy and fighting rearguard actions only as far as
  8868	necessary to enable it to retreat without losing its heavy equipment.
  8869	There had been actions at Lambach, Amstetten, and Melk; but despite the
  8870	courage and enduranceâacknowledged even by the enemyâwith which the
  8871	Russians fought, the only consequence of these actions was a yet more
  8872	rapid retreat. Austrian troops that had escaped capture at Ulm and had
  8873	joined KutÃºzov at Braunau now separated from the Russian army, and
  8874	KutÃºzov was left with only his own weak and exhausted forces. The

 11023	The infantry regiments that had been caught unawares in the outskirts

 11623	Prince VasÃ­li was not a man who deliberately thought out his plans.

 14621	voices, and the army swayed and started in one enormous mass six miles
 14622	long.
 14623	
 14624	The concentrated activity which had begun at the Emperorâs
 14625	headquarters in the morning and had started the whole movement that
 14626	followed was like the first movement of the main wheel of a large tower
 14627	clock. One wheel slowly moved, another was set in motion, and a third,
 14628	and wheels began to revolve faster and faster, levers and cogwheels to
 14629	work, chimes to play, figures to pop out, and the hands to advance with
 14630	regular motion as a result of all that activity.
 14631	
 14632	Just as in the mechanism of a clock, so in the mechanism of the military
 14633	machine, an impulse once given leads to the final result; and just as
 14634	indifferently quiescent till the moment when motion is transmitted
 14635	to them are the parts of the mechanism which the impulse has not yet
 14636	reached. Wheels creak on their axles as the cogs engage one another and
 14637	the revolving pulleys whirr with the rapidity of their movement, but a
 14638	neighboring wheel is as quiet and motionless as though it were prepared
 14639	to remain so for a hundred years; but the moment comes when the lever
 14640	catches it and obeying the impulse that wheel begins to creak and joins
 14641	in the common motion the result and aim of which are beyond its ken.
 14642	
 14643	Just as in a clock, the result of the complicated motion of innumerable
 14644	wheels and pulleys is merely a slow and regular movement of the
 14645	hands which show the time, so the result of all the complicated human
 14646	activities of 160,000 Russians and Frenchâall their passions, desires,
 14647	remorse, humiliations, sufferings, outbursts of pride, fear, and
 14648	enthusiasmâwas only the loss of the battle of Austerlitz, the
 14649	so-called battle of the three Emperorsâthat is to say, a slow movement
 14650	of the hand on the dial of human history.

 15256	CHAPTER XIV
 15257	
 15258	At five in the morning it was still quite dark. The troops of the
 15259	center, the reserves, and BagratiÃ³nâs right flank had not yet moved,
 15260	but on the left flank the columns of infantry, cavalry, and artillery,
 15261	which were to be the first to descend the heights to attack the French
 15262	right flank and drive it into the Bohemian mountains according to plan,
 15263	were already up and astir. The smoke of the campfires, into which they
 15264	were throwing everything superfluous, made the eyes smart. It was cold
 15265	and dark. The officers were hurriedly drinking tea and breakfasting, the
 15266	soldiers, munching biscuit and beating a tattoo with their feet to
 15267	warm themselves, gathering round the fires throwing into the flames the
 15268	remains of sheds, chairs, tables, wheels, tubs, and everything that they
 15269	did not want or could not carry away with them. Austrian column guides
 15270	were moving in and out among the Russian troops and served as heralds
 15271	of the advance. As soon as an Austrian officer showed himself near
 15272	a commanding officerâs quarters, the regiment began to move: the
 15273	soldiers ran from the fires, thrust their pipes into their boots, their
 15274	bags into the carts, got their muskets ready, and formed rank. The
 15275	officers buttoned up their coats, buckled on their swords and pouches,
 15276	and moved along the ranks shouting. The train drivers and orderlies
 15277	harnessed and packed the wagons and tied on the loads. The adjutants and
 15278	battalion and regimental commanders mounted, crossed themselves, gave
 15279	final instructions, orders, and commissions to the baggage men
 15280	who remained behind, and the monotonous tramp of thousands of feet
 15281	resounded. The column moved forward without knowing where and unable,
 15282	from the masses around them, the smoke and the increasing fog, to see
 15283	either the place they were leaving or that to which they were going.
 15284	
 15285	A soldier on the march is hemmed in and borne along by his regiment as
 15286	much as a sailor is by his ship. However far he has walked, whatever
 15287	strange, unknown, and dangerous places he reaches, just as a sailor is
 15288	always surrounded by the same decks, masts, and rigging of his ship, so
 15289	the soldier always has around him the same comrades, the same ranks, the
 15290	same sergeant major IvÃ¡n MÃ­trich, the same company dog Jack, and the
 15291	same commanders. The sailor rarely cares to know the latitude in which
 15292	his ship is sailing, but on the day of battleâheaven knows how and
 15293	whenceâa stern note of which all are conscious sounds in the moral
 15294	atmosphere of an army, announcing the approach of something decisive
 15295	and solemn, and awakening in the men an unusual curiosity. On the day of
 15296	battle the soldiers excitedly try to get beyond the interests of their
 15297	regiment, they listen intently, look about, and eagerly ask concerning
 15298	what is going on around them.
 15299	
 15300	The fog had grown so dense that though it was growing light they could
 15301	not see ten paces ahead. Bushes looked like gigantic trees and level
 15302	ground like cliffs and slopes. Anywhere, on any side, one might
 15303	encounter an enemy invisible ten paces off. But the columns advanced
 15304	for a long time, always in the same fog, descending and ascending hills,
 15305	avoiding gardens and enclosures, going over new and unknown ground, and
 15306	nowhere encountering the enemy. On the contrary, the soldiers became
 15307	aware that in front, behind, and on all sides, other Russian columns
 15308	were moving in the same direction. Every soldier felt glad to know that
 15309	to the unknown place where he was going, many more of our men were going
 15310	too.

 15441	sufficiently weakened to be successfully attacked. But still he did not

 15443	
 15444	Today was a great day for himâthe anniversary of his coronation.
 15445	Before dawn he had slept for a few hours, and refreshed, vigorous, and

 15454	
 15455	When the sun had entirely emerged from the fog, and fields and mist were

 15460	a few minutes later the chief forces of the French army moved rapidly

 21025	
 21026	Soon after his admission to the Masonic Brotherhood, Pierre went to the

 23997	CHAPTER VI
 23998	
 23999	During the first weeks of his stay in Petersburg Prince Andrew felt the

 24002

 24009

 24119	CHAPTER VII
 24120	
 24121	Nearly two years before this, in 1808, Pierre on returning to Petersburg
 24122	after visiting his estates had involuntarily found himself in a leading
 24123	position among the Petersburg Freemasons. He arranged dining and funeral
 24124	lodge meetings, enrolled new members, and busied himself uniting various
 24125	lodges and acquiring authentic charters. He gave money for the erection
 24126	of temples and supplemented as far as he could the collection of alms,
 24127	in regard to which the majority of members were stingy and irregular.
 24128	He supported almost singlehanded a poorhouse the order had founded in
 24129	Petersburg.
 24130	
 24131	His life meanwhile continued as before, with the same infatuations and
 24132	dissipations. He liked to dine and drink well, and though he considered
 24133	it immoral and humiliating could not resist the temptations of the
 24134	bachelor circles in which he moved.
 24135	
 24136	Amid the turmoil of his activities and distractions, however, Pierre at
 24137	the end of a year began to feel that the more firmly he tried to rest
 24138	upon it, the more Masonic ground on which he stood gave way under him.
 24139	At the same time he felt that the deeper the ground sank under him the
 24140	closer bound he involuntarily became to the order. When he had joined
 24141	the Freemasons he had experienced the feeling of one who confidently
 24142	steps onto the smooth surface of a bog. When he put his foot down it
 24143	sank in. To make quite sure of the firmness of the ground, he put
 24144	his other foot down and sank deeper still, became stuck in it, and
 24145	involuntarily waded knee-deep in the bog.
 24146	
 24147	Joseph AlexÃ©evich was not in Petersburgâhe had of late stood aside
 24148	from the affairs of the Petersburg lodges, and lived almost entirely in
 24149	Moscow. All the members of the lodges were men Pierre knew in ordinary
 24150	life, and it was difficult for him to regard them merely as Brothers in
 24151	Freemasonry and not as Prince B. or IvÃ¡n VasÃ­levich D., whom he knew
 24152	in society mostly as weak and insignificant men. Under the Masonic
 24153	aprons and insignia he saw the uniforms and decorations at which they
 24154	aimed in ordinary life. Often after collecting alms, and reckoning up
 24155	twenty to thirty rubles received for the most part in promises from a
 24156	dozen members, of whom half were as well able to pay as himself, Pierre
 24157	remembered the Masonic vow in which each Brother promised to devote
 24158	all his belongings to his neighbor, and doubts on which he tried not to
 24159	dwell arose in his soul.
 24160	
 24161	He divided the Brothers he knew into four categories. In the first he
 24162	put those who did not take an active part in the affairs of the lodges
 24163	or in human affairs, but were exclusively occupied with the mystical
 24164	science of the order: with questions of the threefold designation of
 24165	God, the three primordial elementsâsulphur, mercury, and saltâor
 24166	the meaning of the square and all the various figures of the temple of
 24167	Solomon. Pierre respected this class of Brothers to which the elder ones
 24168	chiefly belonged, including, Pierre thought, Joseph AlexÃ©evich himself,
 24169	but he did not share their interests. His heart was not in the mystical
 24170	aspect of Freemasonry.
 24171	
 24172	In the second category Pierre reckoned himself and others like him,
 24173	seeking and vacillating, who had not yet found in Freemasonry a straight
 24174	and comprehensible path, but hoped to do so.
 24175	
 24176	In the third category he included those Brothers (the majority) who saw
 24177	nothing in Freemasonry but the external forms and ceremonies, and prized
 24178	the strict performance of these forms without troubling about their
 24179	purport or significance. Such were Willarski and even the Grand Master
 24180	of the principal lodge.
 24181	
 24182	Finally, to the fourth category also a great many Brothers belonged,
 24183	particularly those who had lately joined. These according to Pierreâs
 24184	observations were men who had no belief in anything, nor desire for
 24185	anything, but joined the Freemasons merely to associate with the wealthy
 24186	young Brothers who were influential through their connections or rank,
 24187	and of whom there were very many in the lodge.
 24188	
 24189	Pierre began to feel dissatisfied with what he was doing. Freemasonry,
 24190	at any rate as he saw it here, sometimes seemed to him based merely
 24191	on externals. He did not think of doubting Freemasonry itself, but
 24192	suspected that Russian Masonry had taken a wrong path and deviated
 24193	from its original principles. And so toward the end of the year he went
 24194	abroad to be initiated into the higher secrets of the order.
 24195	
 24196	In the summer of 1809 Pierre returned to Petersburg. Our Freemasons knew
 24197	from correspondence with those abroad that BezÃºkhov had obtained the
 24198	confidence of many highly placed persons, had been initiated into many
 24199	mysteries, had been raised to a higher grade, and was bringing back with
 24200	him much that might conduce to the advantage of the Masonic cause
 24201	in Russia. The Petersburg Freemasons all came to see him, tried to
 24202	ingratiate themselves with him, and it seemed to them all that he was
 24203	preparing something for them and concealing it.
 24204	
 24205	A solemn meeting of the lodge of the second degree was convened, at
 24206	which Pierre promised to communicate to the Petersburg Brothers what
 24207	he had to deliver to them from the highest leaders of their order. The
 24208	meeting was a full one. After the usual ceremonies Pierre rose and began
 24209	his address.
 24210	
 24211	âDear Brothers,â he began, blushing and stammering, with a written
 24212	speech in his hand, âit is not sufficient to observe our mysteries in
 24213	the seclusion of our lodgeâwe must actâact! We are drowsing, but we
 24214	must act.â Pierre raised his notebook and began to read.
 24215	
 24216	âFor the dissemination of pure truth and to secure the triumph of
 24217	virtue,â he read, âwe must cleanse men from prejudice, diffuse
 24218	principles in harmony with the spirit of the times, undertake the
 24219	education of the young, unite ourselves in indissoluble bonds with the
 24220	wisest men, boldly yet prudently overcome superstitions, infidelity, and
 24221	folly, and form of those devoted to us a body linked together by unity
 24222	of purpose and possessed of authority and power.
 24223	
 24224	âTo attain this end we must secure a preponderance of virtue over vice
 24225	and must endeavor to secure that the honest man may, even in this world,
 24226	receive a lasting reward for his virtue. But in these great endeavors we
 24227	are gravely hampered by the political institutions of today. What is
 24228	to be done in these circumstances? To favor revolutions, overthrow
 24229	everything, repel force by force?... No! We are very far from that.
 24230	Every violent reform deserves censure, for it quite fails to remedy
 24231	evil while men remain what they are, and also because wisdom needs no
 24232	violence.
 24233	
 24234	âThe whole plan of our order should be based on the idea of
 24235	preparing men of firmness and virtue bound together by unity of
 24236	convictionâaiming at the punishment of vice and folly, and patronizing
 24237	talent and virtue: raising worthy men from the dust and attaching
 24238	them to our Brotherhood. Only then will our order have the power
 24239	unobtrusively to bind the hands of the protectors of disorder and to
 24240	control them without their being aware of it. In a word, we must found a
 24241	form of government holding universal sway, which should be diffused over
 24242	the whole world without destroying the bonds of citizenship, and beside
 24243	which all other governments can continue in their customary course and
 24244	do everything except what impedes the great aim of our order, which
 24245	is to obtain for virtue the victory over vice. This aim was that of
 24246	Christianity itself. It taught men to be wise and good and for their
 24247	own benefit to follow the example and instruction of the best and wisest
 24248	men.
 24249	
 24250	âAt that time, when everything was plunged in darkness, preaching
 24251	alone was of course sufficient. The novelty of Truth endowed her with
 24252	special strength, but now we need much more powerful methods. It is
 24253	now necessary that man, governed by his senses, should find in virtue
 24254	a charm palpable to those senses. It is impossible to eradicate the
 24255	passions; but we must strive to direct them to a noble aim, and it is
 24256	therefore necessary that everyone should be able to satisfy his passions
 24257	within the limits of virtue. Our order should provide means to that end.
 24258	
 24259	âAs soon as we have a certain number of worthy men in every state,
 24260	each of them again training two others and all being closely united,
 24261	everything will be possible for our order, which has already in secret
 24262	accomplished much for the welfare of mankind.â
 24263	
 24264	This speech not only made a strong impression, but created excitement in
 24265	the lodge. The majority of the Brothers, seeing in it dangerous designs
 24266	of Illuminism, * met it with a coldness that surprised Pierre. The Grand
 24267	Master began answering him, and Pierre began developing his views with
 24268	more and more warmth. It was long since there had been so stormy a
 24269	meeting. Parties were formed, some accusing Pierre of Illuminism, others
 24270	supporting him. At that meeting he was struck for the first time by
 24271	the endless variety of menâs minds, which prevents a truth from ever
 24272	presenting itself identically to two persons. Even those members
 24273	who seemed to be on his side understood him in their own way with
 24274	limitations and alterations he could not agree to, as what he always
 24275	wanted most was to convey his thought to others just as he himself
 24276	understood it.
 24277	
 24278	     * The Illuminati sought to substitute republican for
 24279	     monarchical institutions.
 24280	
 24281	At the end of the meeting the Grand Master with irony and ill-will
 24282	reproved BezÃºkhov for his vehemence and said it was not love of virtue
 24283	alone, but also a love of strife that had moved him in the dispute.
 24284	Pierre did not answer him and asked briefly whether his proposal would
 24285	be accepted. He was told that it would not, and without waiting for the
 24286	usual formalities he left the lodge and went home.

 24292	CHAPTER VIII
 24293	
 24294	Again Pierre was overtaken by the depression he so dreaded. For three
 24295	days after the delivery of his speech at the lodge he lay on a sofa at
 24296	home receiving no one and going nowhere.
 24297	
 24298	It was just then that he received a letter from his wife, who implored
 24299	him to see her, telling him how grieved she was about him and how she
 24300	wished to devote her whole life to him.
 24301	
 24302	At the end of the letter she informed him that in a few days she would
 24303	return to Petersburg from abroad.
 24304	
 24305	Following this letter one of the Masonic Brothers whom Pierre respected
 24306	less than the others forced his way in to see him and, turning the
 24307	conversation upon Pierreâs matrimonial affairs, by way of fraternal
 24308	advice expressed the opinion that his severity to his wife was wrong
 24309	and that he was neglecting one of the first rules of Freemasonry by not
 24310	forgiving the penitent.
 24311	
 24312	At the same time his mother-in-law, Prince VasÃ­liâs wife, sent to

 24316	was, this was not even unpleasant to him. Nothing mattered to him.
 24317	Nothing in life seemed to him of much importance, and under the
 24318	influence of the depression that possessed him he valued neither his

 24320	
 24321	âNo one is right and no one is to blame; so she too is not to

 24323

 24327	Compared to what preoccupied him, was it not a matter of indifference

 24329	
 24330	Without replying either to his wife or his mother-in-law, Pierre late

 24333	
 24334	Moscow, 17th November
 24335	
 24336	I have just returned from my benefactor, and hasten to write down what I
 24337	have experienced. Joseph AlexÃ©evich is living poorly and has for three
 24338	years been suffering from a painful disease of the bladder. No one has
 24339	ever heard him utter a groan or a word of complaint. From morning till
 24340	late at night, except when he eats his very plain food, he is working

 24342	on which he lay. I made the sign of the Knights of the East and of
 24343	Jerusalem, and he responded in the same manner, asking me with a mild
 24344	smile what I had learned and gained in the Prussian and Scottish lodges.
 24345	I told him everything as best I could, and told him what I had proposed
 24346	to our Petersburg lodge, of the bad reception I had encountered, and of
 24347	my rupture with the Brothers. Joseph AlexÃ©evich, having remained silent
 24348	and thoughtful for a good while, told me his view of the matter, which
 24349	at once lit up for me my whole past and the future path I should follow.
 24350	He surprised me by asking whether I remembered the threefold aim of
 24351	the order: (1) The preservation and study of the mystery. (2) The
 24352	purification and reformation of oneself for its reception, and (3) The
 24353	improvement of the human race by striving for such purification. Which
 24354	is the principal aim of these three? Certainly self-reformation and
 24355	self-purification. Only to this aim can we always strive independently
 24356	of circumstances. But at the same time just this aim demands the
 24357	greatest efforts of us; and so, led astray by pride, losing sight of
 24358	this aim, we occupy ourselves either with the mystery which in our
 24359	impurity we are unworthy to receive, or seek the reformation of
 24360	the human race while ourselves setting an example of baseness and
 24361	profligacy. Illuminism is not a pure doctrine, just because it is
 24362	attracted by social activity and puffed up by pride. On this ground
 24363	Joseph AlexÃ©evich condemned my speech and my whole activity, and in the
 24364	depth of my soul I agreed with him. Talking of my family affairs he said
 24365	to me, âthe chief duty of a true Mason, as I have told you, lies in
 24366	perfecting himself. We often think that by removing all the difficulties
 24367	of our life we shall more quickly reach our aim, but on the contrary,
 24368	my dear sir, it is only in the midst of worldly cares that we can attain
 24369	our three chief aims: (1) Self-knowledgeâfor man can only know himself
 24370	by comparison, (2) Self-perfecting, which can only be attained by
 24371	conflict, and (3) The attainment of the chief virtueâlove of death.
 24372	Only the vicissitudes of life can show us its vanity and develop our

 24388	Petersburg, 23rd November
 24389	
 24390	I am again living with my wife. My mother-in-law came to me in tears and

 33410	BOOK NINE: 1812
 33411	
 33412	
 33413	
 33414	
 33415	
 33416	CHAPTER I
 33417	
 33418	From the close of the year 1811 intensified arming and concentrating of
 33419	the forces of Western Europe began, and in 1812 these forcesâmillions
 33420	of men, reckoning those transporting and feeding the armyâmoved from the
 33421	west eastwards to the Russian frontier, toward which since 1811 Russian
 33422	forces had been similarly drawn. On the twelfth of June, 1812, the
 33423	forces of Western Europe crossed the Russian frontier and war began,
 33424	that is, an event took place opposed to human reason and to human
 33425	nature. Millions of men perpetrated against one another such innumerable
 33426	crimes, frauds, treacheries, thefts, forgeries, issues of false money,
 33427	burglaries, incendiarisms, and murders as in whole centuries are not
 33428	recorded in the annals of all the law courts of the world, but which
 33429	those who committed them did not at the time regard as being crimes.
 33430	
 33431	What produced this extraordinary occurrence? What were its causes? The
 33432	historians tell us with naÃ¯ve assurance that its causes were the wrongs
 33433	inflicted on the Duke of Oldenburg, the nonobservance of the Continental
 33434	System, the ambition of Napoleon, the firmness of Alexander, the
 33435	mistakes of the diplomatists, and so on.
 33436	
 33437	Consequently, it would only have been necessary for Metternich,
 33438	RumyÃ¡ntsev, or Talleyrand, between a levee and an evening party, to have
 33439	taken proper pains and written a more adroit note, or for Napoleon to
 33440	have written to Alexander: âMy respected Brother, I consent to restore
 33441	the duchy to the Duke of Oldenburgââand there would have been no war.
 33442	
 33443	We can understand that the matter seemed like that to contemporaries.
 33444	It naturally seemed to Napoleon that the war was caused by Englandâs
 33445	intrigues (as in fact he said on the island of St. Helena). It naturally
 33446	seemed to members of the English Parliament that the cause of the war
 33447	was Napoleonâs ambition; to the Duke of Oldenburg, that the cause of the
 33448	war was the violence done to him; to businessmen that the cause of the
 33449	war was the Continental System which was ruining Europe; to the generals
 33450	and old soldiers that the chief reason for the war was the necessity of
 33451	giving them employment; to the legitimists of that day that it was the
 33452	need of re-establishing les bons principes, and to the diplomatists of
 33453	that time that it all resulted from the fact that the alliance between
 33454	Russia and Austria in 1809 had not been sufficiently well concealed
 33455	from Napoleon, and from the awkward wording of Memorandum No. 178. It
 33456	is natural that these and a countless and infinite quantity of other
 33457	reasons, the number depending on the endless diversity of points
 33458	of view, presented themselves to the men of that day; but to us, to
 33459	posterity who view the thing that happened in all its magnitude and
 33460	perceive its plain and terrible meaning, these causes seem insufficient.
 33461	To us it is incomprehensible that millions of Christian men killed and
 33462	tortured each other either because Napoleon was ambitious or Alexander
 33463	was firm, or because Englandâs policy was astute or the Duke of
 33464	Oldenburg wronged. We cannot grasp what connection such circumstances
 33465	have with the actual fact of slaughter and violence: why because the
 33466	Duke was wronged, thousands of men from the other side of Europe killed
 33467	and ruined the people of SmolÃ©nsk and Moscow and were killed by them.
 33468	
 33469	To us, their descendants, who are not historians and are not carried
 33470	away by the process of research and can therefore regard the event
 33471	with unclouded common sense, an incalculable number of causes present
 33472	themselves. The deeper we delve in search of these causes the more of
 33473	them we find; and each separate cause or whole series of causes appears
 33474	to us equally valid in itself and equally false by its insignificance
 33475	compared to the magnitude of the events, and by its impotenceâapart
 33476	from the cooperation of all the other coincident causesâto occasion the
 33477	event. To us, the wish or objection of this or that French corporal to
 33478	serve a second term appears as much a cause as Napoleonâs refusal to
 33479	withdraw his troops beyond the Vistula and to restore the duchy of
 33480	Oldenburg; for had he not wished to serve, and had a second, a third,
 33481	and a thousandth corporal and private also refused, there would have
 33482	been so many less men in Napoleonâs army and the war could not have
 33483	occurred.
 33484	
 33485	Had Napoleon not taken offense at the demand that he should withdraw
 33486	beyond the Vistula, and not ordered his troops to advance, there would
 33487	have been no war; but had all his sergeants objected to serving a second
 33488	term then also there could have been no war. Nor could there have been
 33489	a war had there been no English intrigues and no Duke of Oldenburg, and
 33490	had Alexander not felt insulted, and had there not been an autocratic
 33491	government in Russia, or a Revolution in France and a subsequent
 33492	dictatorship and Empire, or all the things that produced the French
 33493	Revolution, and so on. Without each of these causes nothing could have
 33494	happened. So all these causesâmyriads of causesâcoincided to bring it
 33495	about. And so there was no one cause for that occurrence, but it had
 33496	to occur because it had to. Millions of men, renouncing their human
 33497	feelings and reason, had to go from west to east to slay their fellows,
 33498	just as some centuries previously hordes of men had come from the east
 33499	to the west, slaying their fellows.
 33500	
 33501	The actions of Napoleon and Alexander, on whose words the event seemed
 33502	to hang, were as little voluntary as the actions of any soldier who was
 33503	drawn into the campaign by lot or by conscription. This could not be
 33504	otherwise, for in order that the will of Napoleon and Alexander (on whom
 33505	the event seemed to depend) should be carried out, the concurrence of
 33506	innumerable circumstances was needed without anyone of which the event
 33507	could not have taken place. It was necessary that millions of men in
 33508	whose hands lay the real powerâthe soldiers who fired, or transported
 33509	provisions and gunsâshould consent to carry out the will of these weak
 33510	individuals, and should have been induced to do so by an infinite number
 33511	of diverse and complex causes.
 33512	
 33513	We are forced to fall back on fatalism as an explanation of irrational
 33514	events (that is to say, events the reasonableness of which we do
 33515	not understand). The more we try to explain such events in history
 33516	reasonably, the more unreasonable and incomprehensible do they become to
 33517	us.
 33518	
 33519	Each man lives for himself, using his freedom to attain his personal
 33520	aims, and feels with his whole being that he can now do or abstain from
 33521	doing this or that action; but as soon as he has done it, that action
 33522	performed at a certain moment in time becomes irrevocable and belongs to
 33523	history, in which it has not a free but a predestined significance.
 33524	
 33525	There are two sides to the life of every man, his individual life, which
 33526	is the more free the more abstract its interests, and his elemental hive
 33527	life in which he inevitably obeys laws laid down for him.
 33528	
 33529	Man lives consciously for himself, but is an unconscious instrument in
 33530	the attainment of the historic, universal, aims of humanity. A deed done
 33531	is irrevocable, and its result coinciding in time with the actions of
 33532	millions of other men assumes an historic significance. The higher a man
 33533	stands on the social ladder, the more people he is connected with
 33534	and the more power he has over others, the more evident is the
 33535	predestination and inevitability of his every action.
 33536	
 33537	âThe kingâs heart is in the hands of the Lord.â
 33538	
 33539	A king is historyâs slave.
 33540	
 33541	History, that is, the unconscious, general, hive life of mankind, uses
 33542	every moment of the life of kings as a tool for its own purposes.
 33543	
 33544	Though Napoleon at that time, in 1812, was more convinced than ever that
 33545	it depended on him, verser (ou ne pas verser) le sang de ses peuples
 33546	*âas Alexander expressed it in the last letter he wrote himâhe had never
 33547	been so much in the grip of inevitable laws, which compelled him, while
 33548	thinking that he was acting on his own volition, to perform for the hive
 33549	lifeâthat is to say, for historyâwhatever had to be performed.
 33550	
 33551	    * âTo shed (or not to shed) the blood of his peoples.â
 33552	
 33553	
 33554	The people of the west moved eastwards to slay their fellow men, and
 33555	by the law of coincidence thousands of minute causes fitted in and
 33556	co-ordinated to produce that movement and war: reproaches for the
 33557	nonobservance of the Continental System, the Duke of Oldenburgâs
 33558	wrongs, the movement of troops into Prussiaâundertaken (as it seemed to
 33559	Napoleon) only for the purpose of securing an armed peace, the
 33560	French Emperorâs love and habit of war coinciding with his peopleâs
 33561	inclinations, allurement by the grandeur of the preparations, and the
 33562	expenditure on those preparations and the need of obtaining advantages
 33563	to compensate for that expenditure, the intoxicating honors he received
 33564	in Dresden, the diplomatic negotiations which, in the opinion of
 33565	contemporaries, were carried on with a sincere desire to attain peace,
 33566	but which only wounded the self-love of both sides, and millions of
 33567	other causes that adapted themselves to the event that was happening or
 33568	coincided with it.
 33569	
 33570	When an apple has ripened and falls, why does it fall? Because of its
 33571	attraction to the earth, because its stalk withers, because it is dried
 33572	by the sun, because it grows heavier, because the wind shakes it, or
 33573	because the boy standing below wants to eat it?
 33574	
 33575	Nothing is the cause. All this is only the coincidence of conditions in
 33576	which all vital organic and elemental events occur. And the botanist
 33577	who finds that the apple falls because the cellular tissue decays and so
 33578	forth is equally right with the child who stands under the tree and says
 33579	the apple fell because he wanted to eat it and prayed for it. Equally
 33580	right or wrong is he who says that Napoleon went to Moscow because he
 33581	wanted to, and perished because Alexander desired his destruction, and
 33582	he who says that an undermined hill weighing a million tons fell because
 33583	the last navvy struck it for the last time with his mattock. In historic
 33584	events the so-called great men are labels giving names to events, and
 33585	like labels they have but the smallest connection with the event itself.
 33586	
 33587	Every act of theirs, which appears to them an act of their own will, is
 33588	in an historical sense involuntary and is related to the whole course of
 33589	history and predestined from eternity.
 33590	
 33591	
 33592	
 33593	
 33594	
 33595	CHAPTER II
 33596	
 33597	On the twenty-ninth of May Napoleon left Dresden, where he had spent
 33598	three weeks surrounded by a court that included princes, dukes, kings,
 33599	and even an emperor. Before leaving, Napoleon showed favor to the
 33600	emperor, kings, and princes who had deserved it, reprimanded the kings
 33601	and princes with whom he was dissatisfied, presented pearls and diamonds
 33602	of his ownâthat is, which he had taken from other kingsâto the Empress
 33603	of Austria, and having, as his historian tells us, tenderly embraced the
 33604	Empress Marie Louiseâwho regarded him as her husband, though he had left
 33605	another wife in Parisâleft her grieved by the parting which she seemed
 33606	hardly able to bear. Though the diplomatists still firmly believed in
 33607	the possibility of peace and worked zealously to that end, and though
 33608	the Emperor Napoleon himself wrote a letter to Alexander, calling him
 33609	Monsieur mon frÃ¨re, and sincerely assured him that he did not want war
 33610	and would always love and honor himâyet he set off to join his army,
 33611	and at every station gave fresh orders to accelerate the movement of his
 33612	troops from west to east. He went in a traveling coach with six horses,
 33613	surrounded by pages, aides-de-camp, and an escort, along the road to
 33614	Posen, Thorn, Danzig, and KÃ¶nigsberg. At each of these towns thousands
 33615	of people met him with excitement and enthusiasm.
 33616	
 33617	The army was moving from west to east, and relays of six horses carried
 33618	him in the same direction. On the tenth of June, * coming up with the
 33619	army, he spent the night in apartments prepared for him on the estate of
 33620	a Polish count in the Vilkavisski forest.

 34975	laws defined by a pseudo-theory of war, and they saw only barbarism,
 34976	ignorance, or evil intention in every deviation from that theory. To
 34977	this party belonged the foreign nobles, Wolzogen, Wintzingerode, and
 34978	others, chiefly Germans.
 34979	
 34980	The second party was directly opposed to the first; one extreme, as
 34981	always happens, was met by representatives of the other. The members of
 34982	this party were those who had demanded an advance from VÃ­lna into Poland

 35009	
 35010	Of a fourth opinion the most conspicuous representative was the

 35090	
 35091	All the men of this party were fishing for rubles, decorations, and

 35094	drone population of the army began blowing hard that way, so that it

 35105	
 35106	From among all these parties, just at the time Prince Andrew reached

 35113	
 35114	The men of this party said and thought that what was wrong resulted

 35118	harmful in an army; that a sovereign should reign but not command the
 35119	army, and that the only way out of the position would be for the Emperor
 35120	and his court to leave the army; that the mere presence of the Emperor
 35121	paralyzed the action of fifty thousand men required to secure his
 35122	personal safety, and that the worst commander in chief, if independent,
 35123	would be better than the very best one trammeled by the presence and

 35125	
 35126	Just at the time Prince Andrew was living unoccupied at Drissa,

 35191	At first sight, Pfuel, in his ill-made uniform of a Russian general,

 35223	Pfuel, always inclined to be irritably sarcastic, was particularly

 35225	and criticize his camp in his absence. From this short interview with

 35228	and immutably self-confident men, self-confident to the point of
 35229	martyrdom as only Germans are, because only Germans are self-confident
 35230	on the basis of an abstract notionâscience, that is, the supposed
 35231	knowledge of absolute truth. A Frenchman is self-assured because he
 35232	regards himself personally, both in mind and body, as irresistibly
 35233	attractive to men and women. An Englishman is self-assured, as being a
 35234	citizen of the best-organized state in the world, and therefore as an

 35236	an Englishman is undoubtedly correct. An Italian is self-assured because
 35237	he is excitable and easily forgets himself and other people. A Russian
 35238	is self-assured just because he knows nothing and does not want to know
 35239	anything, since he does not believe that anything can be known. The
 35240	Germanâs self-assurance is worst of all, stronger and more
 35241	repulsive than any other, because he imagines that he knows the
 35242	truthâscienceâwhich he himself has invented but which is for him the

 35244	
 35245	Pfuel was evidently of that sort. He had a scienceâthe theory of oblique

 35252	
 35253	In 1806 Pfuel had been one of those responsible, for the plan of

 35266	He said a few words to Prince Andrew and ChernÃ½shev about the present

 35414	
 35415	The discussions continued a long time, and the longer they lasted
 35416	the more heated became the disputes, culminating in shouts and
 35417	personalities, and the less was it possible to arrive at any general
 35418	conclusion from all that had been said. Prince Andrew, listening to this
 35419	polyglot talk and to these surmises, plans, refutations, and shouts,
 35420	felt nothing but amazement at what they were saying. A thought that had
 35421	long since and often occurred to him during his military activitiesâthe
 35422	idea that there is not and cannot be any science of war, and that
 35423	therefore there can be no such thing as a military geniusânow appeared
 35424	to him an obvious truth. âWhat theory and science is possible about a
 35425	matter the conditions and circumstances of which are unknown and cannot
 35426	be defined, especially when the strength of the acting forces cannot be
 35427	ascertained? No one was or is able to foresee in what condition our or
 35428	the enemyâs armies will be in a dayâs time, and no one can gauge the
 35429	force of this or that detachment. Sometimesâwhen there is not a coward
 35430	at the front to shout, âWe are cut off!â and start running, but a brave
 35431	and jolly lad who shouts, âHurrah!ââa detachment of five thousand

 35434	there be in a matter in which, as in all practical matters, nothing
 35435	can be defined and everything depends on innumerable conditions, the
 35436	significance of which is determined at a particular moment which arrives
 35437	no one knows when? Armfeldt says our army is cut in half, and Paulucci
 35438	says we have got the French army between two fires; Michaud says that
 35439	the worthlessness of the Drissa camp lies in having the river behind it,
 35440	and Pfuel says that is what constitutes its strength; Toll proposes
 35441	one plan, Armfeldt another, and they are all good and all bad, and the
 35442	advantages of any suggestions can be seen only at the moment of trial.
 35443	And why do they all speak of a âmilitary geniusâ? Is a man a genius who
 35444	can order bread to be brought up at the right time and say who is to go
 35445	to the right and who to the left? It is only because military men are
 35446	invested with pomp and power and crowds of sychophants flatter power,
 35447	attributing to it qualities of genius it does not possess. The best
 35448	generals I have known were, on the contrary, stupid or absent-minded
 35449	men. BagratiÃ³n was the best, Napoleon himself admitted that. And of
 35450	Bonaparte himself! I remember his limited, self-satisfied face on the

 35454	inquiring doubt. He should be limited, firmly convinced that what he
 35455	is doing is very important (otherwise he will not have sufficient

 35457	should be humane, should love, or pity, or think of what is just
 35458	and unjust. It is understandable that a theory of their âgeniusâ was
 35459	invented for them long ago because they have power! The success of a

 37482	BOOK TEN: 1812
 37483	
 37484	
 37485	
 37486	
 37487	
 37488	CHAPTER I
 37489	
 37490	Napoleon began the war with Russia because he could not resist going
 37491	to Dresden, could not help having his head turned by the homage he
 37492	received, could not help donning a Polish uniform and yielding to the
 37493	stimulating influence of a June morning, and could not refrain from
 37494	bursts of anger in the presence of KurÃ¡kin and then of BalashÃ«v.
 37495	
 37496	Alexander refused negotiations because he felt himself to be personally
 37497	insulted. Barclay de Tolly tried to command the army in the best
 37498	way, because he wished to fulfill his duty and earn fame as a great
 37499	commander. RostÃ³v charged the French because he could not restrain
 37500	his wish for a gallop across a level field; and in the same way the
 37501	innumerable people who took part in the war acted in accord with their
 37502	personal characteristics, habits, circumstances, and aims. They were
 37503	moved by fear or vanity, rejoiced or were indignant, reasoned, imagining
 37504	that they knew what they were doing and did it of their own free will,
 37505	but they all were involuntary tools of history, carrying on a work
 37506	concealed from them but comprehensible to us. Such is the inevitable
 37507	fate of men of action, and the higher they stand in the social hierarchy
 37508	the less are they free.
 37509	
 37510	The actors of 1812 have long since left the stage, their personal
 37511	interests have vanished leaving no trace, and nothing remains of that
 37512	time but its historic results.
 37513	
 37514	Providence compelled all these men, striving to attain personal aims, to
 37515	further the accomplishment of a stupendous result no one of them at all
 37516	expectedâneither Napoleon, nor Alexander, nor still less any of those
 37517	who did the actual fighting.
 37518	
 37519	The cause of the destruction of the French army in 1812 is clear to us
 37520	now. No one will deny that that cause was, on the one hand, its advance
 37521	into the heart of Russia late in the season without any preparation for
 37522	a winter campaign and, on the other, the character given to the war
 37523	by the burning of Russian towns and the hatred of the foe this aroused
 37524	among the Russian people. But no one at the time foresaw (what now seems
 37525	so evident) that this was the only way an army of eight hundred thousand
 37526	menâthe best in the world and led by the best generalâcould be destroyed
 37527	in conflict with a raw army of half its numerical strength, and led by
 37528	inexperienced commanders as the Russian army was. Not only did no one
 37529	see this, but on the Russian side every effort was made to hinder the
 37530	only thing that could save Russia, while on the French side, despite
 37531	Napoleonâs experience and so-called military genius, every effort was
 37532	directed to pushing on to Moscow at the end of the summer, that is, to
 37533	doing the very thing that was bound to lead to destruction.
 37534	
 37535	In historical works on the year 1812 French writers are very fond of
 37536	saying that Napoleon felt the danger of extending his line, that he
 37537	sought a battle and that his marshals advised him to stop at SmolÃ©nsk,
 37538	and of making similar statements to show that the danger of the campaign
 37539	was even then understood. Russian authors are still fonder of telling
 37540	us that from the commencement of the campaign a Scythian war plan was
 37541	adopted to lure Napoleon into the depths of Russia, and this plan some
 37542	of them attribute to Pfuel, others to a certain Frenchman, others to
 37543	Toll, and others again to Alexander himselfâpointing to notes, projects,
 37544	and letters which contain hints of such a line of action. But all these
 37545	hints at what happened, both from the French side and the Russian, are
 37546	advanced only because they fit in with the event. Had that event not
 37547	occurred these hints would have been forgotten, as we have forgotten the
 37548	thousands and millions of hints and expectations to the contrary
 37549	which were current then but have now been forgotten because the event
 37550	falsified them. There are always so many conjectures as to the issue of
 37551	any event that however it may end there will always be people to say:
 37552	âI said then that it would be so,â quite forgetting that amid their
 37553	innumerable conjectures many were to quite the contrary effect.
 37554	
 37555	Conjectures as to Napoleonâs awareness of the danger of extending his
 37556	line, and (on the Russian side) as to luring the enemy into the depths
 37557	of Russia, are evidently of that kind, and only by much straining can
 37558	historians attribute such conceptions to Napoleon and his marshals,
 37559	or such plans to the Russian commanders. All the facts are in flat
 37560	contradiction to such conjectures. During the whole period of the war
 37561	not only was there no wish on the Russian side to draw the French
 37562	into the heart of the country, but from their first entry into Russia
 37563	everything was done to stop them. And not only was Napoleon not afraid
 37564	to extend his line, but he welcomed every step forward as a triumph and
 37565	did not seek battle as eagerly as in former campaigns, but very lazily.
 37566	
 37567	At the very beginning of the war our armies were divided, and our sole
 37568	aim was to unite them, though uniting the armies was no advantage if we
 37569	meant to retire and lure the enemy into the depths of the country. Our
 37570	Emperor joined the army to encourage it to defend every inch of Russian
 37571	soil and not to retreat. The enormous Drissa camp was formed on Pfuelâs
 37572	plan, and there was no intention of retiring farther. The Emperor
 37573	reproached the commanders in chief for every step they retired. He could
 37574	not bear the idea of letting the enemy even reach SmolÃ©nsk, still less
 37575	could he contemplate the burning of Moscow, and when our armies did
 37576	unite he was displeased that SmolÃ©nsk was abandoned and burned without a
 37577	general engagement having been fought under its walls.
 37578	
 37579	So thought the Emperor, and the Russian commanders and people were still
 37580	more provoked at the thought that our forces were retreating into the
 37581	depths of the country.
 37582	
 37583	Napoleon having cut our armies apart advanced far into the country and
 37584	missed several chances of forcing an engagement. In August he was at
 37585	SmolÃ©nsk and thought only of how to advance farther, though as we now
 37586	see that advance was evidently ruinous to him.
 37587	
 37588	The facts clearly show that Napoleon did not foresee the danger of the
 37589	advance on Moscow, nor did Alexander and the Russian commanders then
 37590	think of luring Napoleon on, but quite the contrary. The luring of
 37591	Napoleon into the depths of the country was not the result of any plan,
 37592	for no one believed it to be possible; it resulted from a most complex
 37593	interplay of intrigues, aims, and wishes among those who took part in
 37594	the war and had no perception whatever of the inevitable, or of the one
 37595	way of saving Russia. Everything came about fortuitously. The armies
 37596	were divided at the commencement of the campaign. We tried to unite
 37597	them, with the evident intention of giving battle and checking the
 37598	enemyâs advance, and by this effort to unite them while avoiding battle
 37599	with a much stronger enemy, and necessarily withdrawing the armies at
 37600	an acute angleâwe led the French on to SmolÃ©nsk. But we withdrew at an
 37601	acute angle not only because the French advanced between our two armies;
 37602	the angle became still more acute and we withdrew still farther, because
 37603	Barclay de Tolly was an unpopular foreigner disliked by BagratiÃ³n (who
 37604	would come under his command), and BagratiÃ³nâbeing in command of the
 37605	second armyâtried to postpone joining up and coming under Barclayâs
 37606	command as long as he could. BagratiÃ³n was slow in effecting the
 37607	junctionâthough that was the chief aim of all at headquartersâbecause,
 37608	as he alleged, he exposed his army to danger on this march, and it was
 37609	best for him to retire more to the left and more to the south, worrying
 37610	the enemy from flank and rear and securing from the Ukraine recruits for
 37611	his army; and it looks as if he planned this in order not to come under
 37612	the command of the detested foreigner Barclay, whose rank was inferior
 37613	to his own.
 37614	
 37615	The Emperor was with the army to encourage it, but his presence and
 37616	ignorance of what steps to take, and the enormous number of advisers and
 37617	plans, destroyed the first armyâs energy and it retired.
 37618	
 37619	The intention was to make a stand at the Drissa camp, but Paulucci,
 37620	aiming at becoming commander in chief, unexpectedly employed his energy
 37621	to influence Alexander, and Pfuelâs whole plan was abandoned and the
 37622	command entrusted to Barclay. But as Barclay did not inspire confidence
 37623	his power was limited. The armies were divided, there was no unity of
 37624	command, and Barclay was unpopular; but from this confusion, division,
 37625	and the unpopularity of the foreign commander in chief, there resulted
 37626	on the one hand indecision and the avoidance of a battle (which we could
 37627	not have refrained from had the armies been united and had someone else,
 37628	instead of Barclay, been in command) and on the other an ever-increasing

 38504	CHAPTER V
 38505	
 38506	From SmolÃ©nsk the troops continued to retreat, followed by the enemy.
 38507	On the tenth of August the regiment Prince Andrew commanded was marching
 38508	along the highroad past the avenue leading to Bald Hills. Heat and
 38509	drought had continued for more than three weeks. Each day fleecy clouds
 38510	floated across the sky and occasionally veiled the sun, but toward
 38511	evening the sky cleared again and the sun set in reddish-brown mist.
 38512	Heavy night dews alone refreshed the earth. The unreaped corn was
 38513	scorched and shed its grain. The marshes dried up. The cattle lowed from
 38514	hunger, finding no food on the sun-parched meadows. Only at night and
 38515	in the forests while the dew lasted was there any freshness. But on the
 38516	road, the highroad along which the troops marched, there was no such
 38517	freshness even at night or when the road passed through the forest; the
 38518	dew was imperceptible on the sandy dust churned up more than six inches
 38519	deep. As soon as day dawned the march began. The artillery and baggage
 38520	wagons moved noiselessly through the deep dust that rose to the very
 38521	hubs of the wheels, and the infantry sank ankle-deep in that soft,
 38522	choking, hot dust that never cooled even at night. Some of this dust
 38523	was kneaded by the feet and wheels, while the rest rose and hung like a
 38524	cloud over the troops, settling in eyes, ears, hair, and nostrils, and
 38525	worst of all in the lungs of the men and beasts as they moved along that
 38526	road. The higher the sun rose the higher rose that cloud of dust, and
 38527	through the screen of its hot fine particles one could look with naked
 38528	eye at the sun, which showed like a huge crimson ball in the unclouded
 38529	sky. There was no wind, and the men choked in that motionless
 38530	atmosphere. They marched with handkerchiefs tied over their noses and
 38531	mouths. When they passed through a village they all rushed to the wells
 38532	and fought for the water and drank it down to the mud.
 38533	
 38534	Prince Andrew was in command of a regiment, and the management of that
 38535	regiment, the welfare of the men and the necessity of receiving
 38536	and giving orders, engrossed him. The burning of SmolÃ©nsk and its
 38537	abandonment made an epoch in his life. A novel feeling of anger against
 38538	the foe made him forget his own sorrow. He was entirely devoted to the
 38539	affairs of his regiment and was considerate and kind to his men and
 38540	officers. In the regiment they called him âour prince,â were proud
 38541	of him and loved him. But he was kind and gentle only to those of his

 38956	CHAPTER VII
 38957	
 38958	While this was taking place in Petersburg the French had already passed
 38959	SmolÃ©nsk and were drawing nearer and nearer to Moscow. Napoleonâs
 38960	historian Thiers, like other of his historians, trying to justify his
 38961	hero says that he was drawn to the walls of Moscow against his will. He
 38962	is as right as other historians who look for the explanation of historic
 38963	events in the will of one man; he is as right as the Russian historians
 38964	who maintain that Napoleon was drawn to Moscow by the skill of the
 38965	Russian commanders. Here besides the law of retrospection, which regards
 38966	all the past as a preparation for events that subsequently occur,
 38967	the law of reciprocity comes in, confusing the whole matter. A good
 38968	chessplayer having lost a game is sincerely convinced that his loss
 38969	resulted from a mistake he made and looks for that mistake in the
 38970	opening, but forgets that at each stage of the game there were similar
 38971	mistakes and that none of his moves were perfect. He only notices the
 38972	mistake to which he pays attention, because his opponent took advantage
 38973	of it. How much more complex than this is the game of war, which
 38974	occurs under certain limits of time, and where it is not one will that
 38975	manipulates lifeless objects, but everything results from innumerable
 38976	conflicts of various wills!
 38977

 39473	Until Prince Andrew settled in BoguchÃ¡rovo its owners had always been

 39504	a movement among the peasants to emigrate to some unknown âwarm rivers.â
 39505	Hundreds of peasants, among them the BoguchÃ¡rovo folk, suddenly began

 39515	forces ready to manifest themselves just as strangely, unexpectedly, and
 39516	at the same time simply, naturally, and forcibly. Now in 1812, to anyone
 39517	living in close touch with these people it was apparent that these

 41380	
 41381	CHAPTER XIX
 41382	
 41383	On the twenty-fourth of August the battle of the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt was
 41384	fought, on the twenty-fifth not a shot was fired by either side, and on
 41385	the twenty-sixth the battle of BorodinÃ³ itself took place.
 41386	
 41387	Why and how were the battles of ShevÃ¡rdino and BorodinÃ³ given and
 41388	accepted? Why was the battle of BorodinÃ³ fought? There was not the least
 41389	sense in it for either the French or the Russians. Its immediate result
 41390	for the Russians was, and was bound to be, that we were brought nearer
 41391	to the destruction of Moscowâwhich we feared more than anything in
 41392	the world; and for the French its immediate result was that they were
 41393	brought nearer to the destruction of their whole armyâwhich they feared
 41394	more than anything in the world. What the result must be was quite
 41395	obvious, and yet Napoleon offered and KutÃºzov accepted that battle.
 41396	
 41397	If the commanders had been guided by reason, it would seem that it must
 41398	have been obvious to Napoleon that by advancing thirteen hundred miles
 41399	and giving battle with a probability of losing a quarter of his army,
 41400	he was advancing to certain destruction, and it must have been equally
 41401	clear to KutÃºzov that by accepting battle and risking the loss of a
 41402	quarter of his army he would certainly lose Moscow. For KutÃºzov this was
 41403	mathematically clear, as it is that if when playing draughts I have one
 41404	man less and go on exchanging, I shall certainly lose, and therefore
 41405	should not exchange. When my opponent has sixteen men and I have
 41406	fourteen, I am only one eighth weaker than he, but when I have exchanged
 41407	thirteen more men he will be three times as strong as I am.
 41408	
 41409	Before the battle of BorodinÃ³ our strength in proportion to the French
 41410	was about as five to six, but after that battle it was little more than
 41411	one to two: previously we had a hundred thousand against a hundred and
 41412	twenty thousand; afterwards little more than fifty thousand against a
 41413	hundred thousand. Yet the shrewd and experienced KutÃºzov accepted the
 41414	battle, while Napoleon, who was said to be a commander of genius,
 41415	gave it, losing a quarter of his army and lengthening his lines of
 41416	communication still more. If it is said that he expected to end the
 41417	campaign by occupying Moscow as he had ended a previous campaign by
 41418	occupying Vienna, there is much evidence to the contrary. Napoleonâs
 41419	historians themselves tell us that from SmolÃ©nsk onwards he wished
 41420	to stop, knew the danger of his extended position, and knew that the
 41421	occupation of Moscow would not be the end of the campaign, for he had
 41422	seen at SmolÃ©nsk the state in which Russian towns were left to him, and
 41423	had not received a single reply to his repeated announcements of his
 41424	wish to negotiate.
 41425	
 41426	In giving and accepting battle at BorodinÃ³, KutÃºzov acted involuntarily
 41427	and irrationally. But later on, to fit what had occurred, the historians
 41428	provided cunningly devised evidence of the foresight and genius of the
 41429	generals who, of all the blind tools of history were the most enslaved
 41430	and involuntary.
 41431	
 41432	The ancients have left us model heroic poems in which the heroes furnish
 41433	the whole interest of the story, and we are still unable to accustom
 41434	ourselves to the fact that for our epoch histories of that kind are
 41435	meaningless.
 41436	
 41437	On the other question, how the battle of BorodinÃ³ and the preceding
 41438	battle of ShevÃ¡rdino were fought, there also exists a definite and
 41439	well-known, but quite false, conception. All the historians describe the
 41440	affair as follows:
 41441	
 41442	The Russian army, they say, in its retreat from SmolÃ©nsk sought out
 41443	for itself the best position for a general engagement and found such a
 41444	position at BorodinÃ³.
 41445	
 41446	The Russians, they say, fortified this position in advance on the left
 41447	of the highroad (from Moscow to SmolÃ©nsk) and almost at a right angle
 41448	to it, from BorodinÃ³ to UtÃ­tsa, at the very place where the battle was
 41449	fought.
 41450	
 41451	In front of this position, they say, a fortified outpost was set up on
 41452	the ShevÃ¡rdino mound to observe the enemy. On the twenty-fourth, we
 41453	are told, Napoleon attacked this advanced post and took it, and, on the
 41454	twenty-sixth, attacked the whole Russian army, which was in position on
 41455	the field of BorodinÃ³.
 41456	
 41457	So the histories say, and it is all quite wrong, as anyone who cares to
 41458	look into the matter can easily convince himself.
 41459	
 41460	The Russians did not seek out the best position but, on the contrary,
 41461	during the retreat passed many positions better than BorodinÃ³. They did
 41462	not stop at any one of these positions because KutÃºzov did not wish to
 41463	occupy a position he had not himself chosen, because the popular demand
 41464	for a battle had not yet expressed itself strongly enough, and because
 41465	MilorÃ¡dovich had not yet arrived with the militia, and for many other
 41466	reasons. The fact is that other positions they had passed were stronger,
 41467	and that the position at BorodinÃ³ (the one where the battle was fought),
 41468	far from being strong, was no more a position than any other spot one
 41469	might find in the Russian Empire by sticking a pin into the map at
 41470	hazard.
 41471	
 41472	Not only did the Russians not fortify the position on the field of
 41473	BorodinÃ³ to the left of, and at a right angle to, the highroad (that
 41474	is, the position on which the battle took place), but never till the
 41475	twenty-fifth of August, 1812, did they think that a battle might be
 41476	fought there. This was shown first by the fact that there were no
 41477	entrenchments there by the twenty fifth and that those begun on the
 41478	twenty-fifth and twenty-sixth were not completed, and secondly, by the
 41479	position of the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt. That redoubt was quite senseless
 41480	in front of the position where the battle was accepted. Why was it
 41481	more strongly fortified than any other post? And why were all efforts
 41482	exhausted and six thousand men sacrificed to defend it till late at
 41483	night on the twenty-fourth? A Cossack patrol would have sufficed to
 41484	observe the enemy. Thirdly, as proof that the position on which the
 41485	battle was fought had not been foreseen and that the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt
 41486	was not an advanced post of that position, we have the fact that up to
 41487	the twenty-fifth, Barclay de Tolly and BagratiÃ³n were convinced that the
 41488	ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt was the left flank of the position, and that KutÃºzov
 41489	himself in his report, written in hot haste after the battle, speaks of
 41490	the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt as the left flank of the position. It was much
 41491	later, when reports on the battle of BorodinÃ³ were written at leisure,
 41492	that the incorrect and extraordinary statement was invented (probably to
 41493	justify the mistakes of a commander in chief who had to be represented
 41494	as infallible) that the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt was an advanced postâwhereas
 41495	in reality it was simply a fortified point on the left flankâand that
 41496	the battle of BorodinÃ³ was fought by us on an entrenched position
 41497	previously selected, whereas it was fought on a quite unexpected spot
 41498	which was almost unentrenched.
 41499	
 41500	The case was evidently this: a position was selected along the river
 41501	KolochÃ¡âwhich crosses the highroad not at a right angle but at an acute
 41502	angleâso that the left flank was at ShevÃ¡rdino, the right flank near the
 41503	village of NÃ³voe, and the center at BorodinÃ³ at the confluence of the
 41504	rivers KolochÃ¡ and VÃ³yna.
 41505	
 41506	To anyone who looks at the field of BorodinÃ³ without thinking of how
 41507	the battle was actually fought, this position, protected by the river
 41508	KolochÃ¡, presents itself as obvious for an army whose object was to
 41509	prevent an enemy from advancing along the SmolÃ©nsk road to Moscow.
 41510	
 41511	Napoleon, riding to ValÃºevo on the twenty-fourth, did not see (as the
 41512	history books say he did) the position of the Russians from UtÃ­tsa
 41513	to BorodinÃ³ (he could not have seen that position because it did not
 41514	exist), nor did he see an advanced post of the Russian army, but while
 41515	pursuing the Russian rearguard he came upon the left flank of the
 41516	Russian positionâat the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubtâand unexpectedly for the
 41517	Russians moved his army across the KolochÃ¡. And the Russians, not having
 41518	time to begin a general engagement, withdrew their left wing from the
 41519	position they had intended to occupy and took up a new position which
 41520	had not been foreseen and was not fortified. By crossing to the other
 41521	side of the KolochÃ¡ to the left of the highroad, Napoleon shifted the
 41522	whole forthcoming battle from right to left (looking from the Russian
 41523	side) and transferred it to the plain between UtÃ­tsa, SemÃ«novsk, and
 41524	BorodinÃ³âa plain no more advantageous as a position than any other plain
 41525	in Russiaâand there the whole battle of the twenty-sixth of August took
 41526	place.
 41527	
 41528	Had Napoleon not ridden out on the evening of the twenty-fourth to the
 41529	KolochÃ¡, and had he not then ordered an immediate attack on the redoubt
 41530	but had begun the attack next morning, no one would have doubted that
 41531	the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt was the left flank of our position, and the
 41532	battle would have taken place where we expected it. In that case
 41533	we should probably have defended the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubtâour left
 41534	flankâstill more obstinately. We should have attacked Napoleon in the
 41535	center or on the right, and the engagement would have taken place on the
 41536	twenty-fifth, in the position we intended and had fortified. But as the
 41537	attack on our left flank took place in the evening after the retreat of
 41538	our rear guard (that is, immediately after the fight at GridnÃ«va), and
 41539	as the Russian commanders did not wish, or were not in time, to begin a
 41540	general engagement then on the evening of the twenty-fourth, the first
 41541	and chief action of the battle of BorodinÃ³ was already lost on the
 41542	twenty-fourth, and obviously led to the loss of the one fought on the
 41543	twenty-sixth.
 41544	
 41545	After the loss of the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt, we found ourselves on the
 41546	morning of the twenty-fifth without a position for our left flank, and
 41547	were forced to bend it back and hastily entrench it where it chanced to
 41548	be.
 41549	
 41550	Not only was the Russian army on the twenty-sixth defended by weak,
 41551	unfinished entrenchments, but the disadvantage of that position was
 41552	increased by the fact that the Russian commandersânot having fully
 41553	realized what had happened, namely the loss of our position on the left
 41554	flank and the shifting of the whole field of the forthcoming battle from
 41555	right to leftâmaintained their extended position from the village of
 41556	NÃ³voe to UtÃ­tsa, and consequently had to move their forces from right to
 41557	left during the battle. So it happened that throughout the whole battle
 41558	the Russians opposed the entire French army launched against our left
 41559	flank with but half as many men. (Poniatowskiâs action against UtÃ­tsa,
 41560	and UvÃ¡rovâs on the right flank against the French, were actions
 41561	distinct from the main course of the battle.) So the battle of BorodinÃ³
 41562	did not take place at all as (in an effort to conceal our commandersâ
 41563	mistakes even at the cost of diminishing the glory due to the Russian
 41564	army and people) it has been described. The battle of BorodinÃ³ was not
 41565	fought on a chosen and entrenched position with forces only slightly
 41566	weaker than those of the enemy, but, as a result of the loss of the
 41567	ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt, the Russians fought the battle of BorodinÃ³ on an
 41568	open and almost unentrenched position, with forces only half as numerous
 41569	as the French; that is to say, under conditions in which it was not
 41570	merely unthinkable to fight for ten hours and secure an indecisive
 41571	result, but unthinkable to keep an army even from complete
 41572	disintegration and flight.

 42836	CHAPTER XXVII
 42837	
 42838	On the twenty-fifth of August, so his historians tell us, Napoleon spent
 42839	the whole day on horseback inspecting the locality, considering plans
 42840	submitted to him by his marshals, and personally giving commands to his
 42841	generals.
 42842	
 42843	The original line of the Russian forces along the river KolochÃ¡ had
 42844	been dislocated by the capture of the ShevÃ¡rdino Redoubt on the

 42846	That part of the line was not entrenched and in front of it the ground
 42847	was more open and level than elsewhere. It was evident to anyone,
 42848	military or not, that it was here the French should attack. It would
 42849	seem that not much consideration was needed to reach this conclusion,
 42850	nor any particular care or trouble on the part of the Emperor and his
 42851	marshals, nor was there any need of that special and supreme quality
 42852	called genius that people are so apt to ascribe to Napoleon; yet the
 42853	historians who described the event later and the men who then surrounded
 42854	Napoleon, and he himself, thought otherwise.
 42855	
 42856	Napoleon rode over the plain and surveyed the locality with a profound
