 42990	CHAPTER XXVIII
 42991	
 42992	Many historians say that the French did not win the battle of BorodinÃ³
 42993	because Napoleon had a cold, and that if he had not had a cold the
 42994	orders he gave before and during the battle would have been still more
 42995	full of genius and Russia would have been lost and the face of the world
 42996	have been changed. To historians who believe that Russia was shaped
 42997	by the will of one manâPeter the Greatâand that France from a republic
 42998	became an empire and French armies went to Russia at the will of one
 42999	manâNapoleonâto say that Russia remained a power because Napoleon had a
 43000	bad cold on the twenty-fourth of August may seem logical and convincing.
 43001	
 43002	If it had depended on Napoleonâs will to fight or not to fight the
 43003	battle of BorodinÃ³, and if this or that other arrangement depended on
 43004	his will, then evidently a cold affecting the manifestation of his will
 43005	might have saved Russia, and consequently the valet who omitted to bring
 43006	Napoleon his waterproof boots on the twenty-fourth would have been
 43007	the savior of Russia. Along that line of thought such a deduction is
 43008	indubitable, as indubitable as the deduction Voltaire made in jest
 43009	(without knowing what he was jesting at) when he saw that the Massacre
 43010	of St. Bartholomew was due to Charles IXâs stomach being deranged. But
 43011	to men who do not admit that Russia was formed by the will of one man,
 43012	Peter I, or that the French Empire was formed and the war with Russia
 43013	begun by the will of one man, Napoleon, that argument seems not merely
 43014	untrue and irrational, but contrary to all human reality. To the
 43015	question of what causes historic events another answer presents itself,
 43016	namely, that the course of human events is predetermined from on
 43017	highâdepends on the coincidence of the wills of all who take part in the
 43018	events, and that a Napoleonâs influence on the course of these events is
 43019	purely external and fictitious.
 43020	
 43021	Strange as at first glance it may seem to suppose that the Massacre of
 43022	St. Bartholomew was not due to Charles IXâs will, though he gave the
 43023	order for it and thought it was done as a result of that order; and
 43024	strange as it may seem to suppose that the slaughter of eighty thousand
 43025	men at BorodinÃ³ was not due to Napoleonâs will, though he ordered the
 43026	commencement and conduct of the battle and thought it was done
 43027	because he ordered it; strange as these suppositions appear, yet human
 43028	dignityâwhich tells me that each of us is, if not more at least not less
 43029	a man than the great Napoleonâdemands the acceptance of that solution of
 43030	the question, and historic investigation abundantly confirms it.
 43031	
 43032	At the battle of BorodinÃ³ Napoleon shot at no one and killed no one.
 43033	That was all done by the soldiers. Therefore it was not he who killed
 43034	people.
 43035	
 43036	The French soldiers went to kill and be killed at the battle of BorodinÃ³
 43037	not because of Napoleonâs orders but by their own volition. The whole
 43038	armyâFrench, Italian, German, Polish, and Dutchâhungry, ragged, and
 43039	weary of the campaign, felt at the sight of an army blocking their road
 43040	to Moscow that the wine was drawn and must be drunk. Had Napoleon then
 43041	forbidden them to fight the Russians, they would have killed him and
 43042	have proceeded to fight the Russians because it was inevitable.
 43043	
 43044	When they heard Napoleonâs proclamation offering them, as compensation
 43045	for mutilation and death, the words of posterity about their having been
 43046	in the battle before Moscow, they cried âVive lâEmpereur!â just as they
 43047	had cried âVive lâEmpereur!â at the sight of the portrait of the boy
 43048	piercing the terrestrial globe with a toy stick, and just as they would
 43049	have cried âVive lâEmpereur!â at any nonsense that might be told them.
 43050	There was nothing left for them to do but cry âVive lâEmpereur!â and go
 43051	to fight, in order to get food and rest as conquerors in Moscow. So it
 43052	was not because of Napoleonâs commands that they killed their fellow
 43053	men.
 43054	
 43055	And it was not Napoleon who directed the course of the battle, for none
 43056	of his orders were executed and during the battle he did not know what
 43057	was going on before him. So the way in which these people killed one
 43058	another was not decided by Napoleonâs will but occurred independently of
 43059	him, in accord with the will of hundreds of thousands of people who took
 43060	part in the common action. It only seemed to Napoleon that it all took
 43061	place by his will. And so the question whether he had or had not a
 43062	cold has no more historic interest than the cold of the least of the
 43063	transport soldiers.
 43064	
 43065	Moreover, the assertion made by various writers that his cold was
 43066	the cause of his dispositions not being as well-planned as on former
 43067	occasions, and of his orders during the battle not being as good as
 43068	previously, is quite baseless, which again shows that Napoleonâs cold on
 43069	the twenty-sixth of August was unimportant.
 43070	
 43071	The dispositions cited above are not at all worse, but are even
 43072	better, than previous dispositions by which he had won victories. His
 43073	pseudo-orders during the battle were also no worse than formerly, but
 43074	much the same as usual. These dispositions and orders only seem worse
 43075	than previous ones because the battle of BorodinÃ³ was the first Napoleon
 43076	did not win. The profoundest and most excellent dispositions and orders
 43077	seem very bad, and every learned militarist criticizes them with looks
 43078	of importance, when they relate to a battle that has been lost, and the
 43079	very worst dispositions and orders seem very good, and serious people
 43080	fill whole volumes to demonstrate their merits, when they relate to a
 43081	battle that has been won.
 43082	
 43083	The dispositions drawn up by Weyrother for the battle of Austerlitz were
 43084	a model of perfection for that kind of composition, but still they were
 43085	criticizedâcriticized for their very perfection, for their excessive
 43086	minuteness.
 43087	
 43088	Napoleon at the battle of BorodinÃ³ fulfilled his office as
 43089	representative of authority as well as, and even better than, at other
 43090	battles. He did nothing harmful to the progress of the battle; he
 43091	inclined to the most reasonable opinions, he made no confusion, did not
 43092	contradict himself, did not get frightened or run away from the field of
 43093	battle, but with his great tact and military experience carried out his
 43094	role of appearing to command, calmly and with dignity.

 44359	Prince Andrewâs regiment was among the reserves which till after one

 44376	
 44377	With each fresh blow less and less chance of life remained for those not

 44866	
 44867	Anyone looking at the disorganized rear of the Russian army would have

 44882

 44888	who had attacked the Russian army in order to drive it from its position

 44890	block the road to Moscow as before, the aim of the French had not been

 44897	want to, but because it could not be done. All the generals, officers,

 44899	flagging spirit of the troops would not permit it.
 44900	
 44901	It was not Napoleon alone who had experienced that nightmare feeling

 44930	BOOK ELEVEN: 1812
 44931

 44934	
 44935	
 44936	CHAPTER I
 44937	
 44938	Absolute continuity of motion is not comprehensible to the human mind.
 44939	Laws of motion of any kind become comprehensible to man only when he
 44940	examines arbitrarily selected elements of that motion; but at the
 44941	same time, a large proportion of human error comes from the arbitrary
 44942	division of continuous motion into discontinuous elements. There is a
 44943	well-known, so-called sophism of the ancients consisting in this, that
 44944	Achilles could never catch up with a tortoise he was following, in spite
 44945	of the fact that he traveled ten times as fast as the tortoise. By
 44946	the time Achilles has covered the distance that separated him from the
 44947	tortoise, the tortoise has covered one tenth of that distance ahead
 44948	of him: when Achilles has covered that tenth, the tortoise has covered
 44949	another one hundredth, and so on forever. This problem seemed to
 44950	the ancients insoluble. The absurd answer (that Achilles could never
 44951	overtake the tortoise) resulted from this: that motion was arbitrarily
 44952	divided into discontinuous elements, whereas the motion both of Achilles
 44953	and of the tortoise was continuous.
 44954	
 44955	By adopting smaller and smaller elements of motion we only approach a
 44956	solution of the problem, but never reach it. Only when we have admitted
 44957	the conception of the infinitely small, and the resulting geometrical
 44958	progression with a common ratio of one tenth, and have found the sum of
 44959	this progression to infinity, do we reach a solution of the problem.
 44960	
 44961	A modern branch of mathematics having achieved the art of dealing with
 44962	the infinitely small can now yield solutions in other more complex
 44963	problems of motion which used to appear insoluble.
 44964	
 44965	This modern branch of mathematics, unknown to the ancients, when dealing
 44966	with problems of motion admits the conception of the infinitely small,
 44967	and so conforms to the chief condition of motion (absolute continuity)
 44968	and thereby corrects the inevitable error which the human mind cannot
 44969	avoid when it deals with separate elements of motion instead of
 44970	examining continuous motion.
 44971	
 44972	In seeking the laws of historical movement just the same thing happens.
 44973	The movement of humanity, arising as it does from innumerable arbitrary
 44974	human wills, is continuous.
 44975	
 44976	To understand the laws of this continuous movement is the aim of
 44977	history. But to arrive at these laws, resulting from the sum of all
 44978	those human wills, manâs mind postulates arbitrary and disconnected
 44979	units. The first method of history is to take an arbitrarily selected
 44980	series of continuous events and examine it apart from others, though
 44981	there is and can be no beginning to any event, for one event always
 44982	flows uninterruptedly from another.
 44983	
 44984	The second method is to consider the actions of some one manâa king or a
 44985	commanderâas equivalent to the sum of many individual wills; whereas the
 44986	sum of individual wills is never expressed by the activity of a single
 44987	historic personage.
 44988	
 44989	Historical science in its endeavor to draw nearer to truth continually
 44990	takes smaller and smaller units for examination. But however small the
 44991	units it takes, we feel that to take any unit disconnected from others,
 44992	or to assume a beginning of any phenomenon, or to say that the will of
 44993	many men is expressed by the actions of any one historic personage, is
 44994	in itself false.
 44995	
 44996	It needs no critical exertion to reduce utterly to dust any deductions
 44997	drawn from history. It is merely necessary to select some larger or
 44998	smaller unit as the subject of observationâas criticism has every
 44999	right to do, seeing that whatever unit history observes must always be
 45000	arbitrarily selected.
 45001	
 45002	Only by taking infinitesimally small units for observation (the
 45003	differential of history, that is, the individual tendencies of men) and
 45004	attaining to the art of integrating them (that is, finding the sum of
 45005	these infinitesimals) can we hope to arrive at the laws of history.
 45006	
 45007	The first fifteen years of the nineteenth century in Europe present an
 45008	extraordinary movement of millions of people. Men leave their customary
 45009	pursuits, hasten from one side of Europe to the other, plunder and
 45010	slaughter one another, triumph and are plunged in despair, and for some
 45011	years the whole course of life is altered and presents an intensive
 45012	movement which first increases and then slackens. What was the cause of
 45013	this movement, by what laws was it governed? asks the mind of man.
 45014	
 45015	The historians, replying to this question, lay before us the sayings and
 45016	doings of a few dozen men in a building in the city of Paris, calling
 45017	these sayings and doings âthe Revolutionâ; then they give a detailed
 45018	biography of Napoleon and of certain people favorable or hostile to him;
 45019	tell of the influence some of these people had on others, and say: that
 45020	is why this movement took place and those are its laws.
 45021	
 45022	But the mind of man not only refuses to believe this explanation, but
 45023	plainly says that this method of explanation is fallacious, because in
 45024	it a weaker phenomenon is taken as the cause of a stronger. The sum of
 45025	human wills produced the Revolution and Napoleon, and only the sum of
 45026	those wills first tolerated and then destroyed them.
 45027	
 45028	âBut every time there have been conquests there have been conquerors;
 45029	every time there has been a revolution in any state there have been
 45030	great men,â says history. And, indeed, human reason replies: every time
 45031	conquerors appear there have been wars, but this does not prove that the
 45032	conquerors caused the wars and that it is possible to find the laws of
 45033	a war in the personal activity of a single man. Whenever I look at my
 45034	watch and its hands point to ten, I hear the bells of the neighboring
 45035	church; but because the bells begin to ring when the hands of the clock
 45036	reach ten, I have no right to assume that the movement of the bells is
 45037	caused by the position of the hands of the watch.
 45038	
 45039	Whenever I see the movement of a locomotive I hear the whistle and see
 45040	the valves opening and wheels turning; but I have no right to conclude
 45041	that the whistling and the turning of wheels are the cause of the
 45042	movement of the engine.
 45043	
 45044	The peasants say that a cold wind blows in late spring because the oaks
 45045	are budding, and really every spring cold winds do blow when the oak
 45046	is budding. But though I do not know what causes the cold winds to blow
 45047	when the oak buds unfold, I cannot agree with the peasants that the
 45048	unfolding of the oak buds is the cause of the cold wind, for the
 45049	force of the wind is beyond the influence of the buds. I see only a
 45050	coincidence of occurrences such as happens with all the phenomena of
 45051	life, and I see that however much and however carefully I observe the
 45052	hands of the watch, and the valves and wheels of the engine, and the
 45053	oak, I shall not discover the cause of the bells ringing, the engine
 45054	moving, or of the winds of spring. To that I must entirely change my
 45055	point of view and study the laws of the movement of steam, of the
 45056	bells, and of the wind. History must do the same. And attempts in this
 45057	direction have already been made.
 45058	
 45059	To study the laws of history we must completely change the subject of
 45060	our observation, must leave aside kings, ministers, and generals, and
 45061	study the common, infinitesimally small elements by which the masses are
 45062	moved. No one can say in how far it is possible for man to advance
 45063	in this way toward an understanding of the laws of history; but it is
 45064	evident that only along that path does the possibility of discovering
 45065	the laws of history lie, and that as yet not a millionth part as much
 45066	mental effort has been applied in this direction by historians as has
 45067	been devoted to describing the actions of various kings, commanders,
 45068	and ministers and propounding the historiansâ own reflections concerning
 45069	these actions.

 45077	The forces of a dozen European nations burst into Russia. The Russian

 45116

 45134	
 45135	For people accustomed to think that plans of campaign and battles are

 45143	commander in chief. The activity of a commander in chief does not at all
 45144	resemble the activity we imagine to ourselves when we sit at ease in
 45145	our studies examining some campaign on the map, with a certain number of
 45146	troops on this and that side in a certain known locality, and begin our
 45147	plans from some given moment. A commander in chief is never dealing with
 45148	the beginning of any eventâthe position from which we always contemplate
 45149	it. The commander in chief is always in the midst of a series of
 45150	shifting events and so he never can at any moment consider the whole
 45151	import of an event that is occurring. Moment by moment the event is
 45152	imperceptibly shaping itself, and at every moment of this continuous,
 45153	uninterrupted shaping of events the commander in chief is in the

 45155	authorities, projects, counsels, threats, and deceptions and is
 45156	continually obliged to reply to innumerable questions addressed to him,

 45158	
 45159	Learned military authorities quite seriously tell us that KutÃºzov should

 45165	
 45166	A commander in chiefâs business, it would seem, is simply to choose one

 45454	At that very time, in circumstances even more important than retreating

 47767	CHAPTER XX
 47768	
 47769	Meanwhile Moscow was empty. There were still people in it, perhaps a
 47770	fiftieth part of its former inhabitants had remained, but it was empty.
 47771	It was empty in the sense that a dying queenless hive is empty.
 47772	
 47773	In a queenless hive no life is left though to a superficial glance it
 47774	seems as much alive as other hives.
 47775	
 47776	The bees circle round a queenless hive in the hot beams of the midday
 47777	sun as gaily as around the living hives; from a distance it smells of
 47778	honey like the others, and bees fly in and out in the same way. But one
 47779	has only to observe that hive to realize that there is no longer any
 47780	life in it. The bees do not fly in the same way, the smell and the sound
 47781	that meet the beekeeper are not the same. To the beekeeperâs tap on the
 47782	wall of the sick hive, instead of the former instant unanimous
 47783	humming of tens of thousands of bees with their abdomens threateningly
 47784	compressed, and producing by the rapid vibration of their wings an
 47785	aerial living sound, the only reply is a disconnected buzzing from
 47786	different parts of the deserted hive. From the alighting board, instead
 47787	of the former spirituous fragrant smell of honey and venom, and the warm
 47788	whiffs of crowded life, comes an odor of emptiness and decay mingling
 47789	with the smell of honey. There are no longer sentinels sounding the
 47790	alarm with their abdomens raised, and ready to die in defense of the
 47791	hive. There is no longer the measured quiet sound of throbbing activity,
 47792	like the sound of boiling water, but diverse discordant sounds of
 47793	disorder. In and out of the hive long black robber bees smeared with
 47794	honey fly timidly and shiftily. They do not sting, but crawl away from
 47795	danger. Formerly only bees laden with honey flew into the hive, and they
 47796	flew out empty; now they fly out laden. The beekeeper opens the lower
 47797	part of the hive and peers in. Instead of black, glossy beesâtamed by
 47798	toil, clinging to one anotherâs legs and drawing out the wax, with a
 47799	ceaseless hum of laborâthat used to hang in long clusters down to the
 47800	floor of the hive, drowsy shriveled bees crawl about separately in
 47801	various directions on the floor and walls of the hive. Instead of a
 47802	neatly glued floor, swept by the bees with the fanning of their wings,
 47803	there is a floor littered with bits of wax, excrement, dying bees
 47804	scarcely moving their legs, and dead ones that have not been cleared
 47805	away.
 47806	
 47807	The beekeeper opens the upper part of the hive and examines the super.
 47808	Instead of serried rows of bees sealing up every gap in the combs and
 47809	keeping the brood warm, he sees the skillful complex structures of the
 47810	combs, but no longer in their former state of purity. All is neglected
 47811	and foul. Black robber bees are swiftly and stealthily prowling about
 47812	the combs, and the short home bees, shriveled and listless as if they
 47813	were old, creep slowly about without trying to hinder the robbers,
 47814	having lost all motive and all sense of life. Drones, bumblebees, wasps,
 47815	and butterflies knock awkwardly against the walls of the hive in their
 47816	flight. Here and there among the cells containing dead brood and honey
 47817	an angry buzzing can sometimes be heard. Here and there a couple of
 47818	bees, by force of habit and custom cleaning out the brood cells, with
 47819	efforts beyond their strength laboriously drag away a dead bee or
 47820	bumblebee without knowing why they do it. In another corner two old bees
 47821	are languidly fighting, or cleaning themselves, or feeding one another,
 47822	without themselves knowing whether they do it with friendly or hostile
 47823	intent. In a third place a crowd of bees, crushing one another, attack
 47824	some victim and fight and smother it, and the victim, enfeebled or
 47825	killed, drops from above slowly and lightly as a feather, among the heap
 47826	of corpses. The keeper opens the two center partitions to examine
 47827	the brood cells. In place of the former close dark circles formed by
 47828	thousands of bees sitting back to back and guarding the high mystery
 47829	of generation, he sees hundreds of dull, listless, and sleepy shells of
 47830	bees. They have almost all died unawares, sitting in the sanctuary they
 47831	had guarded and which is now no more. They reek of decay and death. Only
 47832	a few of them still move, rise, and feebly fly to settle on the enemyâs
 47833	hand, lacking the spirit to die stinging him; the rest are dead and fall
 47834	as lightly as fish scales. The beekeeper closes the hive, chalks a mark
 47835	on it, and when he has time tears out its contents and burns it clean.
 47836	
 47837	So in the same way Moscow was empty when Napoleon, weary, uneasy, and
 47838	morose, paced up and down in front of the KÃ¡mmer-KollÃ©zski rampart,
 47839	awaiting what to his mind was a necessary, if but formal, observance of
 47840	the proprietiesâa deputation.
 47841	
 47842	In various corners of Moscow there still remained a few people aimlessly
 47843	moving about, following their old habits and hardly aware of what they
 47844	were doing.
 47845	
 47846	When with due circumspection Napoleon was informed that Moscow was

 48470	Toward nine oâclock in the morning, when the troops were already moving

 48477	
 48478	In quiet and untroubled times it seems to every administrator that it
 48479	is only by his efforts that the whole population under his rule is
 48480	kept going, and in this consciousness of being indispensable every
 48481	administrator finds the chief reward of his labor and efforts. While the
 48482	sea of history remains calm the ruler-administrator in his frail bark,
 48483	holding on with a boat hook to the ship of the people and himself
 48484	moving, naturally imagines that his efforts move the ship he is holding
 48485	on to. But as soon as a storm arises and the sea begins to heave and
 48486	the ship to move, such a delusion is no longer possible. The ship moves
 48487	independently with its own enormous motion, the boat hook no longer
 48488	reaches the moving vessel, and suddenly the administrator, instead
 48489	of appearing a ruler and a source of power, becomes an insignificant,
 48490	useless, feeble man.

 49031	
 49032	
 49033	The French attributed the Fire of Moscow au patriotisme fÃ©roce de
 49034	RostopchÃ­ne, * the Russians to the barbarity of the French. In reality,
 49035	however, it was not, and could not be, possible to explain the burning
 49036	of Moscow by making any individual, or any group of people, responsible
 49037	for it. Moscow was burned because it found itself in a position in which
 49038	any town built of wood was bound to burn, quite apart from whether it
 49039	had, or had not, a hundred and thirty inferior fire engines. Deserted
 49040	Moscow had to burn as inevitably as a heap of shavings has to burn on
 49041	which sparks continually fall for several days. A town built of wood,
 49042	where scarcely a day passes without conflagrations when the house owners
 49043	are in residence and a police force is present, cannot help burning when
 49044	its inhabitants have left it and it is occupied by soldiers who smoke
 49045	pipes, make campfires of the Senate chairs in the Senate Square, and
 49046	cook themselves meals twice a day. In peacetime it is only necessary to
 49047	billet troops in the villages of any district and the number of fires in
 49048	that district immediately increases. How much then must the probability
 49049	of fire be increased in an abandoned, wooden town where foreign troops
 49050	are quartered. âLe patriotisme fÃ©roce de RostopchÃ­neâ and the barbarity
 49051	of the French were not to blame in the matter. Moscow was set on fire by
 49052	the soldiersâ pipes, kitchens, and campfires, and by the carelessness of
 49053	enemy soldiers occupying houses they did not own. Even if there was any
 49054	arson (which is very doubtful, for no one had any reason to burn the
 49055	housesâin any case a troublesome and dangerous thing to do), arson
 49056	cannot be regarded as the cause, for the same thing would have happened
 49057	without any incendiarism.
 49058	
 49059	    * To RostopchÃ­nâs ferocious patriotism.
 49060	
 49061	However tempting it might be for the French to blame RostopchÃ­nâs
 49062	ferocity and for Russians to blame the scoundrel Bonaparte, or later

 49064	impossible not to see that there could be no such direct cause of the
 49065	fire, for Moscow had to burn as every village, factory, or house must
 49066	burn which is left by its owners and in which strangers are allowed to
 49067	live and cook their porridge. Moscow was burned by its inhabitants, it
 49068	is true, but by those who had abandoned it and not by those who remained
 49069	in it. Moscow when occupied by the enemy did not remain intact like
 49070	Berlin, Vienna, and other towns, simply because its inhabitants
 49071	abandoned it and did not welcome the French with bread and salt, nor
 49072	bring them the keys of the city.

 49078	CHAPTER XXVII
 49079	
 49080	The absorption of the French by Moscow, radiating starwise as it did,

 49083	
 49084	After the last two days spent in solitude and unusual circumstances,
 49085	Pierre was in a state bordering on insanity. He was completely obsessed

 51227	CHAPTER IV
 51228	
 51229	It is natural for us who were not living in those days to imagine that
 51230	when half Russia had been conquered and the inhabitants were fleeing to
 51231	distant provinces, and one levy after another was being raised for the
 51232	defense of the fatherland, all Russians from the greatest to the least
 51233	were solely engaged in sacrificing themselves, saving their fatherland,
 51234	or weeping over its downfall. The tales and descriptions of that time
 51235	without exception speak only of the self-sacrifice, patriotic devotion,
 51236	despair, grief, and the heroism of the Russians. But it was not really
 51237	so. It appears so to us because we see only the general historic
 51238	interest of that time and do not see all the personal human interests
 51239	that people had. Yet in reality those personal interests of the moment
 51240	so much transcend the general interests that they always prevent the
 51241	public interest from being felt or even noticed. Most of the people at
 51242	that time paid no attention to the general progress of events but were
 51243	guided only by their private interests, and they were the very people
 51244	whose activities at that period were most useful.
 51245	
 51246	Those who tried to understand the general course of events and to take
 51247	part in it by self-sacrifice and heroism were the most useless members
 51248	of society, they saw everything upside down, and all they did for the
 51249	common good turned out to be useless and foolishâlike Pierreâs and
 51250	MamÃ³novâs regiments which looted Russian villages, and the lint the
 51251	young ladies prepared and that never reached the wounded, and so on.
 51252	Even those, fond of intellectual talk and of expressing their feelings,
 51253	who discussed Russiaâs position at the time involuntarily introduced
 51254	into their conversation either a shade of pretense and falsehood or
 51255	useless condemnation and anger directed against people accused of
 51256	actions no one could possibly be guilty of. In historic events the rule
 51257	forbidding us to eat of the fruit of the Tree of Knowledge is specially
 51258	applicable. Only unconscious action bears fruit, and he who plays a part
 51259	in an historic event never understands its significance. If he tries to
 51260	realize it his efforts are fruitless.
 51261	
 51262	The more closely a man was engaged in the events then taking place in
 51263	Russia the less did he realize their significance. In Petersburg and
 51264	in the provinces at a distance from Moscow, ladies, and gentlemen in
 51265	militia uniforms, wept for Russia and its ancient capital and talked of
 51266	self-sacrifice and so on; but in the army which retired beyond Moscow
 51267	there was little talk or thought of Moscow, and when they caught sight
 51268	of its burned ruins no one swore to be avenged on the French, but they
 51269	thought about their next pay, their next quarters, of MatrÃ«shka the
 51270	vivandiÃ¨re, and like matters.
 51271	
 51272	As the war had caught him in the service, Nicholas RostÃ³v took a close
 51273	and prolonged part in the defense of his country, but did so casually,
 51274	without any aim at self-sacrifice, and he therefore looked at what was
 51275	going on in Russia without despair and without dismally racking his
 51276	brains over it. Had he been asked what he thought of the state of
 51277	Russia, he would have said that it was not his business to think about

 51279	heard that the regiments were to be made up to their full strength, that

 52515	CHAPTER XII
 52516	
 52517	After the execution Pierre was separated from the rest of the prisoners

 52534	From the moment Pierre had witnessed those terrible murders committed by

 53568	BOOK THIRTEEN: 1812

 53573	
 53574	CHAPTER I
 53575	
 53576	Manâs mind cannot grasp the causes of events in their completeness, but
 53577	the desire to find those causes is implanted in manâs soul. And without
 53578	considering the multiplicity and complexity of the conditions any one
 53579	of which taken separately may seem to be the cause, he snatches at the
 53580	first approximation to a cause that seems to him intelligible and says:
 53581	âThis is the cause!â In historical events (where the actions of men are
 53582	the subject of observation) the first and most primitive approximation
 53583	to present itself was the will of the gods and, after that, the will of
 53584	those who stood in the most prominent positionâthe heroes of history.
 53585	But we need only penetrate to the essence of any historic eventâwhich
 53586	lies in the activity of the general mass of men who take part in itâto
 53587	be convinced that the will of the historic hero does not control the
 53588	actions of the mass but is itself continually controlled. It may seem
 53589	to be a matter of indifference whether we understand the meaning of
 53590	historical events this way or that; yet there is the same difference
 53591	between a man who says that the people of the West moved on the East
 53592	because Napoleon wished it and a man who says that this happened because
 53593	it had to happen, as there is between those who declared that the
 53594	earth was stationary and that the planets moved round it and those who
 53595	admitted that they did not know what upheld the earth, but knew there
 53596	were laws directing its movement and that of the other planets. There
 53597	is, and can be, no cause of an historical event except the one cause of
 53598	all causes. But there are laws directing events, and some of these laws
 53599	are known to us while we are conscious of others we cannot comprehend.
 53600	The discovery of these laws is only possible when we have quite
 53601	abandoned the attempt to find the cause in the will of some one man,
 53602	just as the discovery of the laws of the motion of the planets was
 53603	possible only when men abandoned the conception of the fixity of the
 53604	earth.
 53605	
 53606	The historians consider that, next to the battle of BorodinÃ³ and the
 53607	occupation of Moscow by the enemy and its destruction by fire, the most
 53608	important episode of the war of 1812 was the movement of the Russian
 53609	army from the RyazÃ¡na to the KalÃºga road and to the TarÃºtino campâthe
 53610	so-called flank march across the KrÃ¡snaya PakhrÃ¡ River. They ascribe the
 53611	glory of that achievement of genius to different men and dispute as to
 53612	whom the honor is due. Even foreign historians, including the French,
 53613	acknowledge the genius of the Russian commanders when they speak of
 53614	that flank march. But it is hard to understand why military writers,
 53615	and following them others, consider this flank march to be the profound
 53616	conception of some one man who saved Russia and destroyed Napoleon. In
 53617	the first place it is hard to understand where the profundity and genius
 53618	of this movement lay, for not much mental effort was needed to see that
 53619	the best position for an army when it is not being attacked is where
 53620	there are most provisions; and even a dull boy of thirteen could have
 53621	guessed that the best position for an army after its retreat from Moscow
 53622	in 1812 was on the KalÃºga road. So it is impossible to understand by
 53623	what reasoning the historians reach the conclusion that this maneuver
 53624	was a profound one. And it is even more difficult to understand just why
 53625	they think that this maneuver was calculated to save Russia and destroy
 53626	the French; for this flank march, had it been preceded, accompanied,
 53627	or followed by other circumstances, might have proved ruinous to the
 53628	Russians and salutary for the French. If the position of the Russian
 53629	army really began to improve from the time of that march, it does not at
 53630	all follow that the march was the cause of it.
 53631	
 53632	That flank march might not only have failed to give any advantage to
 53633	the Russian army, but might in other circumstances have led to its
 53634	destruction. What would have happened had Moscow not burned down? If
 53635	Murat had not lost sight of the Russians? If Napoleon had not remained
 53636	inactive? If the Russian army at KrÃ¡snaya PakhrÃ¡ had given battle as
 53637	Bennigsen and Barclay advised? What would have happened had the French
 53638	attacked the Russians while they were marching beyond the PakhrÃ¡? What
 53639	would have happened if on approaching TarÃºtino, Napoleon had attacked
 53640	the Russians with but a tenth of the energy he had shown when he
 53641	attacked them at SmolÃ©nsk? What would have happened had the French moved
 53642	on Petersburg?... In any of these eventualities the flank march that
 53643	brought salvation might have proved disastrous.
 53644	
 53645	The third and most incomprehensible thing is that people studying
 53646	history deliberately avoid seeing that this flank march cannot be
 53647	attributed to any one man, that no one ever foresaw it, and that in
 53648	reality, like the retreat from FilÃ­, it did not suggest itself to anyone
 53649	in its entirety, but resultedâmoment by moment, step by step, event by
 53650	eventâfrom an endless number of most diverse circumstances and was only
 53651	seen in its entirety when it had been accomplished and belonged to the
 53652	past.
 53653	
 53654	At the council at FilÃ­ the prevailing thought in the minds of the
 53655	Russian commanders was the one naturally suggesting itself, namely, a
 53656	direct retreat by the NÃ­zhni road. In proof of this there is the fact
 53657	that the majority of the council voted for such a retreat, and above

 53659	commander in chief and LanskÃ³y, who was in charge of the commissariat

 53664	crossed early in winter. This was the first indication of the necessity

 53666	direct retreat on NÃ­zhni-NÃ³vgorod. The army turned more to the south,
 53667	along the RyazÃ¡n road and nearer to its supplies. Subsequently the

 53690	CHAPTER II
 53691	
 53692	The famous flank movement merely consisted in this: after the advance
 53693	of the French had ceased, the Russian army, which had been continually
 53694	retreating straight back from the invaders, deviated from that direct
 53695	course and, not finding itself pursued, was naturally drawn toward the
 53696	district where supplies were abundant.
 53697	
 53698	If instead of imagining to ourselves commanders of genius leading the
 53699	Russian army, we picture that army without any leaders, it could not
 53700	have done anything but make a return movement toward Moscow, describing
 53701	an arc in the direction where most provisions were to be found and where
 53702	the country was richest.
 53703	
 53704	That movement from the NÃ­zhni to the RyazÃ¡n, TÃºla, and KalÃºga roads was

 54054	
 54055	Next day the troops assembled in their appointed places in the evening

 54187	straight ahead, leading his men under fire, without considering in his
 54188	agitation whether going into action now, with a single division, would
 54189	be of any use or no. Danger, cannon balls, and bullets were just what he
 54190	needed in his angry mood. One of the first bullets killed him, and other
 54191	bullets killed many of his men. And his division remained under fire for
 54192	some time quite uselessly.
 54193	
 54194	
 54195

 54197	
 54198	CHAPTER VII
 54199	
 54200	Meanwhile another column was to have attacked the French from the front,
 54201	but KutÃºzov accompanied that column. He well knew that nothing but
 54202	confusion would come of this battle undertaken against his will, and as
 54203	far as was in his power held the troops back. He did not advance.
 54204	
 54205	He rode silently on his small gray horse, indolently answering
 54206	suggestions that they should attack.
 54207	
 54208	âThe word attack is always on your tongue, but you donât see that we are
 54209	unable to execute complicated maneuvers,â said he to MilorÃ¡dovich who
 54210	asked permission to advance.
 54211	
 54212	âWe couldnât take Murat prisoner this morning or get to the place in
 54213	time, and nothing can be done now!â he replied to someone else.
 54214	
 54215	When KutÃºzov was informed that at the French rearâwhere according to the

 54219	
 54220	âYou see! They are asking to attack and making plans of all kinds,
 54221	but as soon as one gets to business nothing is ready, and the enemy,
 54222	forewarned, takes measures accordingly.â
 54223	
 54224	ErmÃ³lov screwed up his eyes and smiled faintly on hearing these words.
 54225	He understood that for him the storm had blown over, and that KutÃºzov
 54226	would content himself with that hint.
 54227	
 54228	âHeâs having a little fun at my expense,â said ErmÃ³lov softly, nudging
 54229	with his knee RaÃ©vski who was at his side.
 54230	
 54231	Soon after this, ErmÃ³lov moved up to KutÃºzov and respectfully remarked:
 54232	
 54233	âIt is not too late yet, your Highnessâthe enemy has not gone awayâif
 54234	you were to order an attack! If not, the Guards will not so much as see
 54235	a little smoke.â
 54236	
 54237	KutÃºzov did not reply, but when they reported to him that Muratâs troops
 54238	were in retreat he ordered an advance, though at every hundred paces he
 54239	halted for three quarters of an hour.
 54240	
 54241	The whole battle consisted in what OrlÃ³v-DenÃ­sovâs Cossacks had done:
 54242	the rest of the army merely lost some hundreds of men uselessly.
 54243	
 54244	In consequence of this battle KutÃºzov received a diamond decoration,
 54245	and Bennigsen some diamonds and a hundred thousand rubles, others also
 54246	received pleasant recognitions corresponding to their various grades,
 54247	and following the battle fresh changes were made in the staff.
 54248	
 54249	âThatâs how everything is done with us, all topsy-turvy!â said the
 54250	Russian officers and generals after the TarÃºtino battle, letting it be
 54251	understood that some fool there is doing things all wrong but that
 54252	we ourselves should not have done so, just as people speak today. But
 54253	people who talk like that either do not know what they are talking about
 54254	or deliberately deceive themselves. No battleâTarÃºtino, BorodinÃ³, or
 54255	Austerlitzâtakes place as those who planned it anticipated. That is an
 54256	essential condition.
 54257	
 54258	A countless number of free forces (for nowhere is man freer than during
 54259	a battle, where it is a question of life and death) influence the course
 54260	taken by the fight, and that course never can be known in advance and
 54261	never coincides with the direction of any one force.
 54262	
 54263	If many simultaneously and variously directed forces act on a given
 54264	body, the direction of its motion cannot coincide with any one of those
 54265	forces, but will always be a meanâwhat in mechanics is represented by
 54266	the diagonal of a parallelogram of forces.
 54267	
 54268	If in the descriptions given by historians, especially French ones, we
 54269	find their wars and battles carried out in accordance with previously
 54270	formed plans, the only conclusion to be drawn is that those descriptions
 54271	are false.
 54272	
 54273	The battle of TarÃºtino obviously did not attain the aim Toll had in
 54274	viewâto lead the troops into action in the order prescribed by the
 54275	dispositions; nor that which Count OrlÃ³v-DenÃ­sov may have had in viewâto
 54276	take Murat prisoner; nor the result of immediately destroying the whole
 54277	corps, which Bennigsen and others may have had in view; nor the aim of
 54278	the officer who wished to go into action to distinguish himself; nor
 54279	that of the Cossack who wanted more booty than he got, and so on. But
 54280	if the aim of the battle was what actually resulted and what all the
 54281	Russians of that day desiredâto drive the French out of Russia and
 54282	destroy their armyâit is quite clear that the battle of TarÃºtino, just
 54283	because of its incongruities, was exactly what was wanted at that stage
 54284	of the campaign. It would be difficult and even impossible to imagine
 54285	any result more opportune than the actual outcome of this battle. With
 54286	a minimum of effort and insignificant losses, despite the greatest
 54287	confusion, the most important results of the whole campaign were
 54288	attained: the transition from retreat to advance, an exposure of the
 54289	weakness of the French, and the administration of that shock which
 54290	Napoleonâs army had only awaited to begin its flight.
 54291	
 54292	
 54293	
 54294	
 54295	
 54296	CHAPTER VIII
 54297	
 54298	Napoleon enters Moscow after the brilliant victory de la Moskowa; there
 54299	can be no doubt about the victory for the battlefield remains in the
 54300	hands of the French. The Russians retreat and abandon their ancient
 54301	capital. Moscow, abounding in provisions, arms, munitions, and
 54302	incalculable wealth, is in Napoleonâs hands. The Russian army, only half
 54303	the strength of the French, does not make a single attempt to attack for
 54304	a whole month. Napoleonâs position is most brilliant. He can either fall
 54305	on the Russian army with double its strength and destroy it; negotiate
 54306	an advantageous peace, or in case of a refusal make a menacing move on
 54307	Petersburg, or even, in the case of a reverse, return to SmolÃ©nsk or
 54308	VÃ­lna; or remain in Moscow; in short, no special genius would seem to be
 54309	required to retain the brilliant position the French held at that time.
 54310	For that, only very simple and easy steps were necessary: not to allow
 54311	the troops to loot, to prepare winter clothingâof which there was
 54312	sufficient in Moscow for the whole armyâand methodically to collect the
 54313	provisions, of which (according to the French historians) there were
 54314	enough in Moscow to supply the whole army for six months. Yet Napoleon,
 54315	that greatest of all geniuses, who the historians declare had control of
 54316	the army, took none of these steps.
 54317	
 54318	He not merely did nothing of the kind, but on the contrary he used his
 54319	power to select the most foolish and ruinous of all the courses open
 54320	to him. Of all that Napoleon might have done: wintering in Moscow,
 54321	advancing on Petersburg or on NÃ­zhni-NÃ³vgorod, or retiring by a more
 54322	northerly or more southerly route (say by the road KutÃºzov afterwards
 54323	took), nothing more stupid or disastrous can be imagined than what he
 54324	actually did. He remained in Moscow till October, letting the troops
 54325	plunder the city; then, hesitating whether to leave a garrison behind
 54326	him, he quitted Moscow, approached KutÃºzov without joining battle,
 54327	turned to the right and reached MÃ¡lo-YaroslÃ¡vets, again without
 54328	attempting to break through and take the road KutÃºzov took, but retiring
 54329	instead to MozhÃ¡ysk along the devastated SmolÃ©nsk road. Nothing more
 54330	stupid than that could have been devised, or more disastrous for the
 54331	army, as the sequel showed. Had Napoleonâs aim been to destroy his army,
 54332	the most skillful strategist could hardly have devised any series
 54333	of actions that would so completely have accomplished that purpose,
 54334	independently of anything the Russian army might do.
 54335	
 54336	Napoleon, the man of genius, did this! But to say that he destroyed his
 54337	army because he wished to, or because he was very stupid, would be as
 54338	unjust as to say that he had brought his troops to Moscow because he
 54339	wished to and because he was very clever and a genius.
 54340	
 54341	In both cases his personal activity, having no more force than the
 54342	personal activity of any soldier, merely coincided with the laws that
 54343	guided the event.
 54344	
 54345	The historians quite falsely represent Napoleonâs faculties as having
 54346	weakened in Moscow, and do so only because the results did not justify
 54347	his actions. He employed all his ability and strength to do the best he
 54348	could for himself and his army, as he had done previously and as he did
 54349	subsequently in 1813. His activity at that time was no less astounding
 54350	than it was in Egypt, in Italy, in Austria, and in Prussia. We do not
 54351	know for certain in how far his genius was genuine in Egyptâwhere forty
 54352	centuries looked down upon his grandeurâfor his great exploits there are
 54353	all told us by Frenchmen. We cannot accurately estimate his genius in
 54354	Austria or Prussia, for we have to draw our information from French
 54355	or German sources, and the incomprehensible surrender of whole corps
 54356	without fighting and of fortresses without a siege must incline Germans
 54357	to recognize his genius as the only explanation of the war carried on
 54358	in Germany. But we, thank God, have no need to recognize his genius
 54359	in order to hide our shame. We have paid for the right to look at the
 54360	matter plainly and simply, and we will not abandon that right.
 54361	
 54362	His activity in Moscow was as amazing and as full of genius as
 54363	elsewhere. Order after order and plan after plan were issued by him
 54364	from the time he entered Moscow till the time he left it. The absence
 54365	of citizens and of a deputation, and even the burning of Moscow, did not
 54366	disconcert him. He did not lose sight either of the welfare of his
 54367	army or of the doings of the enemy, or of the welfare of the people
 54368	of Russia, or of the direction of affairs in Paris, or of diplomatic
 54369	considerations concerning the terms of the anticipated peace.
 54370	
 54371

 54375	CHAPTER IX
 54376	
 54377	With regard to military matters, Napoleon immediately on his entry into

 54399	With regard to administrative matters, Moscow was granted a
 54400	constitution. A municipality was established and the following

 54402	
 54403	
 54404	INHABITANTS OF MOSCOW!
 54405	
 54406	Your misfortunes are cruel, but His Majesty the Emperor and King
 54407	desires to arrest their course. Terrible examples have taught you how he
 54408	punishes disobedience and crime. Strict measures have been taken to

 54411	municipality or city government. It will take care of you, of your
 54412	needs, and of your welfare. Its members will be distinguished by a red
 54413	ribbon worn across the shoulder, and the mayor of the city will wear
 54414	a white belt as well. But when not on duty they will only wear a red
 54415	ribbon round the left arm.
 54416	
 54417	The city police is established on its former footing, and better order
 54418	already prevails in consequence of its activity. The government has
 54419	appointed two commissaries general, or chiefs of police, and twenty
 54420	commissaries or captains of wards have been appointed to the different
 54421	wards of the city. You will recognize them by the white ribbon they will

 54424	citizens are returning every day to their homes and orders have been

 54430	the hope of a less cruel fate, should be certain that inevitable and
 54431	ignominious death awaits those who make any attempt on your persons or

 54445	    * As looters.

 54526	But strange to say, all these measures, efforts, and plansâwhich were

 54628	That army, like a herd of cattle run wild and trampling underfoot the

 54632

 54639	
 54640	Fleeing from Moscow the soldiers took with them everything they had

 54649	
 54650	The plight of the whole army resembled that of a wounded animal which

 54659	reached him, turned back, and finallyâlike any wild beastâran back along

 54661	familiar.
 54662	
 54663	During the whole of that period Napoleon, who seems to us to have been

 54668	
 54669

 54672	CHAPTER XI
 54673	
 54674	Early in the morning of the sixth of October Pierre went out of the
 54675	shed, and on returning stopped by the door to play with a little
 54676	blue-gray dog, with a long body and short bandy legs, that jumped about
 54677	him. This little dog lived in their shed, sleeping beside KaratÃ¡ev at
 54678	night; it sometimes made excursions into the town but always returned
 54679	again. Probably it had never had an owner, and it still belonged to
 54680	nobody and had no name. The French called it Azor; the soldier who
 54681	told stories called it FemgÃ¡lka; KaratÃ¡ev and others called it Gray, or
 54682	sometimes Flabby. Its lack of a master, a name, or even of a breed or
 54683	any definite color did not seem to trouble the blue-gray dog in the
 54684	least. Its furry tail stood up firm and round as a plume, its bandy legs
 54685	served it so well that it would often gracefully lift a hind leg and run
 54686	very easily and quickly on three legs, as if disdaining to use all
 54687	four. Everything pleased it. Now it would roll on its back, yelping with
 54688	delight, now bask in the sun with a thoughtful air of importance, and
 54689	now frolic about playing with a chip of wood or a straw.
 54690	
 54691	Pierreâs attire by now consisted of a dirty torn shirt (the only

 54700	slackness which had shown itself even in his eyes was now replaced by an

 54702	
 54703	Pierre first looked down the field across which vehicles and horsemen
 54704	were passing that morning, then into the distance across the river, then

 54708	bare feet a smile of animated self-satisfaction flitted across his face.

 54712	For some days the weather had been calm and clear with slight frosts in

 54853	CHAPTER XII
 54854	
 54855	Four weeks had passed since Pierre had been taken prisoner and though
 54856	the French had offered to move him from the menâs to the officersâ shed,
 54857	he had stayed in the shed where he was first put.
 54858	
 54859	In burned and devastated Moscow Pierre experienced almost the extreme
 54860	limits of privation a man can endure; but thanks to his physical
 54861	strength and health, of which he had till then been unconscious, and
 54862	thanks especially to the fact that the privations came so gradually that
 54863	it was impossible to say when they began, he endured his position
 54864	not only lightly but joyfully. And just at this time he obtained the
 54865	tranquillity and ease of mind he had formerly striven in vain to reach.
 54866	He had long sought in different ways that tranquillity of mind, that
 54867	inner harmony which had so impressed him in the soldiers at the battle
 54868	of BorodinÃ³. He had sought it in philanthropy, in Freemasonry, in the
 54869	dissipations of town life, in wine, in heroic feats of self-sacrifice,
 54870	and in romantic love for NatÃ¡sha; he had sought it by reasoningâand all
 54871	these quests and experiments had failed him. And now without thinking
 54872	about it he had found that peace and inner harmony only through the
 54873	horror of death, through privation, and through what he recognized in
 54874	KaratÃ¡ev.
 54875	
 54876	Those dreadful moments he had lived through at the executions had as it
 54877	were forever washed away from his imagination and memory the agitating
 54878	thoughts and feelings that had formerly seemed so important. It did
 54879	not now occur to him to think of Russia, or the war, or politics, or
 54880	Napoleon. It was plain to him that all these things were no business
 54881	of his, and that he was not called on to judge concerning them and
 54882	therefore could not do so. âRussia and summer weather are not bound
 54883	together,â he thought, repeating words of KaratÃ¡evâs which he found
 54884	strangely consoling. His intention of killing Napoleon and his
 54885	calculations of the cabalistic number of the beast of the Apocalypse now
 54886	seemed to him meaningless and even ridiculous. His anger with his wife
 54887	and anxiety that his name should not be smirched now seemed not merely
 54888	trivial but even amusing. What concern was it of his that somewhere or
 54889	other that woman was leading the life she preferred? What did it matter
 54890	to anybody, and especially to him, whether or not they found out that
 54891	their prisonerâs name was Count BezÃºkhov?
 54892	
 54893	He now often remembered his conversation with Prince Andrew and quite
 54894	agreed with him, though he understood Prince Andrewâs thoughts somewhat
 54895	differently. Prince Andrew had thought and said that happiness could
 54896	only be negative, but had said it with a shade of bitterness and irony
 54897	as though he was really saying that all desire for positive happiness is
 54898	implanted in us merely to torment us and never be satisfied. But Pierre
 54899	believed it without any mental reservation. The absence of suffering,
 54900	the satisfaction of oneâs needs and consequent freedom in the choice of
 54901	oneâs occupation, that is, of oneâs way of life, now seemed to Pierre to
 54902	be indubitably manâs highest happiness. Here and now for the first time
 54903	he fully appreciated the enjoyment of eating when he wanted to eat,
 54904	drinking when he wanted to drink, sleeping when he wanted to sleep, of
 54905	warmth when he was cold, of talking to a fellow man when he wished to
 54906	talk and to hear a human voice. The satisfaction of oneâs needsâgood
 54907	food, cleanliness, and freedomânow that he was deprived of all this,
 54908	seemed to Pierre to constitute perfect happiness; and the choice
 54909	of occupation, that is, of his way of lifeânow that that was so
 54910	restrictedâseemed to him such an easy matter that he forgot that a
 54911	superfluity of the comforts of life destroys all joy in satisfying oneâs
 54912	needs, while great freedom in the choice of occupationâsuch freedom as
 54913	his wealth, his education, and his social position had given him in his
 54914	own lifeâis just what makes the choice of occupation insolubly difficult
 54915	and destroys the desire and possibility of having an occupation.
 54916	
 54917	All Pierreâs daydreams now turned on the time when he would be free. Yet
 54918	subsequently, and for the rest of his life, he thought and spoke with
 54919	enthusiasm of that month of captivity, of those irrecoverable, strong,
 54920	joyful sensations, and chiefly of the complete peace of mind and inner
 54921	freedom which he experienced only during those weeks.
 54922	
 54923	When on the first day he got up early, went out of the shed at dawn, and
 54924	saw the cupolas and crosses of the New Convent of the Virgin still dark

 54926	wooded banks above the winding river vanishing in the purple distance,

 54932	strength in life such as he had never before known. And this not only
 54933	stayed with him during the whole of his imprisonment, but even grew in
 54934	strength as the hardships of his position increased.
 54935	
 54936	That feeling of alertness and of readiness for anything was still
 54937	further strengthened in him by the high opinion his fellow prisoners
 54938	formed of him soon after his arrival at the shed. With his knowledge
 54939	of languages, the respect shown him by the French, his simplicity, his
 54940	readiness to give anything asked of him (he received the allowance

 54942	showed to the soldiers by pressing nails into the walls of the hut; his
 54943	gentleness to his companions, and his capacity for sitting still and
 54944	thinking without doing anything (which seemed to them incomprehensible),

 54946	qualities that had been a hindrance, if not actually harmful, to him in
 54947	the world he had lived inâhis strength, his disdain for the comforts of
 54948	life, his absent-mindedness and simplicityâhere among these people gave

 54950	placed responsibilities upon him.

 54957	
 54958	The French evacuation began on the night between the sixth and seventh

 54960	and baggage trains started.
 54961

 55640	
 55641	From the time he received this news to the end of the campaign all

 55648	
 55649	Everywhere KutÃºzov retreated, but the enemy without waiting for his
 55650	retreat fled in the opposite direction.
 55651	
 55652	Napoleonâs historians describe to us his skilled maneuvers at TarÃºtino
 55653	and MÃ¡lo-YaroslÃ¡vets, and make conjectures as to what would have

 55667

 55684	
 55685	But though they all realized that it was necessary to get away, there

 55700	
 55701	When les enfants du Don might so easily have taken the Emperor himself

 55708	
 55709	That Napoleon agreed with Mouton, and that the army retreated, does

 55718	CHAPTER XIX
 55719	
 55720	A man in motion always devises an aim for that motion. To be able to go
 55721	a thousand miles he must imagine that something good awaits him at the
 55722	end of those thousand miles. One must have the prospect of a promised
 55723	land to have the strength to move.
 55724	
 55725	The promised land for the French during their advance had been Moscow,
 55726	during their retreat it was their native land. But that native land
 55727	was too far off, and for a man going a thousand miles it is absolutely
 55728	necessary to set aside his final goal and to say to himself: âToday I
 55729	shall get to a place twenty-five miles off where I shall rest and
 55730	spend the night,â and during the first dayâs journey that resting place
 55731	eclipses his ultimate goal and attracts all his hopes and desires. And
 55732	the impulses felt by a single person are always magnified in a crowd.
 55733	
 55734	For the French retreating along the old SmolÃ©nsk road, the final
 55735	goalâtheir native landâwas too remote, and their immediate goal
 55736	was SmolÃ©nsk, toward which all their desires and hopes, enormously
 55737	intensified in the mass, urged them on. It was not that they knew that
 55738	much food and fresh troops awaited them in SmolÃ©nsk, nor that they were
 55739	told so (on the contrary their superior officers, and Napoleon himself,
 55740	knew that provisions were scarce there), but because this alone could
 55741	give them strength to move on and endure their present privations. So
 55742	both those who knew and those who did not know deceived themselves, and
 55743	pushed on to SmolÃ©nsk as to a promised land.
 55744	
 55745	Coming out onto the highroad the French fled with surprising energy
 55746	and unheard-of rapidity toward the goal they had fixed on. Besides the
 55747	common impulse which bound the whole crowd of French into one mass and
 55748	supplied them with a certain energy, there was another cause binding
 55749	them togetherâtheir great numbers. As with the physical law of gravity,
 55750	their enormous mass drew the individual human atoms to itself. In their
 55751	hundreds of thousands they moved like a whole nation.
 55752	
 55753	Each of them desired nothing more than to give himself up as a prisoner
 55754	to escape from all this horror and misery; but on the one hand the force
 55755	of this common attraction to SmolÃ©nsk, their goal, drew each of them in
 55756	the same direction; on the other hand an army corps could not surrender
 55757	to a company, and though the French availed themselves of every
 55758	convenient opportunity to detach themselves and to surrender on the
 55759	slightest decent pretext, such pretexts did not always occur. Their
 55760	very numbers and their crowded and swift movement deprived them of that
 55761	possibility and rendered it not only difficult but impossible for the
 55762	Russians to stop this movement, to which the French were directing all
 55763	their energies. Beyond a certain limit no mechanical disruption of the
 55764	body could hasten the process of decomposition.
 55765	
 55766	A lump of snow cannot be melted instantaneously. There is a certain
 55767	limit of time in less than which no amount of heat can melt the snow. On
 55768	the contrary the greater the heat the more solidified the remaining snow
 55769	becomes.
 55770	
 55771	Of the Russian commanders KutÃºzov alone understood this. When the flight
 55772	of the French army along the SmolÃ©nsk road became well defined, what
 55773	KonovnÃ­tsyn had foreseen on the night of the eleventh of October began
 55774	to occur. The superior officers all wanted to distinguish themselves,
 55775	to cut off, to seize, to capture, and to overthrow the French, and all
 55776	clamored for action.
 55777	
 55778	KutÃºzov alone used all his power (and such power is very limited in the
 55779	case of any commander in chief) to prevent an attack.
 55780	
 55781	He could not tell them what we say now: âWhy fight, why block the road,
 55782	losing our own men and inhumanly slaughtering unfortunate wretches? What
 55783	is the use of that, when a third of their army has melted away on the
 55784	road from Moscow to VyÃ¡zma without any battle?â But drawing from his
 55785	aged wisdom what they could understand, he told them of the golden

 55788	
 55789	ErmÃ³lov, MilorÃ¡dovich, PlÃ¡tov, and others in proximity to the French

 55793	
 55794	And try as KutÃºzov might to restrain the troops, our men attacked,
 55795	trying to bar the road. Infantry regiments, we are told, advanced to the
 55796	attack with music and with drums beating, and killed and lost thousands
 55797	of men.
 55798	
 55799	But they did not cut off or overthrow anybody and the French army,
 55800	closing up more firmly at the danger, continued, while steadily melting
