 55807	BOOK FOURTEEN: 1812
 55808	
 55809	
 55810	
 55811	
 55812	
 55813	CHAPTER I
 55814	
 55815	The Battle of BorodinÃ³, with the occupation of Moscow that followed it
 55816	and the flight of the French without further conflicts, is one of the
 55817	most instructive phenomena in history.
 55818	
 55819	All historians agree that the external activity of states and nations
 55820	in their conflicts with one another is expressed in wars, and that as a
 55821	direct result of greater or less success in war the political strength
 55822	of states and nations increases or decreases.
 55823	
 55824	Strange as may be the historical account of how some king or emperor,
 55825	having quarreled with another, collects an army, fights his enemyâs
 55826	army, gains a victory by killing three, five, or ten thousand men, and
 55827	subjugates a kingdom and an entire nation of several millions, all
 55828	the facts of history (as far as we know it) confirm the truth of the
 55829	statement that the greater or lesser success of one army against another
 55830	is the cause, or at least an essential indication, of an increase or
 55831	decrease in the strength of the nationâeven though it is unintelligible
 55832	why the defeat of an armyâa hundredth part of a nationâshould oblige
 55833	that whole nation to submit. An army gains a victory, and at once the
 55834	rights of the conquering nation have increased to the detriment of the
 55835	defeated. An army has suffered defeat, and at once a people loses its
 55836	rights in proportion to the severity of the reverse, and if its army
 55837	suffers a complete defeat the nation is quite subjugated.
 55838	
 55839	So according to history it has been found from the most ancient times,
 55840	and so it is to our own day. All Napoleonâs wars serve to confirm this
 55841	rule. In proportion to the defeat of the Austrian army Austria loses
 55842	its rights, and the rights and the strength of France increase. The
 55843	victories of the French at Jena and AuerstÃ¤dt destroy the independent
 55844	existence of Prussia.
 55845	
 55846	But then, in 1812, the French gain a victory near Moscow. Moscow is
 55847	taken and after that, with no further battles, it is not Russia that
 55848	ceases to exist, but the French army of six hundred thousand, and
 55849	then Napoleonic France itself. To strain the facts to fit the rules of
 55850	history: to say that the field of battle at BorodinÃ³ remained in the
 55851	hands of the Russians, or that after Moscow there were other battles
 55852	that destroyed Napoleonâs army, is impossible.
 55853	
 55854	After the French victory at BorodinÃ³ there was no general engagement nor
 55855	any that were at all serious, yet the French army ceased to exist. What
 55856	does this mean? If it were an example taken from the history of China,
 55857	we might say that it was not an historic phenomenon (which is the
 55858	historiansâ usual expedient when anything does not fit their standards);
 55859	if the matter concerned some brief conflict in which only a small number
 55860	of troops took part, we might treat it as an exception; but this event
 55861	occurred before our fathersâ eyes, and for them it was a question of the
 55862	life or death of their fatherland, and it happened in the greatest of
 55863	all known wars.
 55864	
 55865	The period of the campaign of 1812 from the battle of BorodinÃ³ to the
 55866	expulsion of the French proved that the winning of a battle does not
 55867	produce a conquest and is not even an invariable indication of conquest;
 55868	it proved that the force which decides the fate of peoples lies not in
 55869	the conquerors, nor even in armies and battles, but in something else.
 55870	
 55871	The French historians, describing the condition of the French army
 55872	before it left Moscow, affirm that all was in order in the Grand Army,
 55873	except the cavalry, the artillery, and the transportâthere was no forage
 55874	for the horses or the cattle. That was a misfortune no one could remedy,
 55875	for the peasants of the district burned their hay rather than let the
 55876	French have it.
 55877	
 55878	The victory gained did not bring the usual results because the peasants
 55879	Karp and Vlas (who after the French had evacuated Moscow drove in their
 55880	carts to pillage the town, and in general personally failed to manifest
 55881	any heroic feelings), and the whole innumerable multitude of such
 55882	peasants, did not bring their hay to Moscow for the high price offered
 55883	them, but burned it instead.
 55884	
 55885	Let us imagine two men who have come out to fight a duel with rapiers
 55886	according to all the rules of the art of fencing. The fencing has
 55887	gone on for some time; suddenly one of the combatants, feeling himself
 55888	wounded and understanding that the matter is no joke but concerns his
 55889	life, throws down his rapier, and seizing the first cudgel that comes to
 55890	hand begins to brandish it. Then let us imagine that the combatant who
 55891	so sensibly employed the best and simplest means to attain his end was
 55892	at the same time influenced by traditions of chivalry and, desiring to
 55893	conceal the facts of the case, insisted that he had gained his victory
 55894	with the rapier according to all the rules of art. One can imagine what
 55895	confusion and obscurity would result from such an account of the duel.
 55896	
 55897	The fencer who demanded a contest according to the rules of fencing was
 55898	the French army; his opponent who threw away the rapier and snatched up
 55899	the cudgel was the Russian people; those who try to explain the matter
 55900	according to the rules of fencing are the historians who have described
 55901	the event.
 55902	
 55903	After the burning of SmolÃ©nsk a war began which did not follow any
 55904	previous traditions of war. The burning of towns and villages, the
 55905	retreats after battles, the blow dealt at BorodinÃ³ and the renewed
 55906	retreat, the burning of Moscow, the capture of marauders, the seizure of
 55907	transports, and the guerrilla war were all departures from the rules.
 55908	
 55909	Napoleon felt this, and from the time he took up the correct fencing
 55910	attitude in Moscow and instead of his opponentâs rapier saw a cudgel
 55911	raised above his head, he did not cease to complain to KutÃºzov and to
 55912	the Emperor Alexander that the war was being carried on contrary to all
 55913	the rulesâas if there were any rules for killing people. In spite of the
 55914	complaints of the French as to the nonobservance of the rules, in
 55915	spite of the fact that to some highly placed Russians it seemed rather
 55916	disgraceful to fight with a cudgel and they wanted to assume a pose en
 55917	quarte or en tierce according to all the rules, and to make an adroit
 55918	thrust en prime, and so onâthe cudgel of the peopleâs war was lifted
 55919	with all its menacing and majestic strength, and without consulting
 55920	anyoneâs tastes or rules and regardless of anything else, it rose and
 55921	fell with stupid simplicity, but consistently, and belabored the French
 55922	till the whole invasion had perished.
 55923	
 55924	And it is well for a people who do notâas the French did in 1813âsalute
 55925	according to all the rules of art, and, presenting the hilt of their
 55926	rapier gracefully and politely, hand it to their magnanimous conqueror,
 55927	but at the moment of trial, without asking what rules others have
 55928	adopted in similar cases, simply and easily pick up the first cudgel
 55929	that comes to hand and strike with it till the feeling of resentment and
 55930	revenge in their soul yields to a feeling of contempt and compassion.
 55931	
 55932	
 55933	
 55934	
 55935	
 55936	CHAPTER II
 55937	
 55938	One of the most obvious and advantageous departures from the so-called
 55939	laws of war is the action of scattered groups against men pressed
 55940	together in a mass. Such action always occurs in wars that take on a
 55941	national character. In such actions, instead of two crowds opposing
 55942	each other, the men disperse, attack singly, run away when attacked by
 55943	stronger forces, but again attack when opportunity offers. This was done
 55944	by the guerrillas in Spain, by the mountain tribes in the Caucasus, and
 55945	by the Russians in 1812.
 55946	
 55947	People have called this kind of war âguerrilla warfareâ and assume that
 55948	by so calling it they have explained its meaning. But such a war does
 55949	not fit in under any rule and is directly opposed to a well-known rule
 55950	of tactics which is accepted as infallible. That rule says that an
 55951	attacker should concentrate his forces in order to be stronger than his
 55952	opponent at the moment of conflict.
 55953	
 55954	Guerrilla war (always successful, as history shows) directly infringes
 55955	that rule.
 55956	
 55957	This contradiction arises from the fact that military science assumes
 55958	the strength of an army to be identical with its numbers. Military
 55959	science says that the more troops the greater the strength. Les gros
 55960	bataillons ont toujours raison. *
 55961	
 55962	    * Large battalions are always victorious.
 55963	
 55964	For military science to say this is like defining momentum in mechanics
 55965	by reference to the mass only: stating that momenta are equal or unequal
 55966	to each other simply because the masses involved are equal or unequal.
 55967	
 55968	Momentum (quantity of motion) is the product of mass and velocity.
 55969	
 55970	In military affairs the strength of an army is the product of its mass
 55971	and some unknown x.
 55972	
 55973	Military science, seeing in history innumerable instances of the fact
 55974	that the size of any army does not coincide with its strength and that
 55975	small detachments defeat larger ones, obscurely admits the existence
 55976	of this unknown factor and tries to discover itânow in a geometric
 55977	formation, now in the equipment employed, now, and most usually, in the
 55978	genius of the commanders. But the assignment of these various meanings
 55979	to the factor does not yield results which accord with the historic
 55980	facts.
 55981	
 55982	Yet it is only necessary to abandon the false view (adopted to gratify
 55983	the âheroesâ) of the efficacy of the directions issued in wartime by
 55984	commanders, in order to find this unknown quantity.
 55985	
 55986	That unknown quantity is the spirit of the army, that is to say, the
 55987	greater or lesser readiness to fight and face danger felt by all the men
 55988	composing an army, quite independently of whether they are, or are not,
 55989	fighting under the command of a genius, in twoâor three-line formation,
 55990	with cudgels or with rifles that repeat thirty times a minute. Men
 55991	who want to fight will always put themselves in the most advantageous
 55992	conditions for fighting.
 55993	
 55994	The spirit of an army is the factor which multiplied by the mass gives
 55995	the resulting force. To define and express the significance of this
 55996	unknown factorâthe spirit of an armyâis a problem for science.
 55997	
 55998	This problem is only solvable if we cease arbitrarily to substitute
 55999	for the unknown x itself the conditions under which that force becomes
 56000	apparentâsuch as the commands of the general, the equipment employed,
 56001	and so onâmistaking these for the real significance of the factor,
 56002	and if we recognize this unknown quantity in its entirety as being
 56003	the greater or lesser desire to fight and to face danger. Only then,
 56004	expressing known historic facts by equations and comparing the relative
 56005	significance of this factor, can we hope to define the unknown.
 56006	
 56007	Ten men, battalions, or divisions, fighting fifteen men, battalions, or
 56008	divisions, conquerâthat is, kill or take captiveâall the others, while
 56009	themselves losing four, so that on the one side four and on the other
 56010	fifteen were lost. Consequently the four were equal to the fifteen, and
 56011	therefore 4x = 15y. Consequently x/y = 15/4. This equation does not
 56012	give us the value of the unknown factor but gives us a ratio between two
 56013	unknowns. And by bringing variously selected historic units (battles,
 56014	campaigns, periods of war) into such equations, a series of numbers
 56015	could be obtained in which certain laws should exist and might be
 56016	discovered.
 56017	
 56018	The tactical rule that an army should act in masses when attacking, and
 56019	in smaller groups in retreat, unconsciously confirms the truth that the
 56020	strength of an army depends on its spirit. To lead men forward under
 56021	fire more discipline (obtainable only by movement in masses) is needed
 56022	than is needed to resist attacks. But this rule which leaves out of
 56023	account the spirit of the army continually proves incorrect and is in
 56024	particularly striking contrast to the facts when some strong rise or
 56025	fall in the spirit of the troops occurs, as in all national wars.
 56026	
 56027	The French, retreating in 1812âthough according to tactics they should
 56028	have separated into detachments to defend themselvesâcongregated into
 56029	a mass because the spirit of the army had so fallen that only the mass
 56030	held the army together. The Russians, on the contrary, ought according
 56031	to tactics to have attacked in mass, but in fact they split up
 56032	into small units, because their spirit had so risen that separate
 56033	individuals, without orders, dealt blows at the French without needing
 56034	any compulsion to induce them to expose themselves to hardships and
 56035	dangers.
 56036	
 56037	
 56038	
 56039	
 56040	
 56041	CHAPTER III
 56042	
 56043	The so-called partisan war began with the entry of the French into
 56044	SmolÃ©nsk.
 56045	
 56046	Before partisan warfare had been officially recognized by the
 56047	government, thousands of enemy stragglers, marauders, and foragers had
 56048	been destroyed by the Cossacks and the peasants, who killed them off
 56049	as instinctively as dogs worry a stray mad dog to death. DenÃ­s DavÃ½dov,
 56050	with his Russian instinct, was the first to recognize the value of
 56051	this terrible cudgel which regardless of the rules of military science
 56052	destroyed the French, and to him belongs the credit for taking the first
 56053	step toward regularizing this method of warfare.
 56054	
 56055	On August 24 DavÃ½dovâs first partisan detachment was formed and then
 56056	others were recognized. The further the campaign progressed the more
 56057	numerous these detachments became.
 56058	
 56059	The irregulars destroyed the great army piecemeal. They gathered the
 56060	fallen leaves that dropped of themselves from that withered treeâthe
 56061	French armyâand sometimes shook that tree itself. By October, when
 56062	the French were fleeing toward SmolÃ©nsk, there were hundreds of such
 56063	companies, of various sizes and characters. There were some that adopted
 56064	all the army methods and had infantry, artillery, staffs, and the
 56065	comforts of life. Others consisted solely of Cossack cavalry. There were
 56066	also small scratch groups of foot and horse, and groups of peasants and
 56067	landowners that remained unknown. A sacristan commanded one party which
 56068	captured several hundred prisoners in the course of a month; and there
 56069	was VasÃ­lisa, the wife of a village elder, who slew hundreds of the
 56070	French.
 56071	
 56072	The partisan warfare flamed up most fiercely in the latter days of
 56073	October. Its first period had passed: when the partisans themselves,
 56074	amazed at their own boldness, feared every minute to be surrounded
 56075	and captured by the French, and hid in the forests without unsaddling,
 56076	hardly daring to dismount and always expecting to be pursued. By the end
 56077	of October this kind of warfare had taken definite shape: it had become
 56078	clear to all what could be ventured against the French and what could
 56079	not. Now only the commanders of detachments with staffs, and moving
 56080	according to rules at a distance from the French, still regarded many
 56081	things as impossible. The small bands that had started their activities
 56082	long before and had already observed the French closely considered
 56083	things possible which the commanders of the big detachments did not dare
 56084	to contemplate. The Cossacks and peasants who crept in among the French
 56085	now considered everything possible.
 56086	
 56087	On October 22, DenÃ­sov (who was one of the irregulars) was with his
 56088	group at the height of the guerrilla enthusiasm. Since early morning he

 57446	On the third day after leaving Moscow KaratÃ¡ev again fell ill with the

 57454	
 57455	While imprisoned in the shed Pierre had learned not with his intellect
 57456	but with his whole being, by life itself, that man is created for
 57457	happiness, that happiness is within him, in the satisfaction of simple
 57458	human needs, and that all unhappiness arises not from privation but from
 57459	superfluity. And now during these last three weeks of the march he had
 57460	learned still another new, consolatory truthâthat nothing in this world

 57462	can be happy and entirely free, so there is no condition in which he
 57463	need be unhappy and lack freedom. He learned that suffering and freedom
 57464	have their limits and that those limits are very near together; that the
 57465	person in a bed of roses with one crumpled petal suffered as keenly as
 57466	he now, sleeping on the bare damp earth with one side growing chilled
 57467	while the other was warming; and that when he had put on tight dancing
 57468	shoes he had suffered just as he did now when he walked with bare feet

 57475	was appetizing and nourishing, the saltpeter flavor of the gunpowder
 57476	they used instead of salt was even pleasant; there was no great cold,
 57477	it was always warm walking in the daytime, and at night there were the

 57479	that was at first hard to bear was his feet.
 57480	
 57481	After the second dayâs march Pierre, having examined his feet by the

 57487	
 57488	Only now did Pierre realize the full strength of life in man and the
 57489	saving power he has of transferring his attention from one thing

 57491	superfluous steam to blow off when the pressure exceeds a certain limit.
 57492

 57859	November 9: twenty miles from SmolÃ©nsk.
 57860	
 57861

 57866	They all went without knowing whither or why they were going. Still less

 57885	The movements of the Russian and French armies during the campaign

 57954	
 57955	This campaign consisted in a flight of the French during which they did
 57956	all they could to destroy themselves. From the time they turned onto

 58036	CHAPTER XIX
 58037	
 58038	What Russian, reading the account of the last part of the campaign
 58039	of 1812, has not experienced an uncomfortable feeling of regret,
 58040	dissatisfaction, and perplexity? Who has not asked himself how it is
 58041	that the French were not all captured or destroyed when our three armies
 58042	surrounded them in superior numbers, when the disordered French, hungry
 58043	and freezing, surrendered in crowds, and when (as the historians relate)
 58044	the aim of the Russians was to stop the French, to cut them off, and
 58045	capture them all?
 58046	
 58047	How was it that the Russian army, which when numerically weaker than the
 58048	French had given battle at BorodinÃ³, did not achieve its purpose when it
 58049	had surrounded the French on three sides and when its aim was to capture
 58050	them? Can the French be so enormously superior to us that when we had
 58051	surrounded them with superior forces we could not beat them? How could
 58052	that happen?
 58053	
 58054	History (or what is called by that name) replying to these questions
 58055	says that this occurred because KutÃºzov and TormÃ¡sov and ChichagÃ³v, and
 58056	this man and that man, did not execute such and such maneuvers....
 58057	
 58058	But why did they not execute those maneuvers? And why if they were
 58059	guilty of not carrying out a prearranged plan were they not tried and
 58060	punished? But even if we admitted that KutÃºzov, ChichagÃ³v, and others
 58061	were the cause of the Russian failures, it is still incomprehensible
 58062	why, the position of the Russian army being what it was at KrÃ¡snoe and
 58063	at the BerÃ«zina (in both cases we had superior forces), the French army
 58064	with its marshals, kings, and Emperor was not captured, if that was what
 58065	the Russians aimed at.
 58066	
 58067	The explanation of this strange fact given by Russian military
 58068	historians (to the effect that KutÃºzov hindered an attack) is unfounded,
 58069	for we know that he could not restrain the troops from attacking at
 58070	VyÃ¡zma and TarÃºtino.
 58071	
 58072	Why was the Russian armyâwhich with inferior forces had withstood the
 58073	enemy in full strength at BorodinÃ³âdefeated at KrÃ¡snoe and the BerÃ«zina
 58074	by the disorganized crowds of the French when it was numerically
 58075	superior?
 58076	
 58077	If the aim of the Russians consisted in cutting off and capturing
 58078	Napoleon and his marshalsâand that aim was not merely frustrated but all
 58079	attempts to attain it were most shamefully baffledâthen this last period
 58080	of the campaign is quite rightly considered by the French to be a
 58081	series of victories, and quite wrongly considered victorious by Russian
 58082	historians.
 58083	
 58084	The Russian military historians in so far as they submit to claims
 58085	of logic must admit that conclusion, and in spite of their lyrical
 58086	rhapsodies about valor, devotion, and so forth, must reluctantly admit
 58087	that the French retreat from Moscow was a series of victories for
 58088	Napoleon and defeats for KutÃºzov.
 58089	
 58090	But putting national vanity entirely aside one feels that such a
 58091	conclusion involves a contradiction, since the series of French
 58092	victories brought the French complete destruction, while the series
 58093	of Russian defeats led to the total destruction of their enemy and the
 58094	liberation of their country.
 58095	
 58096	The source of this contradiction lies in the fact that the historians
 58097	studying the events from the letters of the sovereigns and the generals,
 58098	from memoirs, reports, projects, and so forth, have attributed to this
 58099	last period of the war of 1812 an aim that never existed, namely that of
 58100	cutting off and capturing Napoleon with his marshals and his army.
 58101	
 58102	There never was or could have been such an aim, for it would have been
 58103	senseless and its attainment quite impossible.
 58104	
 58105	It would have been senseless, first because Napoleonâs disorganized
 58106	army was flying from Russia with all possible speed, that is to say, was
 58107	doing just what every Russian desired. So what was the use of performing
 58108	various operations on the French who were running away as fast as they
 58109	possibly could?
 58110	
 58111	Secondly, it would have been senseless to block the passage of men whose
 58112	whole energy was directed to flight.
 58113	
 58114	Thirdly, it would have been senseless to sacrifice oneâs own troops in
 58115	order to destroy the French army, which without external interference
 58116	was destroying itself at such a rate that, though its path was not
 58117	blocked, it could not carry across the frontier more than it actually
 58118	did in December, namely a hundredth part of the original army.
 58119	
 58120	Fourthly, it would have been senseless to wish to take captive the
 58121	Emperor, kings, and dukesâwhose capture would have been in the highest
 58122	degree embarrassing for the Russians, as the most adroit diplomatists of
 58123	the time (Joseph de Maistre and others) recognized. Still more senseless
 58124	would have been the wish to capture army corps of the French, when our
 58125	own army had melted away to half before reaching KrÃ¡snoe and a whole
 58126	division would have been needed to convoy the corps of prisoners, and
 58127	when our men were not always getting full rations and the prisoners
 58128	already taken were perishing of hunger.
 58129	
 58130	All the profound plans about cutting off and capturing Napoleon and his
 58131	army were like the plan of a market gardener who, when driving out of
 58132	his garden a cow that had trampled down the beds he had planted, should
 58133	run to the gate and hit the cow on the head. The only thing to be said
 58134	in excuse of that gardener would be that he was very angry. But not even
 58135	that could be said for those who drew up this project, for it was not
 58136	they who had suffered from the trampled beds.
 58137	
 58138	But besides the fact that cutting off Napoleon with his army would have
 58139	been senseless, it was impossible.
 58140	
 58141	It was impossible first becauseâas experience shows that a three-mile
 58142	movement of columns on a battlefield never coincides with the plansâthe
 58143	probability of ChichagÃ³v, KutÃºzov, and Wittgenstein effecting a junction
 58144	on time at an appointed place was so remote as to be tantamount to
 58145	impossibility, as in fact thought KutÃºzov, who when he received the plan
 58146	remarked that diversions planned over great distances do not yield the

 58148	
 58149	Secondly it was impossible, because to paralyze the momentum with which
 58150	Napoleonâs army was retiring, incomparably greater forces than the
 58151	Russians possessed would have been required.
 58152	
 58153	Thirdly it was impossible, because the military term âto cut offâ has no
 58154	meaning. One can cut off a slice of bread, but not an army. To cut off
 58155	an armyâto bar its roadâis quite impossible, for there is always plenty
 58156	of room to avoid capture and there is the night when nothing can be
 58157	seen, as the military scientists might convince themselves by the
 58158	example of KrÃ¡snoe and of the BerÃ«zina. It is only possible to capture
 58159	prisoners if they agree to be captured, just as it is only possible
 58160	to catch a swallow if it settles on oneâs hand. Men can only be taken
 58161	prisoners if they surrender according to the rules of strategy and
 58162	tactics, as the Germans did. But the French troops quite rightly did not
 58163	consider that this suited them, since death by hunger and cold awaited
 58164	them in flight or captivity alike.
 58165	
 58166	Fourthly and chiefly it was impossible, because never since the world
 58167	began has a war been fought under such conditions as those that obtained
 58168	in 1812, and the Russian army in its pursuit of the French strained its
 58169	strength to the utmost and could not have done more without destroying
 58170	itself.
 58171	
 58172	During the movement of the Russian army from TarÃºtino to KrÃ¡snoe it
 58173	lost fifty thousand sick or stragglers, that is a number equal to the
 58174	population of a large provincial town. Half the men fell out of the army
 58175	without a battle.
 58176	
 58177	And it is of this period of the campaignâwhen the army lacked boots
 58178	and sheepskin coats, was short of provisions and without vodka, and
 58179	was camping out at night for months in the snow with fifteen degrees
 58180	of frost, when there were only seven or eight hours of daylight and
 58181	the rest was night in which the influence of discipline cannot be
 58182	maintained, when men were taken into that region of death where
 58183	discipline fails, not for a few hours only as in a battle, but for
 58184	months, where they were every moment fighting death from hunger and
 58185	cold, when half the army perished in a single monthâit is of this period
 58186	of the campaign that the historians tell us how MilorÃ¡dovich should have
 58187	made a flank march to such and such a place, TormÃ¡sov to another place,

 58190	so on and so on.
 58191	
 58192	The Russians, half of whom died, did all that could and should have been
 58193	done to attain an end worthy of the nation, and they are not to blame
 58194	because other Russians, sitting in warm rooms, proposed that they should
 58195	do what was impossible.
 58196	
 58197	All that strange contradiction now difficult to understand between the
 58198	facts and the historical accounts only arises because the historians
 58199	dealing with the matter have written the history of the beautiful words
 58200	and sentiments of various generals, and not the history of the events.
 58201	
 58202	To them the words of MilorÃ¡dovich seem very interesting, and so do their
 58203	surmises and the rewards this or that general received; but the question
 58204	of those fifty thousand men who were left in hospitals and in graves
 58205	does not even interest them, for it does not come within the range of
 58206	their investigation.
 58207	
 58208	Yet one need only discard the study of the reports and general plans and
 58209	consider the movement of those hundreds of thousands of men who took a
 58210	direct part in the events, and all the questions that seemed insoluble
 58211	easily and simply receive an immediate and certain solution.
 58212	
 58213	The aim of cutting off Napoleon and his army never existed except in
 58214	the imaginations of a dozen people. It could not exist because it was
 58215	senseless and unattainable.
 58216	
 58217	The people had a single aim: to free their land from invasion. That aim
 58218	was attained in the first place of itself, as the French ran away,
 58219	and so it was only necessary not to stop their flight. Secondly it was
 58220	attained by the guerrilla warfare which was destroying the French, and
 58221	thirdly by the fact that a large Russian army was following the French,
 58222	ready to use its strength in case their movement stopped.
 58223	
 58224	The Russian army had to act like a whip to a running animal. And the
 58225	experienced driver knew it was better to hold the whip raised as a
 58226	menace than to strike the running animal on the head.

 58238	CHAPTER I
 58239	
 58240	When seeing a dying animal a man feels a sense of horror: substance
 58241	similar to his own is perishing before his eyes. But when it is a
 58242	beloved and intimate human being that is dying, besides this horror at
 58243	the extinction of life there is a severance, a spiritual wound, which
 58244	like a physical wound is sometimes fatal and sometimes heals, but always
 58245	aches and shrinks at any external irritating touch.
 58246	
 58247	After Prince Andrewâs death NatÃ¡sha and Princess Mary alike felt this.
 58248	Drooping in spirit and closing their eyes before the menacing cloud of
 58249	death that overhung them, they dared not look life in the face. They
 58250	carefully guarded their open wounds from any rough and painful contact.
 58251	Everything: a carriage passing rapidly in the street, a summons to
 58252	dinner, the maidâs inquiry what dress to prepare, or worse still any
 58253	word of insincere or feeble sympathy, seemed an insult, painfully
 58254	irritated the wound, interrupting that necessary quiet in which
 58255	they both tried to listen to the stern and dreadful choir that still
 58256	resounded in their imagination, and hindered their gazing into those
 58257	mysterious limitless vistas that for an instant had opened out before
 58258	them.
 58259	
 58260	Only when alone together were they free from such outrage and pain.
 58261	They spoke little even to one another, and when they did it was of very
 58262	unimportant matters.
 58263	
 58264	Both avoided any allusion to the future. To admit the possibility of
 58265	a future seemed to them to insult his memory. Still more carefully did
 58266	they avoid anything relating to him who was dead. It seemed to them that
 58267	what they had lived through and experienced could not be expressed in
 58268	words, and that any reference to the details of his life infringed the
 58269	majesty and sacredness of the mystery that had been accomplished before
 58270	their eyes.
 58271	
 58272	Continued abstention from speech, and constant avoidance of everything
 58273	that might lead up to the subjectâthis halting on all sides at the
 58274	boundary of what they might not mentionâbrought before their minds with
 58275	still greater purity and clearness what they were both feeling.
 58276	
 58277	But pure and complete sorrow is as impossible as pure and complete joy.
 58278	Princess Mary, in her position as absolute and independent arbiter of
 58279	her own fate and guardian and instructor of her nephew, was the first to
 58280	be called back to life from that realm of sorrow in which she had dwelt
 58281	for the first fortnight. She received letters from her relations to
 58282	which she had to reply; the room in which little Nicholas had been put
 58283	was damp and he began to cough; AlpÃ¡tych came to YaroslÃ¡vl with reports
 58284	on the state of their affairs and with advice and suggestions that they
 58285	should return to Moscow to the house on the VozdvÃ­zhenka Street, which
 58286	had remained uninjured and needed only slight repairs. Life did not
 58287	stand still and it was necessary to live. Hard as it was for Princess
 58288	Mary to emerge from the realm of secluded contemplation in which she
 58289	had lived till then, and sorry and almost ashamed as she felt to leave
 58290	NatÃ¡sha alone, yet the cares of life demanded her attention and she
 58291	involuntarily yielded to them. She went through the accounts with
 58292	AlpÃ¡tych, conferred with Dessalles about her nephew, and gave orders and
 58293	made preparations for the journey to Moscow.
 58294	
 58295	NatÃ¡sha remained alone and, from the time Princess Mary began making
 58296	preparations for departure, held aloof from her too.
 58297	
 58298	Princess Mary asked the countess to let NatÃ¡sha go with her to Moscow,
 58299	and both parents gladly accepted this offer, for they saw their daughter
 58300	losing strength every day and thought that a change of scene and the
 58301	advice of Moscow doctors would be good for her.
 58302	
 58303	âI am not going anywhere,â NatÃ¡sha replied when this was proposed to
 58304	her. âDo please just leave me alone!â And she ran out of the room, with
 58305	difficulty refraining from tears of vexation and irritation rather than
 58306	of sorrow.
 58307	
 58308	After she felt herself deserted by Princes Mary and alone in her grief,
 58309	NatÃ¡sha spent most of the time in her room by herself, sitting huddled
 58310	up feet and all in the corner of the sofa, tearing and twisting
 58311	something with her slender nervous fingers and gazing intently and
 58312	fixedly at whatever her eyes chanced to fall on. This solitude exhausted
 58313	and tormented her but she was in absolute need of it. As soon as anyone
 58314	entered she got up quickly, changed her position and expression, and
 58315	picked up a book or some sewing, evidently waiting impatiently for the
 58316	intruder to go.
 58317	
 58318	She felt all the time as if she might at any moment penetrate that
 58319	on whichâwith a terrible questioning too great for her strengthâher
 58320	spiritual gaze was fixed.
 58321	
 58322	One day toward the end of December NatÃ¡sha, pale and thin, dressed in a
 58323	black woolen gown, her plaited hair negligently twisted into a knot, was
 58324	crouched feet and all in the corner of her sofa, nervously crumpling and
 58325	smoothing out the end of her sash while she looked at a corner of the

 58890

 60074	CHAPTER XIV
 60075	
 60076	It would be difficult to explain why and whither ants whose heap
 60077	has been destroyed are hurrying: some from the heap dragging bits of
 60078	rubbish, larvae, and corpses, others back to the heap, or why they
 60079	jostle, overtake one another, and fight, and it would be equally
 60080	difficult to explain what caused the Russians after the departure of the
 60081	French to throng to the place that had formerly been Moscow. But when
 60082	we watch the ants round their ruined heap, the tenacity, energy, and
 60083	immense number of the delving insects prove that despite the destruction
 60084	of the heap, something indestructible, which though intangible is the
 60085	real strength of the colony, still exists; and similarly, though in
 60086	Moscow in the month of October there was no government and no churches,
 60087	shrines, riches, or housesâit was still the Moscow it had been in
 60088	August. All was destroyed, except something intangible yet powerful and
 60089	indestructible.
 60090	
 60091	The motives of those who thronged from all sides to Moscow after it had
 60092	been cleared of the enemy were most diverse and personal, and at first
 60093	for the most part savage and brutal. One motive only they all had in
 60094	common: a desire to get to the place that had been called Moscow, to
 60095	apply their activities there.
 60096	
 60097	Within a week Moscow already had fifteen thousand inhabitants, in a
 60098	fortnight twenty-five thousand, and so on. By the autumn of 1813 the
 60099	number, ever increasing and increasing, exceeded what it had been in
 60100	1812.
 60101	
 60102	The first Russians to enter Moscow were the Cossacks of Wintzingerodeâs
 60103	detachment, peasants from the adjacent villages, and residents who had
 60104	fled from Moscow and had been hiding in its vicinity. The Russians who
 60105	entered Moscow, finding it plundered, plundered it in their turn. They
 60106	continued what the French had begun. Trains of peasant carts came to
 60107	Moscow to carry off to the villages what had been abandoned in the
 60108	ruined houses and the streets. The Cossacks carried off what they could
 60109	to their camps, and the householders seized all they could find in other
 60110	houses and moved it to their own, pretending that it was their property.
 60111	
 60112	But the first plunderers were followed by a second and a third
 60113	contingent, and with increasing numbers plundering became more and more
 60114	difficult and assumed more definite forms.
 60115	
 60116	The French found Moscow abandoned but with all the organizations of
 60117	regular life, with diverse branches of commerce and craftsmanship, with
 60118	luxury, and governmental and religious institutions. These forms were

 60120	market stalls, granariesâfor the most part still stocked with goodsâand
 60121	there were factories and workshops, palaces and wealthy houses filled

 60123	cathedrals. The longer the French remained the more these forms of town
 60124	life perished, until finally all was merged into one confused, lifeless
 60125	scene of plunder.
 60126	
 60127	The more the plundering by the French continued, the more both the
 60128	wealth of Moscow and the strength of its plunderers was destroyed. But
 60129	plundering by the Russians, with which the reoccupation of the city
 60130	began, had an opposite effect: the longer it continued and the greater
 60131	the number of people taking part in it the more rapidly was the wealth
 60132	of the city and its regular life restored.
 60133	
 60134	Besides the plunderers, very various people, some drawn by curiosity,

 60136	officials of all kinds, tradesmen, artisans, and peasantsâstreamed into

 60138	
 60139	Within a week the peasants who came with empty carts to carry off

 60142	discomfiture, came to town bringing rye, oats, and hay, and beat down
 60143	one anotherâs prices to below what they had been in former days. Gangs

 60145	all sides logs were being hewn, new houses built, and old, charred ones

 60148	in many churches that had not been burned. Donors contributed
 60149	Church property that had been stolen. Government clerks set up their
 60150	baize-covered tables and their pigeonholes of documents in small rooms.
 60151	The higher authorities and the police organized the distribution of

 61078	CHAPTER I
 61079	
 61080	Seven years had passed. The storm-tossed sea of European history had
 61081	subsided within its shores and seemed to have become calm. But the
 61082	mysterious forces that move humanity (mysterious because the laws of
 61083	their motion are unknown to us) continued to operate.
 61084	
 61085	Though the surface of the sea of history seemed motionless, the movement
 61086	of humanity went on as unceasingly as the flow of time. Various groups
 61087	of people formed and dissolved, the coming formation and dissolution of
 61088	kingdoms and displacement of peoples was in course of preparation.
 61089	
 61090	The sea of history was not driven spasmodically from shore to shore as
 61091	previously. It was seething in its depths. Historic figures were not
 61092	borne by the waves from one shore to another as before. They now seemed
 61093	to rotate on one spot. The historical figures at the head of armies,
 61094	who formerly reflected the movement of the masses by ordering wars,
 61095	campaigns, and battles, now reflected the restless movement by political
 61096	and diplomatic combinations, laws, and treaties.
 61097	
 61098	The historians call this activity of the historical figures âthe
 61099	reaction.â
 61100	
 61101	In dealing with this period they sternly condemn the historical
 61102	personages who, in their opinion, caused what they describe as the
 61103	reaction. All the well-known people of that period, from Alexander and
 61104	Napoleon to Madame de StaÃ«l, Photius, Schelling, Fichte, Chateaubriand,
 61105	and the rest, pass before their stern judgment seat and are acquitted or
 61106	condemned according to whether they conduced to progress or to reaction.
 61107	
 61108	According to their accounts a reaction took place at that time in Russia
 61109	also, and the chief culprit was Alexander I, the same man who according
 61110	to them was the chief cause of the liberal movement at the commencement
 61111	of his reign, being the savior of Russia.
 61112	
 61113	There is no one in Russian literature now, from schoolboy essayist to
 61114	learned historian, who does not throw his little stone at Alexander for
 61115	things he did wrong at this period of his reign.
 61116	
 61117	âHe ought to have acted in this way and in that way. In this case he did
 61118	well and in that case badly. He behaved admirably at the beginning of
 61119	his reign and during 1812, but acted badly by giving a constitution
 61120	to Poland, forming the Holy Alliance, entrusting power to ArakchÃ©ev,
 61121	favoring GolÃ­tsyn and mysticism, and afterwards ShishkÃ³v and Photius.
 61122	He also acted badly by concerning himself with the active army and
 61123	disbanding the SemÃ«nov regiment.â
 61124	
 61125	It would take a dozen pages to enumerate all the reproaches the
 61126	historians address to him, based on their knowledge of what is good for
 61127	humanity.
 61128	
 61129	What do these reproaches mean?
 61130	
 61131	Do not the very actions for which the historians praise Alexander I
 61132	(the liberal attempts at the beginning of his reign, his struggle with
 61133	Napoleon, the firmness he displayed in 1812 and the campaign of 1813)
 61134	flow from the same sourcesâthe circumstances of his birth, education,
 61135	and lifeâthat made his personality what it was and from which the
 61136	actions for which they blame him (the Holy Alliance, the restoration of
 61137	Poland, and the reaction of 1820 and later) also flowed?
 61138	
 61139	In what does the substance of those reproaches lie?
 61140	
 61141	It lies in the fact that an historic character like Alexander I,
 61142	standing on the highest possible pinnacle of human power with the
 61143	blinding light of history focused upon him; a character exposed to those
 61144	strongest of all influences: the intrigues, flattery, and self-deception
 61145	inseparable from power; a character who at every moment of his life
 61146	felt a responsibility for all that was happening in Europe; and not
 61147	a fictitious but a live character who like every man had his personal
 61148	habits, passions, and impulses toward goodness, beauty, and truthâthat
 61149	this characterâthough not lacking in virtue (the historians do not
 61150	accuse him of that)âhad not the same conception of the welfare of
 61151	humanity fifty years ago as a present-day professor who from his
 61152	youth upwards has been occupied with learning: that is, with books and
 61153	lectures and with taking notes from them.
 61154	
 61155	But even if we assume that fifty years ago Alexander I was mistaken in
 61156	his view of what was good for the people, we must inevitably assume that
 61157	the historian who judges Alexander will also after the lapse of some
 61158	time turn out to be mistaken in his view of what is good for humanity.
 61159	This assumption is all the more natural and inevitable because, watching
 61160	the movement of history, we see that every year and with each new
 61161	writer, opinion as to what is good for mankind changes; so that what
 61162	once seemed good, ten years later seems bad, and vice versa. And what is
 61163	more, we find at one and the same time quite contradictory views as to
 61164	what is bad and what is good in history: some people regard giving a
 61165	constitution to Poland and forming the Holy Alliance as praiseworthy in
 61166	Alexander, while others regard it as blameworthy.
 61167	
 61168	The activity of Alexander or of Napoleon cannot be called useful or
 61169	harmful, for it is impossible to say for what it was useful or harmful.
 61170	If that activity displeases somebody, this is only because it does
 61171	not agree with his limited understanding of what is good. Whether the
 61172	preservation of my fatherâs house in Moscow, or the glory of the Russian
 61173	arms, or the prosperity of the Petersburg and other universities, or the
 61174	freedom of Poland or the greatness of Russia, or the balance of power in
 61175	Europe, or a certain kind of European culture called âprogressâ appear
 61176	to me to be good or bad, I must admit that besides these things the
 61177	action of every historic character has other more general purposes
 61178	inaccessible to me.
 61179	
 61180	But let us assume that what is called science can harmonize all
 61181	contradictions and possesses an unchanging standard of good and bad by
 61182	which to try historic characters and events; let us say that Alexander
 61183	could have done everything differently; let us say that with guidance
 61184	from those who blame him and who profess to know the ultimate aim of the
 61185	movement of humanity, he might have arranged matters according to
 61186	the program his present accusers would have given himâof nationality,
 61187	freedom, equality, and progress (these, I think, cover the ground). Let
 61188	us assume that this program was possible and had then been formulated,
 61189	and that Alexander had acted on it. What would then have become of the
 61190	activity of all those who opposed the tendency that then prevailed in
 61191	the governmentâan activity that in the opinion of the historians was
 61192	good and beneficent? Their activity would not have existed: there would
 61193	have been no life, there would have been nothing.
 61194	
 61195	If we admit that human life can be ruled by reason, the possibility of
 61196	life is destroyed.
 61197	
 61198	
 61199	
 61200	
 61201	
 61202	CHAPTER II
 61203	
 61204	If we assume as the historians do that great men lead humanity to the
 61205	attainment of certain endsâthe greatness of Russia or of France,
 61206	the balance of power in Europe, the diffusion of the ideas of the
 61207	Revolution, general progress, or anything elseâthen it is impossible
 61208	to explain the facts of history without introducing the conceptions of
 61209	chance and genius.
 61210	
 61211	If the aim of the European wars at the beginning of the nineteenth
 61212	century had been the aggrandizement of Russia, that aim might have been
 61213	accomplished without all the preceding wars and without the invasion. If
 61214	the aim was the aggrandizement of France, that might have been attained
 61215	without the Revolution and without the Empire. If the aim was the
 61216	dissemination of ideas, the printing press could have accomplished that
 61217	much better than warfare. If the aim was the progress of civilization,
 61218	it is easy to see that there are other ways of diffusing civilization
 61219	more expedient than by the destruction of wealth and of human lives.
 61220	
 61221	Why did it happen in this and not in some other way?
 61222	
 61223	Because it happened so! âChance created the situation; genius utilized
 61224	it,â says history.
 61225	
 61226	But what is chance? What is genius?
 61227	
 61228	The words chance and genius do not denote any really existing thing and
 61229	therefore cannot be defined. Those words only denote a certain stage of
 61230	understanding of phenomena. I do not know why a certain event occurs; I
 61231	think that I cannot know it; so I do not try to know it and I talk about
 61232	chance. I see a force producing effects beyond the scope of ordinary
 61233	human agencies; I do not understand why this occurs and I talk of
 61234	genius.
 61235	
 61236	To a herd of rams, the ram the herdsman drives each evening into a
 61237	special enclosure to feed and that becomes twice as fat as the others
 61238	must seem to be a genius. And it must appear an astonishing conjunction
 61239	of genius with a whole series of extraordinary chances that this ram,
 61240	who instead of getting into the general fold every evening goes into a
 61241	special enclosure where there are oatsâthat this very ram, swelling with
 61242	fat, is killed for meat.
 61243	
 61244	But the rams need only cease to suppose that all that happens to them
 61245	happens solely for the attainment of their sheepish aims; they need only
 61246	admit that what happens to them may also have purposes beyond their ken,
 61247	and they will at once perceive a unity and coherence in what happened
 61248	to the ram that was fattened. Even if they do not know for what purpose
 61249	they are fattened, they will at least know that all that happened to the
 61250	ram did not happen accidentally, and will no longer need the conceptions
 61251	of chance or genius.
 61252	
 61253	Only by renouncing our claim to discern a purpose immediately
 61254	intelligible to us, and admitting the ultimate purpose to be beyond our
 61255	ken, may we discern the sequence of experiences in the lives of
 61256	historic characters and perceive the cause of the effect they produce
 61257	(incommensurable with ordinary human capabilities), and then the words
 61258	chance and genius become superfluous.
 61259	
 61260	We need only confess that we do not know the purpose of the European
 61261	convulsions and that we know only the factsâthat is, the murders, first
 61262	in France, then in Italy, in Africa, in Prussia, in Austria, in Spain,
 61263	and in Russiaâand that the movements from the west to the east and from
 61264	the east to the west form the essence and purpose of these events, and
 61265	not only shall we have no need to see exceptional ability and genius in
 61266	Napoleon and Alexander, but we shall be unable to consider them to
 61267	be anything but like other men, and we shall not be obliged to have
 61268	recourse to chance for an explanation of those small events which made
 61269	these people what they were, but it will be clear that all those small
 61270	events were inevitable.
 61271	
 61272	By discarding a claim to knowledge of the ultimate purpose, we shall
 61273	clearly perceive that just as one cannot imagine a blossom or seed for
 61274	any single plant better suited to it than those it produces, so it is
 61275	impossible to imagine any two people more completely adapted down to the
 61276	smallest detail for the purpose they had to fulfill, than Napoleon and
 61277	Alexander with all their antecedents.
 61278	
 61279

 61282	
 61283	CHAPTER III
 61284	
 61285	The fundamental and essential significance of the European events of the
 61286	beginning of the nineteenth century lies in the movement of the mass of
 61287	the European peoples from west to east and afterwards from east to west.
 61288	The commencement of that movement was the movement from west to east.
 61289	For the peoples of the west to be able to make their warlike movement
 61290	to Moscow it was necessary: (1) that they should form themselves into
 61291	a military group of a size able to endure a collision with the warlike
 61292	military group of the east, (2) that they should abandon all established
 61293	traditions and customs, and (3) that during their military movement they
 61294	should have at their head a man who could justify to himself and to them
 61295	the deceptions, robberies, and murders which would have to be committed
 61296	during that movement.
 61297	
 61298	And beginning with the French Revolution the old inadequately large
 61299	group was destroyed, as well as the old habits and traditions, and step
 61300	by step a group was formed of larger dimensions with new customs and
 61301	traditions, and a man was produced who would stand at the head of the
 61302	coming movement and bear the responsibility for all that had to be done.
 61303	
 61304	A man without convictions, without habits, without traditions, without
 61305	a name, and not even a Frenchman, emergesâby what seem the strangest
 61306	chancesâfrom among all the seething French parties, and without joining
 61307	any one of them is borne forward to a prominent position.
 61308	
 61309	The ignorance of his colleagues, the weakness and insignificance of
 61310	his opponents, the frankness of his falsehoods, and the dazzling and
 61311	self-confident limitations of this man raise him to the head of the
 61312	army. The brilliant qualities of the soldiers of the army sent to Italy,
 61313	his opponentsâ reluctance to fight, and his own childish audacity and
 61314	self-confidence secure him military fame. Innumerable so-called chances
 61315	accompany him everywhere. The disfavor into which he falls with the
 61316	rulers of France turns to his advantage. His attempts to avoid his
 61317	predestined path are unsuccessful: he is not received into the Russian
 61318	service, and the appointment he seeks in Turkey comes to nothing. During
 61319	the war in Italy he is several times on the verge of destruction and
 61320	each time is saved in an unexpected manner. Owing to various diplomatic
 61321	considerations the Russian armiesâjust those which might have destroyed
 61322	his prestigeâdo not appear upon the scene till he is no longer there.
 61323	
 61324	On his return from Italy he finds the government in Paris in a process
 61325	of dissolution in which all those who are in it are inevitably wiped
 61326	out and destroyed. And by chance an escape from this dangerous position
 61327	presents itself in the form of an aimless and senseless expedition
 61328	to Africa. Again so-called chance accompanies him. Impregnable Malta
 61329	surrenders without a shot; his most reckless schemes are crowned with
 61330	success. The enemyâs fleet, which subsequently did not let a single boat
 61331	pass, allows his entire army to elude it. In Africa a whole series of
 61332	outrages are committed against the almost unarmed inhabitants. And the
 61333	men who commit these crimes, especially their leader, assure themselves
 61334	that this is admirable, this is gloryâit resembles Caesar and Alexander
 61335	the Great and is therefore good.
 61336	
 61337	This ideal of glory and grandeurâwhich consists not merely in
 61338	considering nothing wrong that one does but in priding oneself on every
 61339	crime one commits, ascribing to it an incomprehensible supernatural
 61340	significanceâthat ideal, destined to guide this man and his associates,
 61341	had scope for its development in Africa. Whatever he does succeeds. The
 61342	plague does not touch him. The cruelty of murdering prisoners is not
 61343	imputed to him as a fault. His childishly rash, uncalled-for, and
 61344	ignoble departure from Africa, leaving his comrades in distress, is
 61345	set down to his credit, and again the enemyâs fleet twice lets him slip
 61346	past. When, intoxicated by the crimes he has committed so successfully,
 61347	he reaches Paris, the dissolution of the republican government, which a
 61348	year earlier might have ruined him, has reached its extreme limit, and
 61349	his presence there now as a newcomer free from party entanglements can
 61350	only serve to exalt himâand though he himself has no plan, he is quite
 61351	ready for his new rÃ´le.
 61352	
 61353	He had no plan, he was afraid of everything, but the parties snatched at
 61354	him and demanded his participation.
 61355	
 61356	He aloneâwith his ideal of glory and grandeur developed in Italy and
 61357	Egypt, his insane self-adulation, his boldness in crime and frankness in
 61358	lyingâhe alone could justify what had to be done.
 61359	
 61360	He is needed for the place that awaits him, and so almost apart from
 61361	his will and despite his indecision, his lack of a plan, and all his
 61362	mistakes, he is drawn into a conspiracy that aims at seizing power and
 61363	the conspiracy is crowned with success.
 61364	
 61365	He is pushed into a meeting of the legislature. In alarm he wishes to
 61366	flee, considering himself lost. He pretends to fall into a swoon and
 61367	says senseless things that should have ruined him. But the once proud
 61368	and shrewd rulers of France, feeling that their part is played out, are
 61369	even more bewildered than he, and do not say the words they should have
 61370	said to destroy him and retain their power.
 61371	
 61372	Chance, millions of chances, give him power, and all men as if by
 61373	agreement co-operate to confirm that power. Chance forms the characters
 61374	of the rulers of France, who submit to him; chance forms the character
 61375	of Paul I of Russia who recognizes his government; chance contrives
 61376	a plot against him which not only fails to harm him but confirms his
 61377	power. Chance puts the Duc dâEnghien in his hands and unexpectedly
 61378	causes him to kill himâthereby convincing the mob more forcibly than
 61379	in any other way that he had the right, since he had the might.
 61380	Chance contrives that though he directs all his efforts to prepare an
 61381	expedition against England (which would inevitably have ruined him) he
 61382	never carries out that intention, but unexpectedly falls upon Mack and
 61383	the Austrians, who surrender without a battle. Chance and genius give
 61384	him the victory at Austerlitz; and by chance all men, not only the
 61385	French but all Europeâexcept England which does not take part in the
 61386	events about to happenâdespite their former horror and detestation of
 61387	his crimes, now recognize his authority, the title he has given
 61388	himself, and his ideal of grandeur and glory, which seems excellent and
 61389	reasonable to them all.
 61390	
 61391	As if measuring themselves and preparing for the coming movement, the
 61392	western forces push toward the east several times in 1805, 1806, 1807,
 61393	and 1809, gaining strength and growing. In 1811 the group of people that
 61394	had formed in France unites into one group with the peoples of Central
 61395	Europe. The strength of the justification of the man who stands at the
 61396	head of the movement grows with the increased size of the group. During
 61397	the ten-year preparatory period this man had formed relations with all
 61398	the crowned heads of Europe. The discredited rulers of the world can
 61399	oppose no reasonable ideal to the insensate Napoleonic ideal of
 61400	glory and grandeur. One after another they hasten to display their
 61401	insignificance before him. The King of Prussia sends his wife to seek
 61402	the great manâs mercy; the Emperor of Austria considers it a favor that
 61403	this man receives a daughter of the Caesars into his bed; the Pope, the
 61404	guardian of all that the nations hold sacred, utilizes religion for the
 61405	aggrandizement of the great man. It is not Napoleon who prepares himself
 61406	for the accomplishment of his role, so much as all those round him who
 61407	prepare him to take on himself the whole responsibility for what is
 61408	happening and has to happen. There is no step, no crime or petty fraud
 61409	he commits, which in the mouths of those around him is not at once
 61410	represented as a great deed. The most suitable fÃªte the Germans can
 61411	devise for him is a celebration of Jena and AuerstÃ¤dt. Not only is he
 61412	great, but so are his ancestors, his brothers, his stepsons, and his
 61413	brothers-in-law. Everything is done to deprive him of the remains of his
 61414	reason and to prepare him for his terrible part. And when he is ready so
 61415	too are the forces.
 61416	
 61417	The invasion pushes eastward and reaches its final goalâMoscow. That
 61418	city is taken; the Russian army suffers heavier losses than the opposing
 61419	armies had suffered in the former war from Austerlitz to Wagram. But
 61420	suddenly instead of those chances and that genius which hitherto had
 61421	so consistently led him by an uninterrupted series of successes to the
 61422	predestined goal, an innumerable sequence of inverse chances occurâfrom
 61423	the cold in his head at BorodinÃ³ to the sparks which set Moscow on
 61424	fire, and the frostsâand instead of genius, stupidity and immeasurable
 61425	baseness become evident.
 61426	
 61427	The invaders flee, turn back, flee again, and all the chances are now
 61428	not for Napoleon but always against him.
 61429	
 61430	A countermovement is then accomplished from east to west with a
 61431	remarkable resemblance to the preceding movement from west to east.
 61432	Attempted drives from east to westâsimilar to the contrary movements of
 61433	1805, 1807, and 1809âprecede the great westward movement; there is the
 61434	same coalescence into a group of enormous dimensions; the same adhesion
 61435	of the people of Central Europe to the movement; the same hesitation
 61436	midway, and the same increasing rapidity as the goal is approached.
 61437	
 61438	Paris, the ultimate goal, is reached. The Napoleonic government and army
 61439	are destroyed. Napoleon himself is no longer of any account; all his
 61440	actions are evidently pitiful and mean, but again an inexplicable chance
 61441	occurs. The allies detest Napoleon whom they regard as the cause of
 61442	their sufferings. Deprived of power and authority, his crimes and his
 61443	craft exposed, he should have appeared to them what he appeared ten
 61444	years previously and one year laterâan outlawed brigand. But by some
 61445	strange chance no one perceives this. His part is not yet ended. The man
 61446	who ten years before and a year later was considered an outlawed brigand
 61447	is sent to an island two daysâ sail from France, which for some reason
 61448	is presented to him as his dominion, and guards are given to him and
 61449	millions of money are paid him.
 61450	
 61451	
 61452	
 61453	
 61454	
 61455	CHAPTER IV
 61456	
 61457	The flood of nations begins to subside into its normal channels. The
 61458	waves of the great movement abate, and on the calm surface eddies are
 61459	formed in which float the diplomatists, who imagine that they have
 61460	caused the floods to abate.
 61461	
 61462	But the smooth sea again suddenly becomes disturbed. The diplomatists
 61463	think that their disagreements are the cause of this fresh pressure
 61464	of natural forces; they anticipate war between their sovereigns; the
 61465	position seems to them insoluble. But the wave they feel to be rising
 61466	does not come from the quarter they expect. It rises again from the same
 61467	point as beforeâParis. The last backwash of the movement from the west
 61468	occurs: a backwash which serves to solve the apparently insuperable
 61469	diplomatic difficulties and ends the military movement of that period of
 61470	history.
 61471	
 61472	The man who had devastated France returns to France alone, without any
 61473	conspiracy and without soldiers. Any guard might arrest him, but by
 61474	strange chance no one does so and all rapturously greet the man they
 61475	cursed the day before and will curse again a month later.
 61476	
 61477	This man is still needed to justify the final collective act.
 61478	
 61479	That act is performed.
 61480	
 61481	The last rÃ´le is played. The actor is bidden to disrobe and wash off his
 61482	powder and paint: he will not be wanted any more.
 61483	
 61484	And some years pass during which he plays a pitiful comedy to himself
 61485	in solitude on his island, justifying his actions by intrigues and lies
 61486	when the justification is no longer needed, and displaying to the whole
 61487	world what it was that people had mistaken for strength as long as an
 61488	unseen hand directed his actions.
 61489	
 61490	The manager having brought the drama to a close and stripped the actor
 61491	shows him to us.
 61492	
 61493	âSee what you believed in! This is he! Do you now see that it was not he
 61494	but I who moved you?â
 61495	
 61496	But dazed by the force of the movement, it was long before people
 61497	understood this.
 61498	
 61499	Still greater coherence and inevitability is seen in the life of
 61500	Alexander I, the man who stood at the head of the countermovement from
 61501	east to west.
 61502	
 61503	What was needed for him who, overshadowing others, stood at the head of
 61504	that movement from east to west?
 61505	
 61506	What was needed was a sense of justice and a sympathy with European
 61507	affairs, but a remote sympathy not dulled by petty interests; a moral
 61508	superiority over those sovereigns of the day who co-operated with him;
 61509	a mild and attractive personality; and a personal grievance against
 61510	Napoleon. And all this was found in Alexander I; all this had been
 61511	prepared by innumerable so-called chances in his life: his education,
 61512	his early liberalism, the advisers who surrounded him, and by
 61513	Austerlitz, and Tilsit, and Erfurt.
 61514	
 61515	During the national war he was inactive because he was not needed. But
 61516	as soon as the necessity for a general European war presented itself he
 61517	appeared in his place at the given moment and, uniting the nations of
 61518	Europe, led them to the goal.
 61519	
 61520	The goal is reached. After the final war of 1815 Alexander possesses all
 61521	possible power. How does he use it?
 61522	
 61523	Alexander Iâthe pacifier of Europe, the man who from his early years
 61524	had striven only for his peopleâs welfare, the originator of the liberal
 61525	innovations in his fatherlandânow that he seemed to possess the utmost
 61526	power and therefore to have the possibility of bringing about the
 61527	welfare of his peoplesâat the time when Napoleon in exile was drawing
 61528	up childish and mendacious plans of how he would have made mankind happy
 61529	had he retained powerâAlexander I, having fulfilled his mission and
 61530	feeling the hand of God upon him, suddenly recognizes the insignificance
 61531	of that supposed power, turns away from it, and gives it into the hands
 61532	of contemptible men whom he despises, saying only:
 61533	
 61534	âNot unto us, not unto us, but unto Thy Name!... I too am a man like the
 61535	rest of you. Let me live like a man and think of my soul and of God.â
 61536	
 61537	As the sun and each atom of ether is a sphere complete in itself, and
 61538	yet at the same time only a part of a whole too immense for man to
 61539	comprehend, so each individual has within himself his own aims and yet
 61540	has them to serve a general purpose incomprehensible to man.
 61541	
 61542	A bee settling on a flower has stung a child. And the child is afraid
 61543	of bees and declares that bees exist to sting people. A poet admires the
 61544	bee sucking from the chalice of a flower and says it exists to suck the
 61545	fragrance of flowers. A beekeeper, seeing the bee collect pollen from
 61546	flowers and carry it to the hive, says that it exists to gather honey.
 61547	Another beekeeper who has studied the life of the hive more closely
 61548	says that the bee gathers pollen dust to feed the young bees and rear
 61549	a queen, and that it exists to perpetuate its race. A botanist notices
 61550	that the bee flying with the pollen of a male flower to a pistil
 61551	fertilizes the latter, and sees in this the purpose of the beeâs
 61552	existence. Another, observing the migration of plants, notices that the
 61553	bee helps in this work, and may say that in this lies the purpose of the
 61554	bee. But the ultimate purpose of the bee is not exhausted by the first,
 61555	the second, or any of the processes the human mind can discern. The
 61556	higher the human intellect rises in the discovery of these purposes,
 61557	the more obvious it becomes, that the ultimate purpose is beyond our
 61558	comprehension.
 61559	
 61560	All that is accessible to man is the relation of the life of the bee to
 61561	other manifestations of life. And so it is with the purpose of historic
 61562	characters and nations.
 61563	
 61564	
 61565

 61895	CHAPTER VII
 61896	
 61897	In the winter of 1813 Nicholas married Princess Mary and moved to Bald

 61899	
 61900	Within four years he had paid off all his remaining debts without

 61907	
 61908	Having started farming from necessity, he soon grew so devoted to it
 61909	that it became his favorite and almost his sole occupation. Nicholas was
 61910	a plain farmer: he did not like innovations, especially the English ones
 61911	then coming into vogue. He laughed at theoretical treatises on estate
 61912	management, disliked factories, the raising of expensive products,
 61913	and the buying of expensive seed corn, and did not make a hobby of any
 61914	particular part of the work on his estate. He always had before his
 61915	mindâs eye the estate as a whole and not any particular part of it. The
 61916	chief thing in his eyes was not the nitrogen in the soil, nor the oxygen

 61918	agent by which nitrogen, oxygen, manure, and plow were made

 61920	and began to understand its different branches, it was the serf who
 61921	especially attracted his attention. The peasant seemed to him not merely
 61922	a tool, but also a judge of farming and an end in himself. At first
 61923	he watched the serfs, trying to understand their aims and what they
 61924	considered good and bad, and only pretended to direct them and give
 61925	orders while in reality learning from them their methods, their manner
 61926	of speech, and their judgment of what was good and bad. Only when he

 61931	produced very brilliant results.
 61932	
 61933	Guided by some gift of insight, on taking up the management of the

 61941	the family groups to divide into separate households. He was hard alike

 61944	
 61945	He was as careful of the sowing and reaping of the peasantsâ hay

 61950	He disliked having anything to do with the domestic serfsâthe âdronesâ

 61958	
 61959	He did not allow himself either to be hard on or punish a man, or to

 63790	
 63791	SECOND EPILOGUE
 63792	
 63793	
 63794	
 63795	
 63796	
 63797	CHAPTER I
 63798	
 63799	History is the life of nations and of humanity. To seize and put into
 63800	words, to describe directly the life of humanity or even of a single
 63801	nation, appears impossible.
 63802	
 63803	The ancient historians all employed one and the same method to describe
 63804	and seize the apparently elusiveâthe life of a people. They described
 63805	the activity of individuals who ruled the people, and regarded the
 63806	activity of those men as representing the activity of the whole nation.
 63807	
 63808	The question: how did individuals make nations act as they wished and by
 63809	what was the will of these individuals themselves guided? the ancients
 63810	met by recognizing a divinity which subjected the nations to the will of
 63811	a chosen man, and guided the will of that chosen man so as to accomplish
 63812	ends that were predestined.
 63813	
 63814	For the ancients these questions were solved by a belief in the direct
 63815	participation of the Deity in human affairs.
 63816	
 63817	Modern history, in theory, rejects both these principles.
 63818	
 63819	It would seem that having rejected the belief of the ancients in manâs
 63820	subjection to the Deity and in a predetermined aim toward which nations
 63821	are led, modern history should study not the manifestations of power but
 63822	the causes that produce it. But modern history has not done this. Having
 63823	in theory rejected the view held by the ancients, it still follows them
 63824	in practice.
 63825	
 63826	Instead of men endowed with divine authority and directly guided by
 63827	the will of God, modern history has given us either heroes endowed with
 63828	extraordinary, superhuman capacities, or simply men of very various
 63829	kinds, from monarchs to journalists, who lead the masses. Instead of the
 63830	former divinely appointed aims of the Jewish, Greek, or Roman nations,
 63831	which ancient historians regarded as representing the progress of
 63832	humanity, modern history has postulated its own aimsâthe welfare of the
 63833	French, German, or English people, or, in its highest abstraction, the
 63834	welfare and civilization of humanity in general, by which is usually
 63835	meant that of the peoples occupying a small northwesterly portion of a
 63836	large continent.
 63837	
 63838	Modern history has rejected the beliefs of the ancients without
 63839	replacing them by a new conception, and the logic of the situation has
 63840	obliged the historians, after they had apparently rejected the divine
 63841	authority of the kings and the âfateâ of the ancients, to reach the same
 63842	conclusion by another road, that is, to recognize (1) nations guided
 63843	by individual men, and (2) the existence of a known aim to which these
 63844	nations and humanity at large are tending.
 63845	
 63846	At the basis of the works of all the modern historians from Gibbon to
 63847	Buckle, despite their seeming disagreements and the apparent novelty of
 63848	their outlooks, lie those two old, unavoidable assumptions.
 63849	
 63850	In the first place the historian describes the activity of individuals
 63851	who in his opinion have directed humanity (one historian considers
 63852	only monarchs, generals, and ministers as being such men, while another
 63853	includes also orators, learned men, reformers, philosophers, and poets).
 63854	Secondly, it is assumed that the goal toward which humanity is being led
 63855	is known to the historians: to one of them this goal is the greatness of
 63856	the Roman, Spanish, or French realm; to another it is liberty, equality,
 63857	and a certain kind of civilization of a small corner of the world called
 63858	Europe.
 63859	
 63860	In 1789 a ferment arises in Paris; it grows, spreads, and is expressed
 63861	by a movement of peoples from west to east. Several times it moves
 63862	eastward and collides with a countermovement from the east westward.
 63863	In 1812 it reaches its extreme limit, Moscow, and then, with remarkable
 63864	symmetry, a countermovement occurs from east to west, attracting to
 63865	it, as the first movement had done, the nations of middle Europe. The
 63866	counter movement reaches the starting point of the first movement in the
 63867	westâParisâand subsides.
 63868	
 63869	During that twenty-year period an immense number of fields were left
 63870	untilled, houses were burned, trade changed its direction, millions
 63871	of men migrated, were impoverished, or were enriched, and millions
 63872	of Christian men professing the law of love of their fellows slew one
 63873	another.
 63874	
 63875	What does all this mean? Why did it happen? What made those people burn
 63876	houses and slay their fellow men? What were the causes of these events?
 63877	What force made men act so? These are the instinctive, plain, and
 63878	most legitimate questions humanity asks itself when it encounters the
 63879	monuments and tradition of that period.
 63880	
 63881	For a reply to these questions the common sense of mankind turns to the
 63882	science of history, whose aim is to enable nations and humanity to know
 63883	themselves.
 63884	
 63885	If history had retained the conception of the ancients it would have
 63886	said that God, to reward or punish his people, gave Napoleon power and
 63887	directed his will to the fulfillment of the divine ends, and that reply
 63888	would have been clear and complete. One might believe or disbelieve
 63889	in the divine significance of Napoleon, but for anyone believing in
 63890	it there would have been nothing unintelligible in the history of that
 63891	period, nor would there have been any contradictions.
 63892	
 63893	But modern history cannot give that reply. Science does not admit the
 63894	conception of the ancients as to the direct participation of the Deity
 63895	in human affairs, and therefore history ought to give other answers.
 63896	
 63897	Modern history replying to these questions says: you want to know what
 63898	this movement means, what caused it, and what force produced these
 63899	events? Then listen:
 63900	
 63901	âLouis XIV was a very proud and self-confident man; he had such and such
 63902	mistresses and such and such ministers and he ruled France badly. His
 63903	descendants were weak men and they too ruled France badly. And they had
 63904	such and such favorites and such and such mistresses. Moreover, certain
 63905	men wrote some books at that time. At the end of the eighteenth century
 63906	there were a couple of dozen men in Paris who began to talk about all
 63907	men being free and equal. This caused people all over France to begin
 63908	to slash at and drown one another. They killed the king and many other
 63909	people. At that time there was in France a man of geniusâNapoleon. He
 63910	conquered everybody everywhereâthat is, he killed many people because
 63911	he was a great genius. And for some reason he went to kill Africans, and
 63912	killed them so well and was so cunning and wise that when he returned to
 63913	France he ordered everybody to obey him, and they all obeyed him. Having
 63914	become an Emperor he again went out to kill people in Italy, Austria,
 63915	and Prussia. And there too he killed a great many. In Russia there
 63916	was an Emperor, Alexander, who decided to restore order in Europe and
 63917	therefore fought against Napoleon. In 1807 he suddenly made friends
 63918	with him, but in 1811 they again quarreled and again began killing many
 63919	people. Napoleon led six hundred thousand men into Russia and captured
 63920	Moscow; then he suddenly ran away from Moscow, and the Emperor
 63921	Alexander, helped by the advice of Stein and others, united Europe to
 63922	arm against the disturber of its peace. All Napoleonâs allies suddenly
