 63923	became his enemies and their forces advanced against the fresh forces he
 63924	raised. The Allies defeated Napoleon, entered Paris, forced Napoleon to
 63925	abdicate, and sent him to the island of Elba, not depriving him of the
 63926	title of Emperor and showing him every respect, though five years before
 63927	and one year later they all regarded him as an outlaw and a brigand.
 63928	Then Louis XVIII, who till then had been the laughingstock both of the
 63929	French and the Allies, began to reign. And Napoleon, shedding tears
 63930	before his Old Guards, renounced the throne and went into exile. Then
 63931	the skillful statesmen and diplomatists (especially Talleyrand, who
 63932	managed to sit down in a particular chair before anyone else and
 63933	thereby extended the frontiers of France) talked in Vienna and by
 63934	these conversations made the nations happy or unhappy. Suddenly the
 63935	diplomatists and monarchs nearly quarreled and were on the point of
 63936	again ordering their armies to kill one another, but just then Napoleon
 63937	arrived in France with a battalion, and the French, who had been hating
 63938	him, immediately all submitted to him. But the Allied monarchs were
 63939	angry at this and went to fight the French once more. And they defeated
 63940	the genius Napoleon and, suddenly recognizing him as a brigand, sent him
 63941	to the island of St. Helena. And the exile, separated from the beloved
 63942	France so dear to his heart, died a lingering death on that rock and
 63943	bequeathed his great deeds to posterity. But in Europe a reaction
 63944	occurred and the sovereigns once again all began to oppress their
 63945	subjects.â
 63946	
 63947	It would be a mistake to think that this is ironicâa caricature of the
 63948	historical accounts. On the contrary it is a very mild expression of
 63949	the contradictory replies, not meeting the questions, which all the
 63950	historians give, from the compilers of memoirs and the histories
 63951	of separate states to the writers of general histories and the new
 63952	histories of the culture of that period.
 63953	
 63954	The strangeness and absurdity of these replies arise from the fact that
 63955	modern history, like a deaf man, answers questions no one has asked.
 63956	
 63957	If the purpose of history be to give a description of the movement of
 63958	humanity and of the peoples, the first questionâin the absence of a
 63959	reply to which all the rest will be incomprehensibleâis: what is the
 63960	power that moves peoples? To this, modern history laboriously replies
 63961	either that Napoleon was a great genius, or that Louis XIV was very
 63962	proud, or that certain writers wrote certain books.
 63963	
 63964	All that may be so and mankind is ready to agree with it, but it is not
 63965	what was asked. All that would be interesting if we recognized a divine
 63966	power based on itself and always consistently directing its nations
 63967	through Napoleons, Louis-es, and writers; but we do not acknowledge such
 63968	a power, and therefore before speaking about Napoleons, Louis-es, and
 63969	authors, we ought to be shown the connection existing between these men
 63970	and the movement of the nations.
 63971	
 63972	If instead of a divine power some other force has appeared, it should
 63973	be explained in what this new force consists, for the whole interest of
 63974	history lies precisely in that force.
 63975	
 63976	History seems to assume that this force is self-evident and known to
 63977	everyone. But in spite of every desire to regard it as known, anyone
 63978	reading many historical works cannot help doubting whether this new
 63979	force, so variously understood by the historians themselves, is really
 63980	quite well known to everybody.
 63981	
 63982	
 63983	
 63984	
 63985	
 63986	CHAPTER II
 63987	
 63988	What force moves the nations?
 63989	
 63990	Biographical historians and historians of separate nations understand
 63991	this force as a power inherent in heroes and rulers. In their narration
 63992	events occur solely by the will of a Napoleon, and Alexander, or in
 63993	general of the persons they describe. The answers given by this kind
 63994	of historian to the question of what force causes events to happen are
 63995	satisfactory only as long as there is but one historian to each event.
 63996	As soon as historians of different nationalities and tendencies begin
 63997	to describe the same event, the replies they give immediately lose all
 63998	meaning, for this force is understood by them all not only differently
 63999	but often in quite contradictory ways. One historian says that an
 64000	event was produced by Napoleonâs power, another that it was produced by
 64001	Alexanderâs, a third that it was due to the power of some other person.
 64002	Besides this, historians of that kind contradict each other even
 64003	in their statement as to the force on which the authority of some
 64004	particular person was based. Thiers, a Bonapartist, says that Napoleonâs
 64005	power was based on his virtue and genius. Lanfrey, a Republican, says it
 64006	was based on his trickery and deception of the people. So the historians
 64007	of this class, by mutually destroying one anotherâs positions, destroy
 64008	the understanding of the force which produces events, and furnish no
 64009	reply to historyâs essential question.
 64010	
 64011	Writers of universal history who deal with all the nations seem to
 64012	recognize how erroneous is the specialist historiansâ view of the force
 64013	which produces events. They do not recognize it as a power inherent in
 64014	heroes and rulers, but as the resultant of a multiplicity of variously
 64015	directed forces. In describing a war or the subjugation of a people, a
 64016	general historian looks for the cause of the event not in the power
 64017	of one man, but in the interaction of many persons connected with the
 64018	event.
 64019	
 64020	According to this view the power of historical personages, represented
 64021	as the product of many forces, can no longer, it would seem, be regarded
 64022	as a force that itself produces events. Yet in most cases universal
 64023	historians still employ the conception of power as a force that itself
 64024	produces events, and treat it as their cause. In their exposition, an
 64025	historic character is first the product of his time, and his power only
 64026	the resultant of various forces, and then his power is itself a force
 64027	producing events. Gervinus, Schlosser, and others, for instance, at one
 64028	time prove Napoleon to be a product of the Revolution, of the ideas of
 64029	1789 and so forth, and at another plainly say that the campaign of 1812
 64030	and other things they do not like were simply the product of Napoleonâs
 64031	misdirected will, and that the very ideas of 1789 were arrested in their
 64032	development by Napoleonâs caprice. The ideas of the Revolution and the
 64033	general temper of the age produced Napoleonâs power. But Napoleonâs
 64034	power suppressed the ideas of the Revolution and the general temper of
 64035	the age.
 64036	
 64037	This curious contradiction is not accidental. Not only does it occur at
 64038	every step, but the universal historiansâ accounts are all made up of
 64039	a chain of such contradictions. This contradiction occurs because after
 64040	entering the field of analysis the universal historians stop halfway.
 64041	
 64042	To find component forces equal to the composite or resultant force, the
 64043	sum of the components must equal the resultant. This condition is never
 64044	observed by the universal historians, and so to explain the resultant
 64045	forces they are obliged to admit, in addition to the insufficient
 64046	components, another unexplained force affecting the resultant action.
 64047	
 64048	Specialist historians describing the campaign of 1813 or the restoration
 64049	of the Bourbons plainly assert that these events were produced by the
 64050	will of Alexander. But the universal historian Gervinus, refuting this
 64051	opinion of the specialist historian, tries to prove that the campaign of
 64052	1813 and the restoration of the Bourbons were due to other things beside
 64053	Alexanderâs willâsuch as the activity of Stein, Metternich, Madame de
 64054	StaÃ«l, Talleyrand, Fichte, Chateaubriand, and others. The historian
 64055	evidently decomposes Alexanderâs power into the components: Talleyrand,
 64056	Chateaubriand, and the restâbut the sum of the components, that is,
 64057	the interactions of Chateaubriand, Talleyrand, Madame de StaÃ«l, and the
 64058	others, evidently does not equal the resultant, namely the phenomenon
 64059	of millions of Frenchmen submitting to the Bourbons. That Chateaubriand,
 64060	Madame de StaÃ«l, and others spoke certain words to one another only
 64061	affected their mutual relations but does not account for the submission
 64062	of millions. And therefore to explain how from these relations of theirs
 64063	the submission of millions of people resultedâthat is, how component
 64064	forces equal to one A gave a resultant equal to a thousand times Aâthe
 64065	historian is again obliged to fall back on powerâthe force he had
 64066	deniedâand to recognize it as the resultant of the forces, that is, he
 64067	has to admit an unexplained force acting on the resultant. And that is
 64068	just what the universal historians do, and consequently they not only
 64069	contradict the specialist historians but contradict themselves.
 64070	
 64071	Peasants having no clear idea of the cause of rain, say, according to
 64072	whether they want rain or fine weather: âThe wind has blown the clouds
 64073	away,â or, âThe wind has brought up the clouds.â And in the same way the
 64074	universal historians sometimes, when it pleases them and fits in with
 64075	their theory, say that power is the result of events, and sometimes,
 64076	when they want to prove something else, say that power produces events.
 64077	
 64078	A third class of historiansâthe so-called historians of
 64079	cultureâfollowing the path laid down by the universal historians who
 64080	sometimes accept writers and ladies as forces producing eventsâagain
 64081	take that force to be something quite different. They see it in what is
 64082	called cultureâin mental activity.
 64083	
 64084	The historians of culture are quite consistent in regard to their
 64085	progenitors, the writers of universal histories, for if historical
 64086	events may be explained by the fact that certain persons treated one
 64087	another in such and such ways, why not explain them by the fact that
 64088	such and such people wrote such and such books? Of the immense number of
 64089	indications accompanying every vital phenomenon, these historians select
 64090	the indication of intellectual activity and say that this indication is
 64091	the cause. But despite their endeavors to prove that the cause of events
 64092	lies in intellectual activity, only by a great stretch can one admit
 64093	that there is any connection between intellectual activity and the
 64094	movement of peoples, and in no case can one admit that intellectual
 64095	activity controls peopleâs actions, for that view is not confirmed by
 64096	such facts as the very cruel murders of the French Revolution resulting
 64097	from the doctrine of the equality of man, or the very cruel wars and
 64098	executions resulting from the preaching of love.
 64099	
 64100	But even admitting as correct all the cunningly devised arguments with
 64101	which these histories are filledâadmitting that nations are governed by
 64102	some undefined force called an ideaâhistoryâs essential question still
 64103	remains unanswered, and to the former power of monarchs and to the
 64104	influence of advisers and other people introduced by the universal
 64105	historians, another, newer forceâthe ideaâis added, the connection of
 64106	which with the masses needs explanation. It is possible to understand
 64107	that Napoleon had power and so events occurred; with some effort one may
 64108	even conceive that Napoleon together with other influences was the cause
 64109	of an event; but how a book, Le Contrat Social, had the effect of making
 64110	Frenchmen begin to drown one another cannot be understood without an
 64111	explanation of the causal nexus of this new force with the event.
 64112	
 64113	Undoubtedly some relation exists between all who live contemporaneously,
 64114	and so it is possible to find some connection between the intellectual
 64115	activity of men and their historical movements, just as such a
 64116	connection may be found between the movements of humanity and commerce,
 64117	handicraft, gardening, or anything else you please. But why intellectual
 64118	activity is considered by the historians of culture to be the cause or
 64119	expression of the whole historical movement is hard to understand.
 64120	Only the following considerations can have led the historians to such
 64121	a conclusion: (1) that history is written by learned men, and so it is
 64122	natural and agreeable for them to think that the activity of their class
 64123	supplies the basis of the movement of all humanity, just as a similar
 64124	belief is natural and agreeable to traders, agriculturists, and soldiers
 64125	(if they do not express it, that is merely because traders and soldiers
 64126	do not write history), and (2) that spiritual activity, enlightenment,
 64127	civilization, culture, ideas, are all indistinct, indefinite conceptions
 64128	under whose banner it is very easy to use words having a still less
 64129	definite meaning, and which can therefore be readily introduced into any
 64130	theory.
 64131	
 64132	But not to speak of the intrinsic quality of histories of this kind
 64133	(which may possibly even be of use to someone for something) the
 64134	histories of culture, to which all general histories tend more and more
 64135	to approximate, are significant from the fact that after seriously
 64136	and minutely examining various religious, philosophic, and political
 64137	doctrines as causes of events, as soon as they have to describe an
 64138	actual historic event such as the campaign of 1812 for instance, they
 64139	involuntarily describe it as resulting from an exercise of powerâand say
 64140	plainly that that was the result of Napoleonâs will. Speaking so, the
 64141	historians of culture involuntarily contradict themselves, and show that
 64142	the new force they have devised does not account for what happens in
 64143	history, and that history can only be explained by introducing a power
 64144	which they apparently do not recognize.
 64145	
 64146	
 64147	
 64148	
 64149	
 64150	CHAPTER III
 64151	
 64152	A locomotive is moving. Someone asks: âWhat moves it?â A peasant says
 64153	the devil moves it. Another man says the locomotive moves because its
 64154	wheels go round. A third asserts that the cause of its movement lies in
 64155	the smoke which the wind carries away.
 64156	
 64157	The peasant is irrefutable. He has devised a complete explanation. To
 64158	refute him someone would have to prove to him that there is no devil,
 64159	or another peasant would have to explain to him that it is not the devil
 64160	but a German, who moves the locomotive. Only then, as a result of the
 64161	contradiction, will they see that they are both wrong. But the man who
 64162	says that the movement of the wheels is the cause refutes himself, for
 64163	having once begun to analyze he ought to go on and explain further why
 64164	the wheels go round; and till he has reached the ultimate cause of the
 64165	movement of the locomotive in the pressure of steam in the boiler, he
 64166	has no right to stop in his search for the cause. The man who explains
 64167	the movement of the locomotive by the smoke that is carried back has
 64168	noticed that the wheels do not supply an explanation and has taken the
 64169	first sign that occurs to him and in his turn has offered that as an
 64170	explanation.
 64171	
 64172	The only conception that can explain the movement of the locomotive is
 64173	that of a force commensurate with the movement observed.
 64174	
 64175	The only conception that can explain the movement of the peoples is that
 64176	of some force commensurate with the whole movement of the peoples.
 64177	
 64178	Yet to supply this conception various historians take forces of
 64179	different kinds, all of which are incommensurate with the movement
 64180	observed. Some see it as a force directly inherent in heroes, as the
 64181	peasant sees the devil in the locomotive; others as a force resulting
 64182	from several other forces, like the movement of the wheels; others again
 64183	as an intellectual influence, like the smoke that is blown away.
 64184	
 64185	So long as histories are written of separate individuals, whether
 64186	Caesars, Alexanders, Luthers, or Voltaires, and not the histories
 64187	of all, absolutely all those who take part in an event, it is quite
 64188	impossible to describe the movement of humanity without the conception
 64189	of a force compelling men to direct their activity toward a certain end.
 64190	And the only such conception known to historians is that of power.
 64191	
 64192	This conception is the one handle by means of which the material of
 64193	history, as at present expounded, can be dealt with, and anyone who
 64194	breaks that handle off, as Buckle did, without finding some other method
 64195	of treating historical material, merely deprives himself of the one
 64196	possible way of dealing with it. The necessity of the conception of
 64197	power as an explanation of historical events is best demonstrated by
 64198	the universal historians and historians of culture themselves, for they
 64199	professedly reject that conception but inevitably have recourse to it at
 64200	every step.
 64201	
 64202	In dealing with humanityâs inquiry, the science of history up to now
 64203	is like money in circulationâpaper money and coin. The biographies and
 64204	special national histories are like paper money. They can be used and
 64205	can circulate and fulfill their purpose without harm to anyone and even
 64206	advantageously, as long as no one asks what is the security behind them.
 64207	You need only forget to ask how the will of heroes produces events, and
 64208	such histories as Thiersâ will be interesting and instructive and may
 64209	perhaps even possess a tinge of poetry. But just as doubts of the real
 64210	value of paper money arise either because, being easy to make, too much
 64211	of it gets made or because people try to exchange it for gold, so also
 64212	doubts concerning the real value of such histories arise either because
 64213	too many of them are written or because in his simplicity of heart
 64214	someone inquires: by what force did Napoleon do this?âthat is, wants
 64215	to exchange the current paper money for the real gold of actual
 64216	comprehension.
 64217	
 64218	The writers of universal histories and of the history of culture are
 64219	like people who, recognizing the defects of paper money, decide to
 64220	substitute for it money made of metal that has not the specific gravity
 64221	of gold. It may indeed make jingling coin, but will do no more than
 64222	that. Paper money may deceive the ignorant, but nobody is deceived by
 64223	tokens of base metal that have no value but merely jingle. As gold is
 64224	gold only if it is serviceable not merely for exchange but also for use,
 64225	so universal historians will be valuable only when they can reply to
 64226	historyâs essential question: what is power? The universal historians
 64227	give contradictory replies to that question, while the historians of
 64228	culture evade it and answer something quite different. And as counters
 64229	of imitation gold can be used only among a group of people who agree to
 64230	accept them as gold, or among those who do not know the nature of
 64231	gold, so universal historians and historians of culture, not answering
 64232	humanityâs essential question, serve as currency for some purposes of
 64233	their own, only in universities and among the mass of readers who have a
 64234	taste for what they call âserious reading.â
 64235	
 64236	
 64237	
 64238	
 64239	
 64240	CHAPTER IV
 64241	
 64242	Having abandoned the conception of the ancients as to the divine
 64243	subjection of the will of a nation to some chosen man and the subjection
 64244	of that manâs will to the Deity, history cannot without contradictions
 64245	take a single step till it has chosen one of two things: either a return
 64246	to the former belief in the direct intervention of the Deity in human
 64247	affairs or a definite explanation of the meaning of the force producing
 64248	historical events and termed âpower.â
 64249	
 64250	A return to the first is impossible, the belief has been destroyed; and
 64251	so it is essential to explain what is meant by power.
 64252	
 64253	Napoleon ordered an army to be raised and go to war. We are so
 64254	accustomed to that idea and have become so used to it that the question:
 64255	why did six hundred thousand men go to fight when Napoleon uttered
 64256	certain words, seems to us senseless. He had the power and so what he
 64257	ordered was done.
 64258	
 64259	This reply is quite satisfactory if we believe that the power was given
 64260	him by God. But as soon as we do not admit that, it becomes essential to
 64261	determine what is this power of one man over others.
 64262	
 64263	It cannot be the direct physical power of a strong man over a weak oneâa
 64264	domination based on the application or threat of physical force, like
 64265	the power of Hercules; nor can it be based on the effect of moral force,
 64266	as in their simplicity some historians think who say that the leading
 64267	figures in history are heroes, that is, men gifted with a special
 64268	strength of soul and mind called genius. This power cannot be based on
 64269	the predominance of moral strength, for, not to mention heroes such as
 64270	Napoleon about whose moral qualities opinions differ widely, history
 64271	shows us that neither a Louis XI nor a Metternich, who ruled over
 64272	millions of people, had any particular moral qualities, but on the
 64273	contrary were generally morally weaker than any of the millions they
 64274	ruled over.
 64275	
 64276	If the source of power lies neither in the physical nor in the moral
 64277	qualities of him who possesses it, it must evidently be looked for
 64278	elsewhereâin the relation to the people of the man who wields the power.
 64279	
 64280	And that is how power is understood by the science of jurisprudence,
 64281	that exchange bank of history which offers to exchange historyâs
 64282	understanding of power for true gold.
 64283	
 64284	Power is the collective will of the people transferred, by expressed or
 64285	tacit consent, to their chosen rulers.
 64286	
 64287	In the domain of jurisprudence, which consists of discussions of how a
 64288	state and power might be arranged were it possible for all that to
 64289	be arranged, it is all very clear; but when applied to history that
 64290	definition of power needs explanation.
 64291	
 64292	The science of jurisprudence regards the state and power as the ancients
 64293	regarded fireânamely, as something existing absolutely. But for history,
 64294	the state and power are merely phenomena, just as for modern physics
 64295	fire is not an element but a phenomenon.
 64296	
 64297	From this fundamental difference between the view held by history and
 64298	that held by jurisprudence, it follows that jurisprudence can tell
 64299	minutely how in its opinion power should be constituted and what
 64300	powerâexisting immutably outside timeâis, but to historyâs questions
 64301	about the meaning of the mutations of power in time it can answer
 64302	nothing.
 64303	
 64304	If power be the collective will of the people transferred to their
 64305	ruler, was PugachÃ«v a representative of the will of the people? If not,
 64306	then why was Napoleon I? Why was Napoleon III a criminal when he was
 64307	taken prisoner at Boulogne, and why, later on, were those criminals whom
 64308	he arrested?
 64309	
 64310	Do palace revolutionsâin which sometimes only two or three people take
 64311	partâtransfer the will of the people to a new ruler? In international
 64312	relations, is the will of the people also transferred to their
 64313	conqueror? Was the will of the Confederation of the Rhine transferred
 64314	to Napoleon in 1806? Was the will of the Russian people transferred
 64315	to Napoleon in 1809, when our army in alliance with the French went to
 64316	fight the Austrians?
 64317	
 64318	To these questions three answers are possible:
 64319	
 64320	Either to assume (1) that the will of the people is always
 64321	unconditionally transferred to the ruler or rulers they have chosen, and
 64322	that therefore every emergence of a new power, every struggle
 64323	against the power once appointed, should be absolutely regarded as an
 64324	infringement of the real power; or (2) that the will of the people
 64325	is transferred to the rulers conditionally, under definite and known
 64326	conditions, and to show that all limitations, conflicts, and even
 64327	destructions of power result from a nonobservance by the rulers of the
 64328	conditions under which their power was entrusted to them; or (3) that
 64329	the will of the people is delegated to the rulers conditionally, but
 64330	that the conditions are unknown and indefinite, and that the appearance
 64331	of several authorities, their struggles and their falls, result solely
 64332	from the greater or lesser fulfillment by the rulers of these unknown
 64333	conditions on which the will of the people is transferred from some
 64334	people to others.
 64335	
 64336	And these are the three ways in which the historians do explain the
 64337	relation of the people to their rulers.
 64338	
 64339	Some historiansâthose biographical and specialist historians already
 64340	referred toâin their simplicity failing to understand the question of
 64341	the meaning of power, seem to consider that the collective will of
 64342	the people is unconditionally transferred to historical persons, and
 64343	therefore when describing some single state they assume that particular
 64344	power to be the one absolute and real power, and that any other force
 64345	opposing this is not a power but a violation of powerâmere violence.
 64346	
 64347	Their theory, suitable for primitive and peaceful periods of history,
 64348	has the inconvenienceâin application to complex and stormy periods in
 64349	the life of nations during which various powers arise simultaneously and
 64350	struggle with one anotherâthat a Legitimist historian will prove
 64351	that the National Convention, the Directory, and Bonaparte were mere
 64352	infringers of the true power, while a Republican and a Bonapartist will
 64353	prove: the one that the Convention and the other that the Empire was the
 64354	real power, and that all the others were violations of power.
 64355	Evidently the explanations furnished by these historians being mutually
 64356	contradictory can only satisfy young children.
 64357	
 64358	Recognizing the falsity of this view of history, another set of
 64359	historians say that power rests on a conditional delegation of the will
 64360	of the people to their rulers, and that historical leaders have power
 64361	only conditionally on carrying out the program that the will of the
 64362	people has by tacit agreement prescribed to them. But what this program
 64363	consists in these historians do not say, or if they do they continually
 64364	contradict one another.
 64365	
 64366	Each historian, according to his view of what constitutes a nationâs
 64367	progress, looks for these conditions in the greatness, wealth, freedom,
 64368	or enlightenment of citizens of France or some other country. But not
 64369	to mention the historiansâ contradictions as to the nature of this
 64370	programâor even admitting that some one general program of these
 64371	conditions existsâthe facts of history almost always contradict that
 64372	theory. If the conditions under which power is entrusted consist in the
 64373	wealth, freedom, and enlightenment of the people, how is it that Louis
 64374	XIV and IvÃ¡n the Terrible end their reigns tranquilly, while Louis XVI
 64375	and Charles I are executed by their people? To this question historians
 64376	reply that Louis XIVâs activity, contrary to the program, reacted on
 64377	Louis XVI. But why did it not react on Louis XIV or on Louis XVâwhy
 64378	should it react just on Louis XVI? And what is the time limit for such
 64379	reactions? To these questions there are and can be no answers. Equally
 64380	little does this view explain why for several centuries the collective
 64381	will is not withdrawn from certain rulers and their heirs, and
 64382	then suddenly during a period of fifty years is transferred to the
 64383	Convention, to the Directory, to Napoleon, to Alexander, to Louis XVIII,
 64384	to Napoleon again, to Charles X, to Louis Philippe, to a Republican
 64385	government, and to Napoleon III. When explaining these rapid transfers
 64386	of the peopleâs will from one individual to another, especially in view
 64387	of international relations, conquests, and alliances, the historians are
 64388	obliged to admit that some of these transfers are not normal delegations
 64389	of the peopleâs will but are accidents dependent on cunning, on
 64390	mistakes, on craft, or on the weakness of a diplomatist, a ruler, or a
 64391	party leader. So that the greater part of the events of historyâcivil
 64392	wars, revolutions, and conquestsâare presented by these historians
 64393	not as the results of free transferences of the peopleâs will, but as
 64394	results of the ill-directed will of one or more individuals, that is,
 64395	once again, as usurpations of power. And so these historians also see
 64396	and admit historical events which are exceptions to the theory.
 64397	
 64398	These historians resemble a botanist who, having noticed that some
 64399	plants grow from seeds producing two cotyledons, should insist that all
 64400	that grows does so by sprouting into two leaves, and that the palm, the
 64401	mushroom, and even the oak, which blossom into full growth and no longer
 64402	resemble two leaves, are deviations from the theory.
 64403	
 64404	Historians of the third class assume that the will of the people
 64405	is transferred to historic personages conditionally, but that the
 64406	conditions are unknown to us. They say that historical personages have
 64407	power only because they fulfill the will of the people which has been
 64408	delegated to them.
 64409	
 64410	But in that case, if the force that moves nations lies not in the
 64411	historic leaders but in the nations themselves, what significance have
 64412	those leaders?
 64413	
 64414	The leaders, these historians tell us, express the will of the people:
 64415	the activity of the leaders represents the activity of the people.
 64416	
 64417	But in that case the question arises whether all the activity of the
 64418	leaders serves as an expression of the peopleâs will or only some part
 64419	of it. If the whole activity of the leaders serves as the expression of
 64420	the peopleâs will, as some historians suppose, then all the details
 64421	of the court scandals contained in the biographies of a Napoleon or
 64422	a Catherine serve to express the life of the nation, which is evident
 64423	nonsense; but if it is only some particular side of the activity of an
 64424	historical leader which serves to express the peopleâs life, as other
 64425	so-called âphilosophicalâ historians believe, then to determine which
 64426	side of the activity of a leader expresses the nationâs life, we have
 64427	first of all to know in what the nationâs life consists.
 64428	
 64429	Met by this difficulty historians of that class devise some most
 64430	obscure, impalpable, and general abstraction which can cover all
 64431	conceivable occurrences, and declare this abstraction to be the aim of
 64432	humanityâs movement. The most usual generalizations adopted by almost
 64433	all the historians are: freedom, equality, enlightenment, progress,
 64434	civilization, and culture. Postulating some generalization as the goal
 64435	of the movement of humanity, the historians study the men of whom the
 64436	greatest number of monuments have remained: kings, ministers, generals,
 64437	authors, reformers, popes, and journalists, to the extent to which in
 64438	their opinion these persons have promoted or hindered that abstraction.
 64439	But as it is in no way proved that the aim of humanity does consist in
 64440	freedom, equality, enlightenment, or civilization, and as the connection
 64441	of the people with the rulers and enlighteners of humanity is only based
 64442	on the arbitrary assumption that the collective will of the people is
 64443	always transferred to the men whom we have noticed, it happens that the
 64444	activity of the millions who migrate, burn houses, abandon agriculture,
 64445	and destroy one another never is expressed in the account of the
 64446	activity of some dozen people who did not burn houses, practice
 64447	agriculture, or slay their fellow creatures.
 64448	
 64449	History proves this at every turn. Is the ferment of the peoples of
 64450	the west at the end of the eighteenth century and their drive eastward
 64451	explained by the activity of Louis XIV, XV, and XVI, their mistresses
 64452	and ministers, and by the lives of Napoleon, Rousseau, Diderot,
 64453	Beaumarchais, and others?
 64454	
 64455	Is the movement of the Russian people eastward to KazÃ¡n and Siberia
 64456	expressed by details of the morbid character of IvÃ¡n the Terrible and by
 64457	his correspondence with KÃºrbski?
 64458	
 64459	Is the movement of the peoples at the time of the Crusades explained by
 64460	the life and activity of the Godfreys and the Louis-es and their ladies?
 64461	For us that movement of the peoples from west to east, without
 64462	leaders, with a crowd of vagrants, and with Peter the Hermit, remains
 64463	incomprehensible. And yet more incomprehensible is the cessation of that
 64464	movement when a rational and sacred aim for the Crusadeâthe deliverance
 64465	of Jerusalemâhad been clearly defined by historic leaders. Popes, kings,
 64466	and knights incited the peoples to free the Holy Land; but the people
 64467	did not go, for the unknown cause which had previously impelled them to
 64468	go no longer existed. The history of the Godfreys and the Minnesingers
 64469	can evidently not cover the life of the peoples. And the history of the
 64470	Godfreys and the Minnesingers has remained the history of Godfreys
 64471	and Minnesingers, but the history of the life of the peoples and their
 64472	impulses has remained unknown.
 64473	
 64474	Still less does the history of authors and reformers explain to us the
 64475	life of the peoples.
 64476	
 64477	The history of culture explains to us the impulses and conditions of
 64478	life and thought of a writer or a reformer. We learn that Luther had
 64479	a hot temper and said such and such things; we learn that Rousseau was
 64480	suspicious and wrote such and such books; but we do not learn why after
 64481	the Reformation the peoples massacred one another, nor why during the
 64482	French Revolution they guillotined one another.
 64483	
 64484	If we unite both these kinds of history, as is done by the newest
 64485	historians, we shall have the history of monarchs and writers, but not
 64486	the history of the life of the peoples.
 64487	
 64488	
 64489	
 64490	
 64491	
 64492	CHAPTER V
 64493	
 64494	The life of the nations is not contained in the lives of a few men, for
 64495	the connection between those men and the nations has not been found.
 64496	The theory that this connection is based on the transference of the
 64497	collective will of a people to certain historical personages is an
 64498	hypothesis unconfirmed by the experience of history.
 64499	
 64500	The theory of the transference of the collective will of the people to
 64501	historic persons may perhaps explain much in the domain of jurisprudence
 64502	and be essential for its purposes, but in its application to history, as
 64503	soon as revolutions, conquests, or civil wars occurâthat is, as soon as
 64504	history beginsâthat theory explains nothing.
 64505	
 64506	The theory seems irrefutable just because the act of transference of the
 64507	peopleâs will cannot be verified, for it never occurred.
 64508	
 64509	Whatever happens and whoever may stand at the head of affairs, the
 64510	theory can always say that such and such a person took the lead because
 64511	the collective will was transferred to him.
 64512	
 64513	The replies this theory gives to historical questions are like the
 64514	replies of a man who, watching the movements of a herd of cattle and
 64515	paying no attention to the varying quality of the pasturage in different
 64516	parts of the field, or to the driving of the herdsman, should attribute
 64517	the direction the herd takes to what animal happens to be at its head.
 64518	
 64519	âThe herd goes in that direction because the animal in front leads
 64520	it and the collective will of all the other animals is vested in that
 64521	leader.â This is what historians of the first class sayâthose who assume
 64522	the unconditional transference of the peopleâs will.
 64523	
 64524	âIf the animals leading the herd change, this happens because the
 64525	collective will of all the animals is transferred from one leader to
 64526	another, according to whether the animal is or is not leading them in
 64527	the direction selected by the whole herd.â Such is the reply historians
 64528	who assume that the collective will of the people is delegated to
 64529	rulers under conditions which they regard as known. (With this method
 64530	of observation it often happens that the observer, influenced by the
 64531	direction he himself prefers, regards those as leaders who, owing to the
 64532	peopleâs change of direction, are no longer in front, but on one side,
 64533	or even in the rear.)
 64534	
 64535	âIf the animals in front are continually changing and the direction of
 64536	the whole herd is constantly altered, this is because in order to follow
 64537	a given direction the animals transfer their will to the animals that
 64538	have attracted our attention, and to study the movements of the herd
 64539	we must watch the movements of all the prominent animals moving on all
 64540	sides of the herd.â So say the third class of historians who regard all
 64541	historical persons, from monarchs to journalists, as the expression of
 64542	their age.
 64543	
 64544	The theory of the transference of the will of the people to historic
 64545	persons is merely a paraphraseâa restatement of the question in other
 64546	words.
 64547	
 64548	What causes historical events? Power. What is power? Power is the
 64549	collective will of the people transferred to one person. Under what
 64550	condition is the will of the people delegated to one person? On
 64551	condition that that person expresses the will of the whole people. That
 64552	is, power is power: in other words, power is a word the meaning of which
 64553	we do not understand.
 64554	
 64555	If the realm of human knowledge were confined to abstract reasoning,
 64556	then having subjected to criticism the explanation of âpowerâ that
 64557	juridical science gives us, humanity would conclude that power is merely
 64558	a word and has no real existence. But to understand phenomena man
 64559	has, besides abstract reasoning, experience by which he verifies his
 64560	reflections. And experience tells us that power is not merely a word but
 64561	an actually existing phenomenon.
 64562	
 64563	Not to speak of the fact that no description of the collective activity
 64564	of men can do without the conception of power, the existence of power is
 64565	proved both by history and by observing contemporary events.
 64566	
 64567	Whenever an event occurs a man appears or men appear, by whose will the
 64568	event seems to have taken place. Napoleon III issues a decree and the
 64569	French go to Mexico. The King of Prussia and Bismarck issue decrees and
 64570	an army enters Bohemia. Napoleon I issues a decree and an army enters
 64571	Russia. Alexander I gives a command and the French submit to the
 64572	Bourbons. Experience shows us that whatever event occurs it is always
 64573	related to the will of one or of several men who have decreed it.
 64574	
 64575	The historians, in accord with the old habit of acknowledging divine
 64576	intervention in human affairs, want to see the cause of events in
 64577	the expression of the will of someone endowed with power, but that
 64578	supposition is not confirmed either by reason or by experience.
 64579	
 64580	On the one side reflection shows that the expression of a manâs willâhis
 64581	wordsâare only part of the general activity expressed in an event,
 64582	as for instance in a war or a revolution, and so without assuming an
 64583	incomprehensible, supernatural forceâa miracleâone cannot admit that
 64584	words can be the immediate cause of the movements of millions of men.
 64585	On the other hand, even if we admitted that words could be the cause
 64586	of events, history shows that the expression of the will of historical
 64587	personages does not in most cases produce any effect, that is to say,
 64588	their commands are often not executed, and sometimes the very opposite
 64589	of what they order occurs.
 64590	
 64591	Without admitting divine intervention in the affairs of humanity we
 64592	cannot regard âpowerâ as the cause of events.
 64593	
 64594	Power, from the standpoint of experience, is merely the relation that
 64595	exists between the expression of someoneâs will and the execution of
 64596	that will by others.
 64597	
 64598	To explain the conditions of that relationship we must first establish a
 64599	conception of the expression of will, referring it to man and not to the
 64600	Deity.
 64601	
 64602	If the Deity issues a command, expresses His will, as ancient history
 64603	tells us, the expression of that will is independent of time and is not
 64604	caused by anything, for the Divinity is not controlled by an event. But
 64605	speaking of commands that are the expression of the will of men acting
 64606	in time and in relation to one another, to explain the connection of
 64607	commands with events we must restore: (1) the condition of all that
 64608	takes place: the continuity of movement in time both of the events and
 64609	of the person who commands, and (2) the inevitability of the connection
 64610	between the person commanding and those who execute his command.
 64611	
 64612	
 64613	
 64614	
 64615	
 64616	CHAPTER VI
 64617	
 64618	Only the expression of the will of the Deity, not dependent on time, can
 64619	relate to a whole series of events occurring over a period of years or
 64620	centuries, and only the Deity, independent of everything, can by His
 64621	sole will determine the direction of humanityâs movement; but man acts
 64622	in time and himself takes part in what occurs.
 64623	
 64624	Reinstating the first condition omitted, that of time, we see that no
 64625	command can be executed without some preceding order having been given
 64626	rendering the execution of the last command possible.
 64627	
 64628	No command ever appears spontaneously, or itself covers a whole series
 64629	of occurrences; but each command follows from another, and never refers
 64630	to a whole series of events but always to one moment only of an event.
 64631	
 64632	When, for instance, we say that Napoleon ordered armies to go to war,
 64633	we combine in one simultaneous expression a whole series of consecutive
 64634	commands dependent one on another. Napoleon could not have commanded
 64635	an invasion of Russia and never did so. Today he ordered such and such
 64636	papers to be written to Vienna, to Berlin, and to Petersburg;
 64637	tomorrow such and such decrees and orders to the army, the fleet, the
 64638	commissariat, and so on and so onâmillions of commands, which formed
 64639	a whole series corresponding to a series of events which brought the
 64640	French armies into Russia.
 64641	
 64642	If throughout his reign Napoleon gave commands concerning an invasion
 64643	of England and expended on no other undertaking so much time and effort,
 64644	and yet during his whole reign never once attempted to execute that
 64645	design but undertook an expedition into Russia, with which country he
 64646	considered it desirable to be in alliance (a conviction he repeatedly
 64647	expressed)âthis came about because his commands did not correspond to
 64648	the course of events in the first case, but did so correspond in the
 64649	latter.
 64650	
 64651	For an order to be certainly executed, it is necessary that a man should
 64652	order what can be executed. But to know what can and what cannot be
 64653	executed is impossible, not only in the case of Napoleonâs invasion of
 64654	Russia in which millions participated, but even in the simplest event,
 64655	for in either case millions of obstacles may arise to prevent its
 64656	execution. Every order executed is always one of an immense number
 64657	unexecuted. All the impossible orders inconsistent with the course of
 64658	events remain unexecuted. Only the possible ones get linked up with a
 64659	consecutive series of commands corresponding to a series of events, and
 64660	are executed.
 64661	
 64662	Our false conception that an event is caused by a command which precedes
 64663	it is due to the fact that when the event has taken place and out of
 64664	thousands of others those few commands which were consistent with that
 64665	event have been executed, we forget about the others that were not
 64666	executed because they could not be. Apart from that, the chief source
 64667	of our error in this matter is due to the fact that in the historical
 64668	accounts a whole series of innumerable, diverse, and petty events, such
 64669	for instance as all those which led the French armies to Russia, is
 64670	generalized into one event in accord with the result produced by that
 64671	series of events, and corresponding with this generalization the whole
 64672	series of commands is also generalized into a single expression of will.
 64673	
 64674	We say that Napoleon wished to invade Russia and invaded it. In
 64675	reality in all Napoleonâs activity we never find anything resembling an
 64676	expression of that wish, but find a series of orders, or expressions of
 64677	his will, very variously and indefinitely directed. Amid a long series
 64678	of unexecuted orders of Napoleonâs one series, for the campaign of 1812,
 64679	was carried outânot because those orders differed in any way from the
 64680	other, unexecuted orders but because they coincided with the course of
 64681	events that led the French army into Russia; just as in stencil work
 64682	this or that figure comes out not because the color was laid on from
 64683	this side or in that way, but because it was laid on from all sides over
 64684	the figure cut in the stencil.
 64685	
 64686	So that examining the relation in time of the commands to the events,
 64687	we find that a command can never be the cause of the event, but that a
 64688	certain definite dependence exists between the two.
 64689	
 64690	To understand in what this dependence consists it is necessary to
 64691	reinstate another omitted condition of every command proceeding not from
 64692	the Deity but from a man, which is, that the man who gives the command
 64693	himself takes part in the event.
 64694	
 64695	This relation of the commander to those he commands is just what is
 64696	called power. This relation consists in the following:
 64697	
 64698	For common action people always unite in certain combinations, in which
 64699	regardless of the difference of the aims set for the common action, the
 64700	relation between those taking part in it is always the same.
 64701	
 64702	Men uniting in these combinations always assume such relations toward
 64703	one another that the larger number take a more direct share, and the
 64704	smaller number a less direct share, in the collective action for which
 64705	they have combined.
 64706	
 64707	Of all the combinations in which men unite for collective action one of
 64708	the most striking and definite examples is an army.
 64709	
 64710	Every army is composed of lower grades of the serviceâthe rank and
 64711	fileâof whom there are always the greatest number; of the next higher
 64712	military rankâcorporals and noncommissioned officers of whom there are
 64713	fewer, and of still-higher officers of whom there are still fewer,
 64714	and so on to the highest military command which is concentrated in one
 64715	person.
 64716	
 64717	A military organization may be quite correctly compared to a cone, of
 64718	which the base with the largest diameter consists of the rank and file;
 64719	the next higher and smaller section of the cone consists of the next
 64720	higher grades of the army, and so on to the apex, the point of which
 64721	will represent the commander in chief.
 64722	
 64723	The soldiers, of whom there are the most, form the lower section of
 64724	the cone and its base. The soldier himself does the stabbing, hacking,
 64725	burning, and pillaging, and always receives orders for these actions
 64726	from men above him; he himself never gives an order. The noncommissioned
 64727	officers (of whom there are fewer) perform the action itself less
 64728	frequently than the soldiers, but they already give commands. An
 64729	officer still less often acts directly himself, but commands still more
 64730	frequently. A general does nothing but command the troops, indicates the
 64731	objective, and hardly ever uses a weapon himself. The commander in chief
 64732	never takes direct part in the action itself, but only gives general
 64733	orders concerning the movement of the mass of the troops. A similar
 64734	relation of people to one another is seen in every combination of men
 64735	for common activityâin agriculture, trade, and every administration.
 64736	
 64737	And so without particularly analyzing all the contiguous sections of
 64738	a cone and of the ranks of an army, or the ranks and positions in
 64739	any administrative or public business whatever from the lowest to the
 64740	highest, we see a law by which men, to take associated action, combine
 64741	in such relations that the more directly they participate in performing
 64742	the action the less they can command and the more numerous they are,
 64743	while the less their direct participation in the action itself, the more
 64744	they command and the fewer of them there are; rising in this way from
 64745	the lowest ranks to the man at the top, who takes the least direct share
 64746	in the action and directs his activity chiefly to commanding.
 64747	
 64748	This relation of the men who command to those they command is what
 64749	constitutes the essence of the conception called power.
 64750	
 64751	Having restored the condition of time under which all events occur,
 64752	we find that a command is executed only when it is related to a
 64753	corresponding series of events. Restoring the essential condition of
 64754	relation between those who command and those who execute, we find that
 64755	by the very nature of the case those who command take the smallest part
 64756	in the action itself and that their activity is exclusively directed to
 64757	commanding.
 64758	
 64759	
 64760	
 64761	
 64762	
 64763	CHAPTER VII
 64764	
 64765	When an event is taking place people express their opinions and wishes
 64766	about it, and as the event results from the collective activity of
 64767	many people, some one of the opinions or wishes expressed is sure to be
 64768	fulfilled if but approximately. When one of the opinions expressed
 64769	is fulfilled, that opinion gets connected with the event as a command
 64770	preceding it.
 64771	
 64772	Men are hauling a log. Each of them expresses his opinion as to how and
 64773	where to haul it. They haul the log away, and it happens that this is
 64774	done as one of them said. He ordered it. There we have command and power
 64775	in their primary form. The man who worked most with his hands could not
 64776	think so much about what he was doing, or reflect on or command what
 64777	would result from the common activity; while the man who commanded
 64778	more would evidently work less with his hands on account of his greater
 64779	verbal activity.
 64780	
 64781	When some larger concourse of men direct their activity to a common aim
 64782	there is a yet sharper division of those who, because their activity is
 64783	given to directing and commanding, take less part in the direct work.
 64784	
 64785	When a man works alone he always has a certain set of reflections which
 64786	as it seems to him directed his past activity, justify his present
 64787	activity, and guide him in planning his future actions. Just the same is
 64788	done by a concourse of people, allowing those who do not take a direct
 64789	part in the activity to devise considerations, justifications, and
 64790	surmises concerning their collective activity.
 64791	
 64792	For reasons known or unknown to us the French began to drown and kill
 64793	one another. And corresponding to the event its justification appears in
 64794	peopleâs belief that this was necessary for the welfare of France, for
 64795	liberty, and for equality. People ceased to kill one another, and
 64796	this event was accompanied by its justification in the necessity for a
 64797	centralization of power, resistance to Europe, and so on. Men went
 64798	from the west to the east killing their fellow men, and the event
 64799	was accompanied by phrases about the glory of France, the baseness of
 64800	England, and so on. History shows us that these justifications of the
 64801	events have no common sense and are all contradictory, as in the case of
 64802	killing a man as the result of recognizing his rights, and the killing
 64803	of millions in Russia for the humiliation of England. But these
 64804	justifications have a very necessary significance in their own day.
 64805	
 64806	These justifications release those who produce the events from moral
 64807	responsibility. These temporary aims are like the broom fixed in front
 64808	of a locomotive to clear the snow from the rails in front: they clear
 64809	menâs moral responsibilities from their path.
 64810	
 64811	Without such justification there would be no reply to the simplest
 64812	question that presents itself when examining each historical event. How
 64813	is it that millions of men commit collective crimesâmake war, commit
 64814	murder, and so on?
 64815	
 64816	With the present complex forms of political and social life in Europe
 64817	can any event that is not prescribed, decreed, or ordered by monarchs,
 64818	ministers, parliaments, or newspapers be imagined? Is there any
 64819	collective action which cannot find its justification in political
 64820	unity, in patriotism, in the balance of power, or in civilization? So
 64821	that every event that occurs inevitably coincides with some expressed
 64822	wish and, receiving a justification, presents itself as the result of
 64823	the will of one man or of several men.
 64824	
 64825	In whatever direction a ship moves, the flow of the waves it cuts
 64826	will always be noticeable ahead of it. To those on board the ship the
 64827	movement of those waves will be the only perceptible motion.
 64828	
 64829	Only by watching closely moment by moment the movement of that flow and
 64830	comparing it with the movement of the ship do we convince ourselves that
 64831	every bit of it is occasioned by the forward movement of the ship,
 64832	and that we were led into error by the fact that we ourselves were
 64833	imperceptibly moving.
 64834	
 64835	We see the same if we watch moment by moment the movement of historical
 64836	characters (that is, re-establish the inevitable condition of all that
 64837	occursâthe continuity of movement in time) and do not lose sight of the
 64838	essential connection of historical persons with the masses.
 64839	
 64840	When the ship moves in one direction there is one and the same wave
 64841	ahead of it, when it turns frequently the wave ahead of it also turns
 64842	frequently. But wherever it may turn there always will be the wave
 64843	anticipating its movement.
 64844	
 64845	Whatever happens it always appears that just that event was foreseen
 64846	and decreed. Wherever the ship may go, the rush of water which neither
 64847	directs nor increases its movement foams ahead of it, and at a distance
 64848	seems to us not merely to move of itself but to govern the shipâs
 64849	movement also.
 64850	
 64851	Examining only those expressions of the will of historical persons
 64852	which, as commands, were related to events, historians have assumed
 64853	that the events depended on those commands. But examining the events
 64854	themselves and the connection in which the historical persons stood to
 64855	the people, we have found that they and their orders were dependent on
 64856	events. The incontestable proof of this deduction is that, however many
 64857	commands were issued, the event does not take place unless there are
 64858	other causes for it, but as soon as an event occursâbe it what it
 64859	mayâthen out of all the continually expressed wishes of different people
 64860	some will always be found which by their meaning and their time of
 64861	utterance are related as commands to the events.
 64862	
 64863	Arriving at this conclusion we can reply directly and positively to
 64864	these two essential questions of history:
 64865	
 64866	(1) What is power?
 64867	
 64868	(2) What force produces the movement of the nations?
 64869	
 64870	(1) Power is the relation of a given person to other individuals,
 64871	in which the more this person expresses opinions, predictions, and
 64872	justifications of the collective action that is performed, the less is
 64873	his participation in that action.
 64874	
 64875	(2) The movement of nations is caused not by power, nor by intellectual
 64876	activity, nor even by a combination of the two as historians have
 64877	supposed, but by the activity of all the people who participate in
 64878	the events, and who always combine in such a way that those taking
 64879	the largest direct share in the event take on themselves the least
 64880	responsibility and vice versa.
 64881	
 64882	Morally the wielder of power appears to cause the event; physically
 64883	it is those who submit to the power. But as the moral activity is
 64884	inconceivable without the physical, the cause of the event is neither in
 64885	the one nor in the other but in the union of the two.
 64886	
 64887	Or in other words, the conception of a cause is inapplicable to the
 64888	phenomena we are examining.
 64889	
 64890	In the last analysis we reach the circle of infinityâthat final limit
 64891	to which in every domain of thought manâs reason arrives if it is not
 64892	playing with the subject. Electricity produces heat, heat produces
 64893	electricity. Atoms attract each other and atoms repel one another.
 64894	
 64895	Speaking of the interaction of heat and electricity and of atoms, we
 64896	cannot say why this occurs, and we say that it is so because it is
 64897	inconceivable otherwise, because it must be so and that it is a law. The
 64898	same applies to historical events. Why war and revolution occur we do
 64899	not know. We only know that to produce the one or the other action,
 64900	people combine in a certain formation in which they all take part, and
 64901	we say that this is so because it is unthinkable otherwise, or in other
 64902	words that it is a law.
 64903	
 64904	
 64905	
 64906	
 64907	
 64908	CHAPTER VIII
 64909	
 64910	If history dealt only with external phenomena, the establishment of this
 64911	simple and obvious law would suffice and we should have finished our
 64912	argument. But the law of history relates to man. A particle of matter
 64913	cannot tell us that it does not feel the law of attraction or repulsion
 64914	and that that law is untrue, but man, who is the subject of history,
 64915	says plainly: I am free and am therefore not subject to the law.
 64916	
 64917	The presence of the problem of manâs free will, though unexpressed, is
 64918	felt at every step of history.
 64919	
 64920	All seriously thinking historians have involuntarily encountered this
 64921	question. All the contradictions and obscurities of history and the
 64922	false path historical science has followed are due solely to the lack of
 64923	a solution of that question.
 64924	
 64925	If the will of every man were free, that is, if each man could act as he
 64926	pleased, all history would be a series of disconnected incidents.
 64927	
 64928	If in a thousand years even one man in a million could act freely, that
 64929	is, as he chose, it is evident that one single free act of that manâs
 64930	in violation of the laws governing human action would destroy the
 64931	possibility of the existence of any laws for the whole of humanity.
 64932	
 64933	If there be a single law governing the actions of men, free will cannot
 64934	exist, for then manâs will is subject to that law.
 64935	
 64936	In this contradiction lies the problem of free will, which from most
 64937	ancient times has occupied the best human minds and from most ancient
 64938	times has been presented in its whole tremendous significance.
 64939	
 64940	The problem is that regarding man as a subject of observation
 64941	from whatever point of viewâtheological, historical, ethical, or
 64942	philosophicâwe find a general law of necessity to which he (like all
 64943	that exists) is subject. But regarding him from within ourselves as what
 64944	we are conscious of, we feel ourselves to be free.
 64945	
 64946	This consciousness is a source of self-cognition quite apart from and
 64947	independent of reason. Through his reason man observes himself, but only
 64948	through consciousness does he know himself.
 64949	
 64950	Apart from consciousness of self no observation or application of reason
 64951	is conceivable.
 64952	
 64953	To understand, observe, and draw conclusions, man must first of all be
 64954	conscious of himself as living. A man is only conscious of himself as
 64955	a living being by the fact that he wills, that is, is conscious of
 64956	his volition. But his willâwhich forms the essence of his lifeâman
 64957	recognizes (and can but recognize) as free.
 64958	
 64959	If, observing himself, man sees that his will is always directed by
 64960	one and the same law (whether he observes the necessity of taking
 64961	food, using his brain, or anything else) he cannot recognize this
 64962	never-varying direction of his will otherwise than as a limitation of
 64963	it. Were it not free it could not be limited. A manâs will seems to him
 64964	to be limited just because he is not conscious of it except as free.
 64965	
 64966	You say: I am not free. But I have lifted my hand and let it fall.
 64967	Everyone understands that this illogical reply is an irrefutable
 64968	demonstration of freedom.
 64969	
 64970	That reply is the expression of a consciousness that is not subject to
 64971	reason.
 64972	
 64973	If the consciousness of freedom were not a separate and independent
 64974	source of self-consciousness it would be subject to reasoning and
 64975	to experience, but in fact such subjection does not exist and is
 64976	inconceivable.
 64977	
 64978	A series of experiments and arguments proves to every man that he, as
 64979	an object of observation, is subject to certain laws, and man submits to
 64980	them and never resists the laws of gravity or impermeability once he
 64981	has become acquainted with them. But the same series of experiments
 64982	and arguments proves to him that the complete freedom of which he is
 64983	conscious in himself is impossible, and that his every action depends
 64984	on his organization, his character, and the motives acting upon him; yet
 64985	man never submits to the deductions of these experiments and arguments.
 64986	Having learned from experiment and argument that a stone falls
 64987	downwards, a man indubitably believes this and always expects the law
 64988	that he has learned to be fulfilled.
 64989	
 64990	But learning just as certainly that his will is subject to laws, he does
 64991	not and cannot believe this.
 64992	
 64993	However often experiment and reasoning may show a man that under the
 64994	same conditions and with the same character he will do the same thing as
 64995	before, yet when under the same conditions and with the same character
 64996	he approaches for the thousandth time the action that always ends in the
 64997	same way, he feels as certainly convinced as before the experiment
 64998	that he can act as he pleases. Every man, savage or sage, however
 64999	incontestably reason and experiment may prove to him that it is
 65000	impossible to imagine two different courses of action in precisely the
 65001	same conditions, feels that without this irrational conception (which
 65002	constitutes the essence of freedom) he cannot imagine life. He feels
 65003	that however impossible it may be, it is so, for without this conception
 65004	of freedom not only would he be unable to understand life, but he would
 65005	be unable to live for a single moment.
 65006	
 65007	He could not live, because all manâs efforts, all his impulses to life,
 65008	are only efforts to increase freedom. Wealth and poverty, fame and
 65009	obscurity, power and subordination, strength and weakness, health and
 65010	disease, culture and ignorance, work and leisure, repletion and hunger,
 65011	virtue and vice, are only greater or lesser degrees of freedom.
 65012	
 65013	A man having no freedom cannot be conceived of except as deprived of
 65014	life.
 65015	
 65016	If the conception of freedom appears to reason to be a senseless
 65017	contradiction like the possibility of performing two actions at one and
 65018	the same instant of time, or of an effect without a cause, that only
 65019	proves that consciousness is not subject to reason.
 65020	
 65021	This unshakable, irrefutable consciousness of freedom, uncontrolled by
 65022	experiment or argument, recognized by all thinkers and felt by everyone
 65023	without exception, this consciousness without which no conception of man
 65024	is possible constitutes the other side of the question.
 65025	
 65026	Man is the creation of an all-powerful, all-good, and all-seeing God.
 65027	What is sin, the conception of which arises from the consciousness of
 65028	manâs freedom? That is a question for theology.
 65029	
 65030	The actions of men are subject to general immutable laws expressed in
 65031	statistics. What is manâs responsibility to society, the conception of
 65032	which results from the conception of freedom? That is a question for
 65033	jurisprudence.
 65034	
 65035	Manâs actions proceed from his innate character and the motives acting
 65036	upon him. What is conscience and the perception of right and wrong
 65037	in actions that follows from the consciousness of freedom? That is a
 65038	question for ethics.
 65039	
 65040	Man in connection with the general life of humanity appears subject
 65041	to laws which determine that life. But the same man apart from that
 65042	connection appears to be free. How should the past life of nations and
 65043	of humanity be regardedâas the result of the free, or as the result of
 65044	the constrained, activity of man? That is a question for history.
 65045	
 65046	Only in our self-confident day of the popularization of knowledgeâthanks
 65047	to that most powerful engine of ignorance, the diffusion of printed
 65048	matterâhas the question of the freedom of will been put on a level on
 65049	which the question itself cannot exist. In our time the majority of
 65050	so-called advanced peopleâthat is, the crowd of ignoramusesâhave taken
 65051	the work of the naturalists who deal with one side of the question for a
 65052	solution of the whole problem.
 65053	
 65054	They say and write and print that the soul and freedom do not exist,
 65055	for the life of man is expressed by muscular movements and muscular
 65056	movements are conditioned by the activity of the nerves; the soul and
 65057	free will do not exist because at an unknown period of time we sprang
 65058	from the apes. They say this, not at all suspecting that thousands of
 65059	years ago that same law of necessity which with such ardor they are now
 65060	trying to prove by physiology and comparative zoology was not merely
 65061	acknowledged by all the religions and all the thinkers, but has never
 65062	been denied. They do not see that the role of the natural sciences in
 65063	this matter is merely to serve as an instrument for the illumination
 65064	of one side of it. For the fact that, from the point of view of
 65065	observation, reason and the will are merely secretions of the brain, and
 65066	that man following the general law may have developed from lower animals
 65067	at some unknown period of time, only explains from a fresh side
 65068	the truth admitted thousands of years ago by all the religious and
 65069	philosophic theoriesâthat from the point of view of reason man is
 65070	subject to the law of necessity; but it does not advance by a hairâs
 65071	breadth the solution of the question, which has another, opposite, side,
 65072	based on the consciousness of freedom.
 65073	
 65074	If men descended from the apes at an unknown period of time, that is
 65075	as comprehensible as that they were made from a handful of earth at a
 65076	certain period of time (in the first case the unknown quantity is the
 65077	time, in the second case it is the origin); and the question of how
 65078	manâs consciousness of freedom is to be reconciled with the law of
 65079	necessity to which he is subject cannot be solved by comparative
 65080	physiology and zoology, for in a frog, a rabbit, or an ape, we can
 65081	observe only the muscular nervous activity, but in man we observe
 65082	consciousness as well as the muscular and nervous activity.
 65083	
 65084	The naturalists and their followers, thinking they can solve this
 65085	question, are like plasterers set to plaster one side of the walls of
 65086	a church who, availing themselves of the absence of the chief
 65087	superintendent of the work, should in an access of zeal plaster over the
 65088	windows, icons, woodwork, and still unbuttressed walls, and should be
 65089	delighted that from their point of view as plasterers, everything is now
 65090	so smooth and regular.
 65091	
 65092	
 65093	
 65094	
 65095	
 65096	CHAPTER IX
 65097	
 65098	For the solution of the question of free will or inevitability, history
 65099	has this advantage over other branches of knowledge in which the
 65100	question is dealt with, that for history this question does not refer
 65101	to the essence of manâs free will but its manifestation in the past and
 65102	under certain conditions.
 65103	
 65104	In regard to this question, history stands to the other sciences as
 65105	experimental science stands to abstract science.
 65106	
 65107	The subject for history is not manâs will itself but our presentation of
 65108	it.
 65109	
 65110	And so for history, the insoluble mystery presented by the
 65111	incompatibility of free will and inevitability does not exist as it does
 65112	for theology, ethics, and philosophy. History surveys a presentation of
 65113	manâs life in which the union of these two contradictions has already
 65114	taken place.
 65115	
 65116	In actual life each historic event, each human action, is very clearly
 65117	and definitely understood without any sense of contradiction, although
 65118	each event presents itself as partly free and partly compulsory.
 65119	
 65120	To solve the question of how freedom and necessity are combined and
 65121	what constitutes the essence of these two conceptions, the philosophy
 65122	of history can and should follow a path contrary to that taken by other
 65123	sciences. Instead of first defining the conceptions of freedom and
 65124	inevitability in themselves, and then ranging the phenomena of life
 65125	under those definitions, history should deduce a definition of the
 65126	conception of freedom and inevitability themselves from the immense
 65127	quantity of phenomena of which it is cognizant and that always appear
 65128	dependent on these two elements.
 65129	
 65130	Whatever presentation of the activity of many men or of an individual
 65131	we may consider, we always regard it as the result partly of manâs free
 65132	will and partly of the law of inevitability.
 65133	
 65134	Whether we speak of the migration of the peoples and the incursions
 65135	of the barbarians, or of the decrees of Napoleon III, or of someoneâs
 65136	action an hour ago in choosing one direction out of several for his
 65137	walk, we are unconscious of any contradiction. The degree of freedom and
 65138	inevitability governing the actions of these people is clearly defined
 65139	for us.
 65140	
 65141	Our conception of the degree of freedom often varies according to
 65142	differences in the point of view from which we regard the event, but
 65143	every human action appears to us as a certain combination of freedom and
 65144	inevitability. In every action we examine we see a certain measure of
 65145	freedom and a certain measure of inevitability. And always the more
 65146	freedom we see in any action the less inevitability do we perceive, and
 65147	the more inevitability the less freedom.
 65148	
 65149	The proportion of freedom to inevitability decreases and increases
 65150	according to the point of view from which the action is regarded, but
 65151	their relation is always one of inverse proportion.
 65152	
 65153	A sinking man who clutches at another and drowns him; or a hungry mother
 65154	exhausted by feeding her baby, who steals some food; or a man trained
 65155	to discipline who on duty at the word of command kills a defenseless
 65156	manâseem less guilty, that is, less free and more subject to the law of
 65157	necessity, to one who knows the circumstances in which these people were
 65158	placed, and more free to one who does not know that the man was himself
 65159	drowning, that the mother was hungry, that the soldier was in the ranks,
 65160	and so on. Similarly a man who committed a murder twenty years ago and
 65161	has since lived peaceably and harmlessly in society seems less guilty
 65162	and his action more due to the law of inevitability, to someone who
 65163	considers his action after twenty years have elapsed than to one who
 65164	examined it the day after it was committed. And in the same way every
 65165	action of an insane, intoxicated, or highly excited man appears less
 65166	free and more inevitable to one who knows the mental condition of him
 65167	who committed the action, and seems more free and less inevitable to one
 65168	who does not know it. In all these cases the conception of freedom
 65169	is increased or diminished and the conception of compulsion is
 65170	correspondingly decreased or increased, according to the point of view
 65171	from which the action is regarded. So that the greater the conception of
 65172	necessity the smaller the conception of freedom and vice versa.
 65173	
 65174	Religion, the common sense of mankind, the science of jurisprudence,
 65175	and history itself understand alike this relation between necessity and
 65176	freedom.
 65177	
 65178	All cases without exception in which our conception of freedom and
 65179	necessity is increased and diminished depend on three considerations:
 65180	
 65181	(1) The relation to the external world of the man who commits the deeds.
 65182	
 65183	(2) His relation to time.
 65184	
 65185	(3) His relation to the causes leading to the action.
 65186	
 65187	The first consideration is the clearness of our perception of the manâs
 65188	relation to the external world and the greater or lesser clearness
 65189	of our understanding of the definite position occupied by the man
 65190	in relation to everything coexisting with him. This is what makes it
 65191	evident that a drowning man is less free and more subject to necessity
 65192	than one standing on dry ground, and that makes the actions of a man
 65193	closely connected with others in a thickly populated district, or of one
 65194	bound by family, official, or business duties, seem certainly less free
 65195	and more subject to necessity than those of a man living in solitude and
 65196	seclusion.
 65197	
 65198	If we consider a man alone, apart from his relation to everything around
 65199	him, each action of his seems to us free. But if we see his relation
 65200	to anything around him, if we see his connection with anything
 65201	whateverâwith a man who speaks to him, a book he reads, the work on
 65202	which he is engaged, even with the air he breathes or the light that
 65203	falls on the things about himâwe see that each of these circumstances
 65204	has an influence on him and controls at least some side of his activity.
 65205	And the more we perceive of these influences the more our conception of
 65206	his freedom diminishes and the more our conception of the necessity that
 65207	weighs on him increases.
 65208	
 65209	The second consideration is the more or less evident time relation of
 65210	the man to the world and the clearness of our perception of the place
 65211	the manâs action occupies in time. That is the ground which makes the
 65212	fall of the first man, resulting in the production of the human race,
 65213	appear evidently less free than a manâs entry into marriage today. It is
 65214	the reason why the life and activity of people who lived centuries ago
 65215	and are connected with me in time cannot seem to me as free as the life
 65216	of a contemporary, the consequences of which are still unknown to me.
 65217	
 65218	The degree of our conception of freedom or inevitability depends in this
 65219	respect on the greater or lesser lapse of time between the performance
 65220	of the action and our judgment of it.
 65221	
 65222	If I examine an act I performed a moment ago in approximately the same
