 65223	circumstances as those I am in now, my action appears to me undoubtedly
 65224	free. But if I examine an act performed a month ago, then being in
 65225	different circumstances, I cannot help recognizing that if that act had
 65226	not been committed much that resulted from itâgood, agreeable, and even
 65227	essentialâwould not have taken place. If I reflect on an action still
 65228	more remote, ten years ago or more, then the consequences of my action
 65229	are still plainer to me and I find it hard to imagine what would have
 65230	happened had that action not been performed. The farther I go back
 65231	in memory, or what is the same thing the farther I go forward in my
 65232	judgment, the more doubtful becomes my belief in the freedom of my
 65233	action.
 65234	
 65235	In history we find a very similar progress of conviction concerning
 65236	the part played by free will in the general affairs of humanity. A
 65237	contemporary event seems to us to be indubitably the doing of all the
 65238	known participants, but with a more remote event we already see its
 65239	inevitable results which prevent our considering anything else possible.
 65240	And the farther we go back in examining events the less arbitrary do
 65241	they appear.
 65242	
 65243	The Austro-Prussian war appears to us undoubtedly the result of the
 65244	crafty conduct of Bismarck, and so on. The Napoleonic wars still seem
 65245	to us, though already questionably, to be the outcome of their heroesâ
 65246	will. But in the Crusades we already see an event occupying its definite
 65247	place in history and without which we cannot imagine the modern history
 65248	of Europe, though to the chroniclers of the Crusades that event appeared
 65249	as merely due to the will of certain people. In regard to the migration
 65250	of the peoples it does not enter anyoneâs head today to suppose that
 65251	the renovation of the European world depended on Attilaâs caprice. The
 65252	farther back in history the object of our observation lies, the more
 65253	doubtful does the free will of those concerned in the event become and
 65254	the more manifest the law of inevitability.
 65255	
 65256	The third consideration is the degree to which we apprehend that
 65257	endless chain of causation inevitably demanded by reason, in which each
 65258	phenomenon comprehended, and therefore manâs every action, must have
 65259	its definite place as a result of what has gone before and as a cause of
 65260	what will follow.
 65261	
 65262	The better we are acquainted with the physiological, psychological, and
 65263	historical laws deduced by observation and by which man is controlled,
 65264	and the more correctly we perceive the physiological, psychological,
 65265	and historical causes of the action, and the simpler the action we are
 65266	observing and the less complex the character and mind of the man in
 65267	question, the more subject to inevitability and the less free do our
 65268	actions and those of others appear.
 65269	
 65270	When we do not at all understand the cause of an action, whether a
 65271	crime, a good action, or even one that is simply nonmoral, we ascribe a
 65272	greater amount of freedom to it. In the case of a crime we most urgently
 65273	demand the punishment for such an act; in the case of a virtuous act we
 65274	rate its merit most highly. In an indifferent case we recognize in it
 65275	more individuality, originality, and independence. But if even one of
 65276	the innumerable causes of the act is known to us we recognize a certain
 65277	element of necessity and are less insistent on punishment for the crime,
 65278	or the acknowledgment of the merit of the virtuous act, or the freedom
 65279	of the apparently original action. That a criminal was reared among
 65280	malefactors mitigates his fault in our eyes. The self-sacrifice of a father
 65281	or mother, or self-sacrifice with the possibility of a reward, is more
 65282	comprehensible than gratuitous self-sacrifice, and therefore seems less
 65283	deserving of sympathy and less the result of free will. The founder of a
 65284	sect or party, or an inventor, impresses us less when we know how or by
 65285	what the way was prepared for his activity. If we have a large range
 65286	of examples, if our observation is constantly directed to seeking the
 65287	correlation of cause and effect in peopleâs actions, their actions
 65288	appear to us more under compulsion and less free the more correctly we
 65289	connect the effects with the causes. If we examined simple actions and
 65290	had a vast number of such actions under observation, our conception of
 65291	their inevitability would be still greater. The dishonest conduct of the
 65292	son of a dishonest father, the misconduct of a woman who had fallen
 65293	into bad company, a drunkardâs relapse into drunkenness, and so on are
 65294	actions that seem to us less free the better we understand their cause.
 65295	If the man whose actions we are considering is on a very low stage of
 65296	mental development, like a child, a madman, or a simpletonâthen,
 65297	knowing the causes of the act and the simplicity of the character and
 65298	intelligence in question, we see so large an element of necessity and so
 65299	little free will that as soon as we know the cause prompting the action
 65300	we can foretell the result.
 65301	
 65302	On these three considerations alone is based the conception of
 65303	irresponsibility for crimes and the extenuating circumstances admitted
 65304	by all legislative codes. The responsibility appears greater or less
 65305	according to our greater or lesser knowledge of the circumstances in
 65306	which the man was placed whose action is being judged, and according
 65307	to the greater or lesser interval of time between the commission of the
 65308	action and its investigation, and according to the greater or lesser
 65309	understanding of the causes that led to the action.
 65310	
 65311	
 65312	
 65313	
 65314	
 65315	CHAPTER X
 65316	
 65317	Thus our conception of free will and inevitability gradually diminishes
 65318	or increases according to the greater or lesser connection with the
 65319	external world, the greater or lesser remoteness of time, and the
 65320	greater or lesser dependence on the causes in relation to which we
 65321	contemplate a manâs life.
 65322	
 65323	So that if we examine the case of a man whose connection with the
 65324	external world is well known, where the time between the action and
 65325	its examination is great, and where the causes of the action are most
 65326	accessible, we get the conception of a maximum of inevitability and a
 65327	minimum of free will. If we examine a man little dependent on external
 65328	conditions, whose action was performed very recently, and the causes of
 65329	whose action are beyond our ken, we get the conception of a minimum of
 65330	inevitability and a maximum of freedom.
 65331	
 65332	In neither caseâhowever we may change our point of view, however plain
 65333	we may make to ourselves the connection between the man and the external
 65334	world, however inaccessible it may be to us, however long or short the
 65335	period of time, however intelligible or incomprehensible the causes
 65336	of the action may beâcan we ever conceive either complete freedom or
 65337	complete necessity.
 65338	
 65339	(1) To whatever degree we may imagine a man to be exempt from the
 65340	influence of the external world, we never get a conception of freedom
 65341	in space. Every human action is inevitably conditioned by what surrounds
 65342	him and by his own body. I lift my arm and let it fall. My action seems
 65343	to me free; but asking myself whether I could raise my arm in every
 65344	direction, I see that I raised it in the direction in which there was
 65345	least obstruction to that action either from things around me or from
 65346	the construction of my own body. I chose one out of all the possible
 65347	directions because in it there were fewest obstacles. For my action
 65348	to be free it was necessary that it should encounter no obstacles. To
 65349	conceive of a man being free we must imagine him outside space, which is
 65350	evidently impossible.
 65351	
 65352	(2) However much we approximate the time of judgment to the time of the
 65353	deed, we never get a conception of freedom in time. For if I examine
 65354	an action committed a second ago I must still recognize it as not
 65355	being free, for it is irrevocably linked to the moment at which it was
 65356	committed. Can I lift my arm? I lift it, but ask myself: could I have
 65357	abstained from lifting my arm at the moment that has already passed? To
 65358	convince myself of this I do not lift it the next moment. But I am
 65359	not now abstaining from doing so at the first moment when I asked the
 65360	question. Time has gone by which I could not detain, the arm I then
 65361	lifted is no longer the same as the arm I now refrain from lifting,
 65362	nor is the air in which I lifted it the same that now surrounds me. The
 65363	moment in which the first movement was made is irrevocable, and at that
 65364	moment I could make only one movement, and whatever movement I made
 65365	would be the only one. That I did not lift my arm a moment later does
 65366	not prove that I could have abstained from lifting it then. And since I
 65367	could make only one movement at that single moment of time, it could not
 65368	have been any other. To imagine it as free, it is necessary to imagine
 65369	it in the present, on the boundary between the past and the futureâthat
 65370	is, outside time, which is impossible.
 65371	
 65372	(3) However much the difficulty of understanding the causes may be
 65373	increased, we never reach a conception of complete freedom, that is,
 65374	an absence of cause. However inaccessible to us may be the cause of the
 65375	expression of will in any action, our own or anotherâs, the first demand
 65376	of reason is the assumption of and search for a cause, for without a
 65377	cause no phenomenon is conceivable. I raise my arm to perform an action
 65378	independently of any cause, but my wish to perform an action without a
 65379	cause is the cause of my action.
 65380	
 65381	But even ifâimagining a man quite exempt from all influences, examining
 65382	only his momentary action in the present, unevoked by any causeâwe were
 65383	to admit so infinitely small a remainder of inevitability as equaled
 65384	zero, we should even then not have arrived at the conception of complete
 65385	freedom in man, for a being uninfluenced by the external world, standing
 65386	outside of time and independent of cause, is no longer a man.
 65387	
 65388	In the same way we can never imagine the action of a man quite devoid of
 65389	freedom and entirely subject to the law of inevitability.
 65390	
 65391	(1) However we may increase our knowledge of the conditions of space
 65392	in which man is situated, that knowledge can never be complete, for the
 65393	number of those conditions is as infinite as the infinity of space. And
 65394	therefore so long as not all the conditions influencing men are defined,
 65395	there is no complete inevitability but a certain measure of freedom
 65396	remains.
 65397	
 65398	(2) However we may prolong the period of time between the action we are
 65399	examining and the judgment upon it, that period will be finite, while
 65400	time is infinite, and so in this respect too there can never be absolute
 65401	inevitability.
 65402	
 65403	(3) However accessible may be the chain of causation of any action, we
 65404	shall never know the whole chain since it is endless, and so again we
 65405	never reach absolute inevitability.
 65406	
 65407	But besides this, even if, admitting the remaining minimum of freedom to
 65408	equal zero, we assumed in some given caseâas for instance in that of a
 65409	dying man, an unborn babe, or an idiotâcomplete absence of freedom, by
 65410	so doing we should destroy the very conception of man in the case we are
 65411	examining, for as soon as there is no freedom there is also no man. And
 65412	so the conception of the action of a man subject solely to the law of
 65413	inevitability without any element of freedom is just as impossible as
 65414	the conception of a manâs completely free action.
 65415	
 65416	And so to imagine the action of a man entirely subject to the law of
 65417	inevitability without any freedom, we must assume the knowledge of an
 65418	infinite number of space relations, an infinitely long period of time,
 65419	and an infinite series of causes.
 65420	
 65421	To imagine a man perfectly free and not subject to the law of
 65422	inevitability, we must imagine him all alone, beyond space, beyond time,
 65423	and free from dependence on cause.
 65424	
 65425	In the first case, if inevitability were possible without freedom
 65426	we should have reached a definition of inevitability by the laws of
 65427	inevitability itself, that is, a mere form without content.
 65428	
 65429	In the second case, if freedom were possible without inevitability we
 65430	should have arrived at unconditioned freedom beyond space, time, and
 65431	cause, which by the fact of its being unconditioned and unlimited would
 65432	be nothing, or mere content without form.
 65433	
 65434	We should in fact have reached those two fundamentals of which manâs
 65435	whole outlook on the universe is constructedâthe incomprehensible
 65436	essence of life, and the laws defining that essence.
 65437	
 65438	Reason says: (1) space with all the forms of matter that give it
 65439	visibility is infinite, and cannot be imagined otherwise. (2) Time is
 65440	infinite motion without a moment of rest and is unthinkable otherwise.
 65441	(3) The connection between cause and effect has no beginning and can
 65442	have no end.
 65443	
 65444	Consciousness says: (1) I alone am, and all that exists is but me,
 65445	consequently I include space. (2) I measure flowing time by the fixed
 65446	moment of the present in which alone I am conscious of myself as living,
 65447	consequently I am outside time. (3) I am beyond cause, for I feel myself
 65448	to be the cause of every manifestation of my life.
 65449	
 65450	Reason gives expression to the laws of inevitability. Consciousness
 65451	gives expression to the essence of freedom.
 65452	
 65453	Freedom not limited by anything is the essence of life, in manâs
 65454	consciousness. Inevitability without content is manâs reason in its
 65455	three forms.
 65456	
 65457	Freedom is the thing examined. Inevitability is what examines. Freedom
 65458	is the content. Inevitability is the form.
 65459	
 65460	Only by separating the two sources of cognition, related to one another
 65461	as form to content, do we get the mutually exclusive and separately
 65462	incomprehensible conceptions of freedom and inevitability.
 65463	
 65464	Only by uniting them do we get a clear conception of manâs life.
 65465	
 65466	Apart from these two concepts which in their union mutually define one
 65467	another as form and content, no conception of life is possible.
 65468	
 65469	All that we know of the life of man is merely a certain relation of free
 65470	will to inevitability, that is, of consciousness to the laws of reason.
 65471	
 65472	All that we know of the external world of nature is only a certain
 65473	relation of the forces of nature to inevitability, or of the essence of
 65474	life to the laws of reason.
 65475	
 65476	The great natural forces lie outside us and we are not conscious of
 65477	them; we call those forces gravitation, inertia, electricity, animal
 65478	force, and so on, but we are conscious of the force of life in man and
 65479	we call that freedom.
 65480	
 65481	But just as the force of gravitation, incomprehensible in itself but
 65482	felt by every man, is understood by us only to the extent to which we
 65483	know the laws of inevitability to which it is subject (from the first
 65484	knowledge that all bodies have weight, up to Newtonâs law), so too the
 65485	force of free will, incomprehensible in itself but of which everyone is
 65486	conscious, is intelligible to us only in as far as we know the laws of
 65487	inevitability to which it is subject (from the fact that every man dies,
 65488	up to the knowledge of the most complex economic and historic laws).
 65489	
 65490	All knowledge is merely a bringing of this essence of life under the
 65491	laws of reason.
 65492	
 65493	Manâs free will differs from every other force in that man is directly
 65494	conscious of it, but in the eyes of reason it in no way differs from
 65495	any other force. The forces of gravitation, electricity, or chemical
 65496	affinity are only distinguished from one another in that they are
 65497	differently defined by reason. Just so the force of manâs free will
 65498	is distinguished by reason from the other forces of nature only by the
 65499	definition reason gives it. Freedom, apart from necessity, that is,
 65500	apart from the laws of reason that define it, differs in no way from
 65501	gravitation, or heat, or the force that makes things grow; for reason,
 65502	it is only a momentary undefinable sensation of life.
 65503	
 65504	And as the undefinable essence of the force moving the heavenly bodies,
 65505	the undefinable essence of the forces of heat and electricity, or
 65506	of chemical affinity, or of the vital force, forms the content of
 65507	astronomy, physics, chemistry, botany, zoology, and so on, just in the
 65508	same way does the force of free will form the content of history.
 65509	But just as the subject of every science is the manifestation of this
 65510	unknown essence of life while that essence itself can only be the
 65511	subject of metaphysics, even the manifestation of the force of free will
 65512	in human beings in space, in time, and in dependence on cause forms
 65513	the subject of history, while free will itself is the subject of
 65514	metaphysics.
 65515	
 65516	In the experimental sciences what we know we call the laws of
 65517	inevitability, what is unknown to us we call vital force. Vital force is
 65518	only an expression for the unknown remainder over and above what we know
 65519	of the essence of life.
 65520	
 65521	So also in history what is known to us we call laws of inevitability,
 65522	what is unknown we call free will. Free will is for history only an
 65523	expression for the unknown remainder of what we know about the laws of
 65524	human life.
 65525	
 65526	
 65527	
 65528	
 65529	
 65530	CHAPTER XI
 65531	
 65532	History examines the manifestations of manâs free will in connection
 65533	with the external world in time and in dependence on cause, that is, it
 65534	defines this freedom by the laws of reason, and so history is a science
 65535	only in so far as this free will is defined by those laws.
 65536	
 65537	The recognition of manâs free will as something capable of influencing
 65538	historical events, that is, as not subject to laws, is the same for
 65539	history as the recognition of a free force moving the heavenly bodies
 65540	would be for astronomy.
 65541	
 65542	That assumption would destroy the possibility of the existence of laws,
 65543	that is, of any science whatever. If there is even a single body
 65544	moving freely, then the laws of Kepler and Newton are negatived and no
 65545	conception of the movement of the heavenly bodies any longer exists. If
 65546	any single action is due to free will, then not a single historical law
 65547	can exist, nor any conception of historical events.
 65548	
 65549	For history, lines exist of the movement of human wills, one end
 65550	of which is hidden in the unknown but at the other end of which a
 65551	consciousness of manâs will in the present moves in space, time, and
 65552	dependence on cause.
 65553	
 65554	The more this field of motion spreads out before our eyes, the more
 65555	evident are the laws of that movement. To discover and define those laws
 65556	is the problem of history.
 65557	
 65558	From the standpoint from which the science of history now regards its
 65559	subject on the path it now follows, seeking the causes of events in
 65560	manâs free will, a scientific enunciation of those laws is impossible,
 65561	for however manâs free will may be restricted, as soon as we recognize
 65562	it as a force not subject to law, the existence of law becomes
 65563	impossible.
 65564	
 65565	Only by reducing this element of free will to the infinitesimal, that
 65566	is, by regarding it as an infinitely small quantity, can we convince
 65567	ourselves of the absolute inaccessibility of the causes, and then
 65568	instead of seeking causes, history will take the discovery of laws as
 65569	its problem.
 65570	
 65571	The search for these laws has long been begun and the new methods of
 65572	thought which history must adopt are being worked out simultaneously
 65573	with the self-destruction toward whichâever dissecting and dissecting
 65574	the causes of phenomenaâthe old method of history is moving.
 65575	
 65576	All human sciences have traveled along that path. Arriving at
 65577	infinitesimals, mathematics, the most exact of sciences, abandons the
 65578	process of analysis and enters on the new process of the integration
 65579	of unknown, infinitely small, quantities. Abandoning the conception
 65580	of cause, mathematics seeks law, that is, the property common to all
 65581	unknown, infinitely small, elements.
 65582	
 65583	In another form but along the same path of reflection the other sciences
 65584	have proceeded. When Newton enunciated the law of gravity he did not say
 65585	that the sun or the earth had a property of attraction; he said that all
 65586	bodies from the largest to the smallest have the property of attracting
 65587	one another, that is, leaving aside the question of the cause of the
 65588	movement of the bodies, he expressed the property common to all bodies
 65589	from the infinitely large to the infinitely small. The same is done by
 65590	the natural sciences: leaving aside the question of cause, they seek for
 65591	laws. History stands on the same path. And if history has for its object
 65592	the study of the movement of the nations and of humanity and not the
 65593	narration of episodes in the lives of individuals, it too, setting
 65594	aside the conception of cause, should seek the laws common to all the
 65595	inseparably interconnected infinitesimal elements of free will.
 65596	
 65597	
 65598	
 65599	
 65600	
 65601	CHAPTER XII
 65602	
 65603	From the time the law of Copernicus was discovered and proved, the mere
 65604	recognition of the fact that it was not the sun but the earth that moves
 65605	sufficed to destroy the whole cosmography of the ancients. By disproving
 65606	that law it might have been possible to retain the old conception of
 65607	the movements of the bodies, but without disproving it, it would seem
 65608	impossible to continue studying the Ptolemaic worlds. But even after
 65609	the discovery of the law of Copernicus the Ptolemaic worlds were still
 65610	studied for a long time.
 65611	
 65612	From the time the first person said and proved that the number of births
 65613	or of crimes is subject to mathematical laws, and that this or that
 65614	mode of government is determined by certain geographical and economic
 65615	conditions, and that certain relations of population to soil produce
 65616	migrations of peoples, the foundations on which history had been built
 65617	were destroyed in their essence.
 65618	
 65619	By refuting these new laws the former view of history might have been
 65620	retained; but without refuting them it would seem impossible to continue
 65621	studying historic events as the results of manâs free will. For if a
 65622	certain mode of government was established or certain migrations
 65623	of peoples took place in consequence of such and such geographic,
 65624	ethnographic, or economic conditions, then the free will of those
 65625	individuals who appear to us to have established that mode of government
 65626	or occasioned the migrations can no longer be regarded as the cause.
 65627	
 65628	And yet the former history continues to be studied side by side with the
 65629	laws of statistics, geography, political economy, comparative philology,
 65630	and geology, which directly contradict its assumptions.
 65631	
 65632	The struggle between the old views and the new was long and stubbornly
 65633	fought out in physical philosophy. Theology stood on guard for the
 65634	old views and accused the new of violating revelation. But when truth
 65635	conquered, theology established itself just as firmly on the new
 65636	foundation.
 65637	
 65638	Just as prolonged and stubborn is the struggle now proceeding between
 65639	the old and the new conception of history, and theology in the same way
 65640	stands on guard for the old view, and accuses the new view of subverting
 65641	revelation.
 65642	
 65643	In the one case as in the other, on both sides the struggle provokes
 65644	passion and stifles truth. On the one hand there is fear and regret for
 65645	the loss of the whole edifice constructed through the ages, on the other
 65646	is the passion for destruction.
 65647	
 65648	To the men who fought against the rising truths of physical philosophy,
 65649	it seemed that if they admitted that truth it would destroy faith in
 65650	God, in the creation of the firmament, and in the miracle of Joshua the
 65651	son of Nun. To the defenders of the laws of Copernicus and Newton, to
 65652	Voltaire for example, it seemed that the laws of astronomy destroyed
 65653	religion, and he utilized the law of gravitation as a weapon against
 65654	religion.
 65655	
 65656	Just so it now seems as if we have only to admit the law of
 65657	inevitability, to destroy the conception of the soul, of good and evil,
 65658	and all the institutions of state and church that have been built up on
 65659	those conceptions.
 65660	
 65661	So too, like Voltaire in his time, uninvited defenders of the law of
 65662	inevitability today use that law as a weapon against religion, though
 65663	the law of inevitability in history, like the law of Copernicus in
 65664	astronomy, far from destroying, even strengthens the foundation on which
 65665	the institutions of state and church are erected.
 65666	
 65667	As in the question of astronomy then, so in the question of history
 65668	now, the whole difference of opinion is based on the recognition or
 65669	nonrecognition of something absolute, serving as the measure of visible
 65670	phenomena. In astronomy it was the immovability of the earth, in history
 65671	it is the independence of personalityâfree will.
 65672	
 65673	As with astronomy the difficulty of recognizing the motion of the earth
 65674	lay in abandoning the immediate sensation of the earthâs fixity and of
 65675	the motion of the planets, so in history the difficulty of recognizing
 65676	the subjection of personality to the laws of space, time, and cause
 65677	lies in renouncing the direct feeling of the independence of oneâs own
 65678	personality. But as in astronomy the new view said: âIt is true that we
 65679	do not feel the movement of the earth, but by admitting its immobility
 65680	we arrive at absurdity, while by admitting its motion (which we do not
 65681	feel) we arrive at laws,â so also in history the new view says: âIt is
 65682	true that we are not conscious of our dependence, but by admitting our
 65683	free will we arrive at absurdity, while by admitting our dependence on
 65684	the external world, on time, and on cause, we arrive at laws.â
 65685	
 65686	In the first case it was necessary to renounce the consciousness of an
 65687	unreal immobility in space and to recognize a motion we did not feel;
 65688	in the present case it is similarly necessary to renounce a freedom
 65689	that does not exist, and to recognize a dependence of which we are not
 65690	conscious.
 65691
